There are, of course, wealthy people who also spend a lot of money on stuff. But even in those cases what we see is their richness, not their wealth. We see the cars they chose to buy and perhaps the school they choose to send their kids to. We don’t see the savings, retirement accounts, or investment portfolios. We see the homes they bought, not the homes they could have bought had they stretched themselves thin.

当然，也有一些富人会在物质上花很多钱。但即使在这些情况下，我们看到的也是他们的富裕程度，而不是他们的财富。我们看到的是他们选择购买的汽车，或许还有他们选择送孩子去的学校。我们看不到他们的储蓄、退休账户或投资组合。我们看到的是他们购买的房子，而不是他们如果精打细算就能买到的房子。

The danger here is that I think most people, deep down, want to be wealthy. They want freedom and flexibility, which is what financial assets not yet spent can give you. But it is so ingrained in us that to have money is to spend money that we don’t get to see the restraint it takes to actually be wealthy. And since we can’t see it, it’s hard to learn about it.

危险在于，我认为大多数人内心深处都渴望致富。他们渴望自由和灵活性，而这正是尚未动用金融资产所能提供的。但“有钱就得花钱”的观念在我们心中根深蒂固，以至于我们看不到真正致富所需的克制。正因为我们看不到这一点，所以很难去了解这一点。

People are good at learning by imitation. But the hidden nature of wealth makes it hard to imitate others and learn from their ways. After he died, Ronald Read became many people’s financial role model. He was lionized in the media and cherished on social media. But he was nobody’s financial role model while he was living because every penny of his wealth was hidden, even to those who knew him.

人们擅长通过模仿学习。但财富的隐蔽性使得模仿他人并学习其行事方式变得困难。罗纳德·里德去世后，成为许多人的理财榜样。他被媒体推崇，在社交媒体上备受追捧。但他在世时并非任何人的理财榜样，因为他的每一分钱都隐藏起来，即使是认识他的人也看不到。

Imagine how hard it would be to learn how to write if you couldn’t read the works of great authors. Who would be your inspiration? Who would you admire? Whose nuanced tricks and tips would you follow? It would make something that is already hard even harder. It’s difficult to learn from what you can’t see. Which helps explain why it’s so hard for many to build wealth.

想象一下，如果你读不到伟大作家的作品，学习写作会有多难。谁会成为你的灵感来源？你会钦佩谁？你会效仿谁的精妙技巧？这会让本来就很难的事情变得更加困难。从你看不见的东西中学习是很困难的。这也解释了为什么很多人积累财富如此困难。

The world is filled with people who look modest but are actually wealthy and people who look rich who live at the razor’s edge of insolvency. Keep this in mind when quickly judging others’ success and setting your own goals.

世界上有很多看似平凡却实则富有的人，也有很多看似富有却濒临破产的人。在快速评判他人的成功并设定自己的目标时，请记住这一点。

If wealth is what you don’t spend, what good is it? Well, let me convince you to save money.

如果财富就是你不花的钱，那它还有什么用呢？好吧，让我来说服你存钱。

#↩

#↩

Let me convince you to save money.

让我说服你省钱。

It won’t take long.

不会花很长时间。

But it’s an odd task, isn’t it?

但这是一个奇怪的任务，不是吗？

Do people need to be convinced to save money?

人们需要被说服才能省钱吗？

My observation is that, yes, many do.

我的观察是，确实有很多人这样做。

Past a certain level of income people fall into three groups: Those who save, those who don’t think they can save, and those who don’t think they need to save.

超过一定的收入水平后，人们会分为三类：储蓄的人、认为自己无法储蓄的人和认为自己不需要储蓄的人。

This is for the latter two.

这是针对后两者而言的。

The first idea—simple, but easy to overlook—is that building wealth has little to do with your income or investment returns, and lots to do with your savings rate.

第一个想法很简单，但很容易被忽视，那就是积累财富与你的收入或投资回报关系不大，而与你的储蓄率关系很大。

A quick story about the power of efficiency.

关于效率的力量的一个简短故事。

In the 1970s the world looked like it was running out of oil. The calculation wasn’t hard: The global economy used a lot of oil, the global economy was growing, and the amount of oil we could drill couldn’t keep up.

20世纪70年代，世界石油资源似乎即将枯竭。原因很简单：全球经济消耗了大量石油，全球经济持续增长，而我们能够开采的石油量却远远跟不上。

We didn’t run out of oil, thank goodness. But that wasn’t just because we found more oil, or even got better at taking it out of the ground.

谢天谢地，我们的石油没有枯竭。但这不仅仅是因为我们发现了更多的石油，甚至不仅仅是因为我们开采石油的技术进步了。

The biggest reason we overcame the oil crisis is because we started building cars, factories, and homes that are more energy efficient than they used to be. The United States uses 60% less energy per dollar of GDP today than it did in 1950.³² The average miles per gallon of all vehicles on the road has doubled since 1975. A 1989 Ford Taurus (sedan) averaged 18.0 MPG. A 2019 Chevy Suburban (absurdly large SUV) averages 18.1 MPG.

我们战胜石油危机的最大原因是我们开始建造比以往更节能的汽车、工厂和住宅。如今，美国每美元GDP的能耗比1950年降低了60%。³² 自1975年以来，道路上所有车辆的平均每加仑行驶里程翻了一番。1989年的福特金牛座（轿车）平均每加仑行驶里程为18.0英里。2019年的雪佛兰Suburban（超大SUV）平均每加仑行驶里程为18.1英里。

The world grew its “energy wealth” not by increasing the energy it had, but by decreasing the energy it needed. U.S. oil and gas production has increased 65% since 1975, while conservation and efficiency has more than doubled what we can do with that energy. So it’s easy to see which has mattered more.

世界“能源财富”的增长并非源于能源储备的增加，而是源于能源需求的减少。自1975年以来，美国石油和天然气产量增长了65%，而节能减排和能源效率的提高则使能源利用效率翻了一番多。因此，显而易见，哪个因素更为重要。

The important thing here is that finding more energy is largely out of our control and shrouded in uncertainty, because it relies on a slippery mix of having the right geology, geography, weather, and geopolitics. But becoming more efficient with the energy we use is largely in our control. The decision to buy a lighter car or ride a bike is up to you and has a 100% chance of improving efficiency.

重要的是，寻找更多能源在很大程度上不受我们控制，充满不确定性，因为它依赖于地质、地理、天气和地缘政治等各种难以捉摸的因素。但提高能源使用效率在很大程度上取决于我们自己。购买更轻的汽车或骑自行车的决定权在你手中，而且有100%的机会提高能源效率。

The same is true with our money.

我们的钱也是如此。

Investment returns can make you rich. But whether an investing strategy will work, and how long it will work for, and whether markets will cooperate, is always in doubt. Results are shrouded in uncertainty.

投资回报可以让你致富。但投资策略是否有效、能维持多久、市场是否会配合，始终存在疑问。结果笼罩在不确定性之中。

Personal savings and frugality—finance’s conservation and efficiency—are parts of the money equation that are more in your control and have a 100% chance of being as effective in the future as they are today.

个人储蓄和节俭——财务的节约和效率——是金钱等式的一部分，它们更受你控制，并且有 100% 的机会在未来像现在一样有效。

If you view building wealth as something that will require more money or big investment returns, you may become as pessimistic as the energy doomers were in the 1970s. The path forward looks hard and out of your control.

如果你认为积累财富需要投入更多资金或获得巨额投资回报，你可能会变得像20世纪70年代的能源末日论者一样悲观。未来的道路看起来充满艰辛，而且不受你掌控。

If you view it as powered by your own frugality and efficiency, the destiny is clearer.

如果你将其视为由自己的节俭和效率所驱动，那么命运就更加清晰了。

Wealth is just the accumulated leftovers after you spend what you take in. And since you can build wealth without a high income, but have no chance of building wealth without a high savings rate, it’s clear which one matters more.

财富只不过是花掉收入之后积累的剩余部分。没有高收入你也可以积累财富，但如果没有高储蓄率就不可能积累财富，所以哪一个更重要显而易见。

More importantly, the value of wealth is relative to what you need.

更重要的是，财富的价值是相对于你所需要的而言的。

Say you and I have the same net worth.

假设你和我的净资产相同。

And say you’re a better investor than me. I can earn 8% annual returns and you can earn 12% annual returns.

假设你比我更擅长投资。我可以赚取 8% 的年回报率，而你可以赚取 12% 的年回报率。

But I’m more efficient with my money. Let’s say I need half as much money to be happy while your lifestyle compounds as fast as your assets.

但我的理财效率更高。假设我需要的钱只有现在的一半就能快乐，而你的生活方式却能像你的资产一样快速增长。

I’m better off than you are, despite being a worse investor. I’m getting more benefit from my investments despite lower returns.

尽管我的投资水平不如你，但我的状况比你好。尽管回报率较低，但我的投资收益却更高。

The same is true for incomes. Learning to be happy with less money creates a gap between what you have and what you want—similar to the gap you get from growing your paycheck, but easier and more in your control.

收入也是如此。学会用更少的钱获得快乐，会让你拥有的和你想要的之间产生差距——类似于你薪水增加带来的差距，但更容易掌控。

A high savings rate means having lower expenses than you otherwise could, and having lower expenses means your savings go farther than they would if you spent more.

高储蓄率意味着您的支出比其他情况下要低，而支出较低意味着您的储蓄比您花费更多时更有用。

Think about this in the context of how much time and effort goes into achieving 0.1% of annual investment outperformance—millions of hours of research, tens of billions of dollars of effort from professionals—and it’s easy to see what’s potentially more important or worth chasing.

想想看，为了实现 0.1% 的年度投资超额收益需要投入多少时间和精力——数百万小时的研究、数百亿美元的专业人士的努力——我们就很容易看出什么可能更重要或更值得追求。

There are professional investors who grind 80 hours a week to add a tenth of a percentage point to their returns when there are two or three full percentage points of lifestyle bloat in their finances that can be exploited with less effort.

有些专业投资者每周工作 80 个小时，只为增加十分之一的回报，而实际上他们的财务状况中，有两到三个百分点是生活方式造成的膨胀，可以用较少的努力来利用。

Big investment returns and fat paychecks are amazing when they can be achieved, and some can achieve them. But the fact that there’s so much effort put into one side of the finance equation and so little put into the other is an opportunity for most people.

丰厚的投资回报和丰厚的薪水，如果能够实现，当然令人惊喜，而且有些人确实能够做到。但事实上，在财务等式的一边投入如此多的努力，而在另一边却投入如此少，这对大多数人来说却是一个机会。

Past a certain level of income, what you need is just what sits below your ego.

超过一定的收入水平后，你所需要的只是能满足你自尊心的东西。

Everyone needs the basics. Once they’re covered there’s another level of comfortable basics, and past that there’s basics that are both comfortable, entertaining, and enlightening.

每个人都需要基础知识。一旦掌握了基础知识，就会有另一层舒适的基础知识，而在此之上，还有既舒适又有趣、富有启发性的基础知识。

But spending beyond a pretty low level of materialism is mostly a reflection of ego approaching income, a way to spend money to show people that you have (or had) money.

但是，超出相当低的物质水平的消费大多是自我接近收入的体现，是一种花钱的方式，向人们展示你有钱（或曾经有钱）。

Think of it like this, and one of the most powerful ways to increase your savings isn’t to raise your income. It’s to raise your humility.

想想看，增加储蓄最有效的方法之一不是提高收入，而是提高谦逊的品质。

When you define savings as the gap between your ego and your income you realize why many people with decent incomes save so little. It’s a daily struggle against instincts to extend your peacock feathers to their outermost limits and keep up with others doing the same.

当你把储蓄定义为你的自我价值感和收入之间的差距时，你就会明白为什么很多收入不错的人却储蓄如此之少。这就像一场每日与本能的斗争，让你的孔雀羽毛伸展到极致，并跟上其他人的步伐。

People with enduring personal finance success—not necessarily those with high incomes—tend to have a propensity to not give a damn what others think about them.

拥有持久个人财务成功的人（不一定是高收入者）往往倾向于不在乎别人对他们的看法。

So people’s ability to save is more in their control than they might think.

因此，人们的储蓄能力比他们想象的更受他们控制。

Savings can be created by spending less.

减少支出就能节省开支。

You can spend less if you desire less.

如果你想要的少一点，你就可以花更少的钱。

And you will desire less if you care less about what others think of you.

如果你不那么在意别人对你的看法，你的欲望就会减少。

As I argue often in this book, money relies more on psychology than finance.

正如我在本书中经常论证的那样，金钱更多地依赖于心理而不是财务。

And you don’t need a specific reason to save.

而且您不需要特定的理由来储蓄。

Some people save money for a downpayment on a house, or a new car, or for retirement.

有些人存钱是为了支付房子的首付、新车的首付或者退休金。

That’s great, of course.

那当然很好。

But saving does not require a goal of purchasing something specific.

但储蓄并不需要以购买特定的东西为目标。

You can save just for saving’s sake. And indeed you should. Everyone should.

你可以为了省钱而省钱。你确实应该这样做。每个人都应该这样做。

Only saving for a specific goal makes sense in a predictable world. But ours isn’t. Saving is a hedge against life’s inevitable ability to surprise the hell out of you at the worst possible moment.

在这个可预测的世界里，只为特定目标而储蓄才有意义。但我们的世界并非如此。储蓄是为了对冲生活不可避免的意外，避免在最糟糕的时刻给你带来意外。

Another benefit of savings that isn’t attached to a spending goal is what we discussed in chapter 7: gaining control over your time.

不附加支出目标的储蓄的另一个好处是我们在第 7 章中讨论过的：掌控自己的时间。

Everyone knows the tangible stuff money buys. The intangible stuff is harder to wrap your head around, so it tends to go unnoticed. But the intangible benefits of money can be far more valuable and capable of increasing your happiness than the tangible things that are obvious targets of our savings.

每个人都知道金钱能买到有形的东西。无形的东西更难理解，所以往往被忽视。但金钱带来的无形利益可能比那些我们明显储蓄的有形物品更有价值，也更能提升你的幸福感。

Savings without a spending goal gives you options and flexibility, the ability to wait and the opportunity to pounce. It gives you time to think. It lets you change course on your own terms.

没有支出目标的储蓄能给你选择和灵活性，让你有等待的能力，也有把握抓住机会。它给了你思考的时间，让你能够根据自己的意愿改变方向。

Every bit of savings is like taking a point in the future that would have been owned by someone else and giving it back to yourself.

每一点的节省，都像是把未来原本属于别人的一点，拿回来给自己。

That flexibility and control over your time is an unseen return on wealth.

这种灵活性和对时间的控制是一种看不见的财富回报。

What is the return on cash in the bank that gives you the option of changing careers, or retiring early, or freedom from worry?

银行里的现金能给你带来多少回报，让你可以选择改变职业、提前退休或无忧无虑？

I’d say it’s incalculable.

我想说这是无法估量的。

It’s incalculable in two ways. It’s so large and important that we can’t put a price on it. But it’s also literally incalculable—we can’t measure it like we can measure interest rates—and what we can’t measure we tend to overlook.

它在两个方面是无法估量的。它如此庞大、如此重要，以至于我们无法用金钱来衡量它。但它也确实无法估量——我们无法像衡量利率那样衡量它——而我们往往会忽略那些无法衡量的东西。

When you don’t have control over your time, you’re forced to accept whatever bad luck is thrown your way. But if you have flexibility you have the time to wait for no-brainer opportunities to fall in your lap. This is a hidden return on your savings.

当你无法掌控自己的时间时，你只能被迫接受任何厄运。但如果你有灵活性，你就有时间等待那些无需思考就能轻易获得的机会。这就是你储蓄的隐性回报。

Savings in the bank that earn 0% interest might actually generate an extraordinary return if they give you the flexibility to take a job with a lower salary but more purpose, or wait for investment opportunities that come when those without flexibility turn desperate.

如果银行里的零利率储蓄能让你灵活地接受一份薪水较低但更有意义的工作，或者等待那些缺乏灵活性的人陷入绝望时出现的投资机会，那么它们实际上可能会产生非凡的回报。

And that hidden return is becoming more important.

而这种隐藏的回报正变得越来越重要。

The world used to be hyper-local. Just over 100 years ago 75% of Americans had neither telephones nor regular mail service, according to historian Robert Gordon. That made competition hyper-local. A worker with just average intelligence might be the best in their town, and they got treated like the best because they didn’t have to compete with the smarter worker in another town.

世界曾经高度本地化。据历史学家罗伯特·戈登称，就在100多年前，75%的美国人既没有电话，也没有普通的邮政服务。这使得竞争高度本地化。一个智力平平的工人可能就是他们所在城镇最优秀的人，而且他们也得到了最优秀的待遇，因为他们不必与另一个城镇更聪明的工人竞争。

That’s now changed.

现在情况已经改变。

A hyper-connected world means the talent pool you compete in has gone from hundreds or thousands spanning your town to millions or billions spanning the globe. This is especially true for jobs that rely on working with your head versus your muscles: teaching, marketing, analysis, consulting, accounting, programming, journalism, and even medicine increasingly compete in global talent pools. More fields will fall into this category as digitization erases global boundaries—as “software eats the world,” as venture capitalist Marc Andreesen puts it.

高度互联的世界意味着，你所竞争的人才库已从遍布城镇的数百或数千人，扩展到遍布全球的数百万或数十亿人。对于那些依赖脑力而非体力劳动的职业来说尤其如此：教学、市场营销、分析、咨询、会计、编程、新闻，甚至医学，在全球人才库中的竞争日益激烈。随着数字化消除全球界限——正如风险投资家马克·安德森所说，“软件吞噬世界”，越来越多的领域将陷入这一境地。

A question you should ask as the range of your competition expands is, “How do I stand out?”

随着竞争范围的扩大，你应该问的一个问题是：“我如何脱颖而出？”

“I’m smart” is increasingly a bad answer to that question, because there are a lot of smart people in the world. Almost 600 people ace the SATs each year. Another 7,000 come within a handful of points. In a winner-take-all and globalized world these kinds of people are increasingly your direct competitors.

“我很聪明”越来越不像是一个好的答案，因为世界上有很多聪明人。每年有近600人在SAT考试中取得高分，另有7000人的分数只相差几分。在一个赢家通吃、全球化的世界里，这些人越来越成为你的直接竞争对手。

Intelligence is not a reliable advantage in a world that’s become as connected as ours has.

在当今这个互联互通的世界里，智力并不是一个可靠的优势。

But flexibility is.

但灵活性是。

In a world where intelligence is hyper-competitive and many previous technical skills have become automated, competitive advantages tilt toward nuanced and soft skills—like communication, empathy, and, perhaps most of all, flexibility.

在这个情报竞争异常激烈、许多以前的技术技能已经实现自动化的世界里，竞争优势倾向于细致入微的软技能，比如沟通能力、同理心，以及最重要的灵活性。

If you have flexibility you can wait for good opportunities, both in your career and for your investments. You’ll have a better chance of being able to learn a new skill when it’s necessary. You’ll feel less urgency to chase competitors who can do things you can’t, and have more leeway to find your passion and your niche at your own pace. You can find a new routine, a slower pace, and think about life with a different set of assumptions. The ability to do those things when most others can’t is one of the few things that will set you apart in a world where intelligence is no longer a sustainable advantage.

如果你拥有灵活性，你就能等待良机，无论是在事业上还是在投资方面。你将更有可能在必要时学习新技能。你不再急于追逐那些能做到你做不到的事情的竞争对手，而是拥有更多自由，按照自己的节奏找到激情所在和利基市场。你可以找到新的日常，放慢节奏，用不同的假设来思考生活。在这个智力不再是可持续优势的世界里，拥有在大多数人做不到的时候做到这些的能力，是少数几个能让你脱颖而出的因素之一。

Having more control over your time and options is becoming one of the most valuable currencies in the world.

更好地控制自己的时间和选择正在成为世界上最有价值的货币之一。

That’s why more people can, and more people should, save money.

这就是为什么更多的人能够、而且更多的人应该存钱。

You know what else they should do? Stop trying to be so rational. Let me tell you why.

你知道他们还应该做什么吗？别再那么理性了。让我来告诉你原因。

#↩

#↩

You’re not a spreadsheet. You’re a person. A screwed up, emotional person.

你不是一张电子表格。你是一个人。一个精神失常、情绪化的人。

It took me a while to figure this out, but once it clicked I realized it’s one of the most important parts of finance.

我花了一段时间才弄明白这一点，但一旦明白了，我意识到这是金融最重要的部分之一。

With it comes something that often goes overlooked: Do not aim to be coldly rational when making financial decisions. Aim to just be pretty reasonable. Reasonable is more realistic and you have a better chance of sticking with it for the long run, which is what matters most when managing money.

随之而来的是经常被忽视的一点：做财务决策时，不要力求冷酷理性。力求做到相当理性就好。理性更现实，你更有可能长期坚持下去，而这才是理财最重要的。

To show you what I mean, let me tell you the story of a guy who tried to cure syphilis with malaria.

为了向您说明我的意思，让我给您讲一个试图用疟疾治愈梅毒的人的故事。

Julius Wagner-Jauregg was a 19th-century psychiatrist with two unique skills: He was good at recognizing patterns, and what others saw as “crazy” he found merely “bold.”

朱利叶斯·瓦格纳-贾雷格 (Julius Wagner-Jauregg) 是 19 世纪的一位精神病学家，拥有两项独特的技能：他善于识别模式，而其他人认为的“疯狂”在他看来只是“大胆”。

His specialty was patients with severe neurosyphilis—then a fatal diagnosis with no known treatment. He began noticing a pattern: syphilis patients tended to recover if they had the added misfortune of having prolonged fevers from an unrelated ailment.

他的专长是治疗重症神经梅毒——当时这种疾病是致命的，且没有已知的治疗方法。他开始注意到一个规律：如果梅毒患者不幸患上了与自身无关的疾病，并伴有长时间发烧，他们往往会康复。

Wagner-Jauregg assumed this was due to a hunch that had been around for centuries but doctors didn’t understand well: fevers play a role in helping the body fight infection.

瓦格纳-乔雷格认为，这是由于几个世纪以来医生们一直不太理解的一种猜测：发烧有助于身体抵抗感染。

So he jumped to the logical conclusion.

因此他得出了合乎逻辑的结论。

In the early 1900s Wagner-Jauregg began injecting patients with low-end strains of typhoid, malaria, and smallpox to trigger fevers strong enough to kill off their syphilis. This was as dangerous as it sounds. Some of his patients died from the treatment. He eventually settled on a weak version of malaria, since it could be effectively countered with quinine after a few days of bone-rattling fevers.

20世纪初，瓦格纳-乔雷格开始给病人注射低毒株的伤寒、疟疾和天花病毒，以引发足以杀死梅毒的强烈发烧。这听起来很危险。他的一些病人死于这种疗法。最终，他选择了一种弱效的疟疾疗法，因为在几天令人毛骨悚然的高烧之后，用奎宁就能有效缓解。

After some tragic trial and error his experiment worked. Wagner-Jauregg reported that 6 in 10 syphilis patients treated with “malariotherapy” recovered, compared to around 3 in 10 patients left alone. He won the Nobel Prize in medicine in 1927. The organization today notes: “The main work that concerned Wagner-Jauregg throughout his working life was the endeavour to cure mental disease by inducing a fever.”³³

经过一番悲惨的反复尝试，他的实验终于成功了。瓦格纳-若雷格报告称，接受“疟疾疗法”治疗的梅毒患者中，每10人中有6人康复，而未接受治疗的患者中，只有约3人康复。他于1927年获得了诺贝尔医学奖。该组织今天指出：“瓦格纳-若雷格毕生致力于通过诱导发烧来治疗精神疾病。”³³

Penicillin eventually made malariotherapy for syphilis patients obsolete, thank goodness. But Wagner-Jauregg is one of the only doctors in history who not only recognized fever’s role in fighting infection, but also prescribed it as a treatment.

谢天谢地，青霉素最终使梅毒患者的疟疾疗法失效。但瓦格纳-乔雷格是历史上少数几位不仅认识到发烧在抵抗感染中的作用，还将其作为治疗方法的医生之一。

Fevers have always been as feared as they are mysterious. Ancient Romans worshiped Febris, the Goddess who protected people from fevers. Amulets were left at temples to placate her, hoping to stave off the next round of shivers.

发烧一直以来都既令人恐惧又神秘莫测。古罗马人崇拜菲布里斯女神，她守护着人们免受发烧的侵袭。人们在神庙里放置护身符来安抚她，希望能借此阻止下一轮的发烧。

But Wagner-Jauregg was onto something. Fevers are not accidental nuisances. They do play a role in the body’s road to recovery. We now have better, more scientific evidence of fever’s usefulness in fighting infection. A one-degree increase in body temperature has been shown to slow the replication rate of some viruses by a factor of 200. “Numerous investigators have identified a better outcome among patients who displayed fever,” one NIH paper writes.³⁴ The Seattle Children’s Hospital includes a section on its website to educate parents who may panic at the slightest rise in their child’s temperature: “Fevers turn on the body’s immune system. They help the body fight infection. Normal fevers between 100° and 104° f are good for sick children.”³⁵

但瓦格纳-乔雷格的发现确有道理。发烧并非偶然的烦恼，而是在身体康复过程中发挥着重要作用。现在，我们有更充分、更科学的证据证明发烧有助于抵抗感染。研究表明，体温升高一度可以使某些病毒的复制速度减慢 200 倍。美国国立卫生研究院的一篇论文写道：“许多研究人员发现，出现发烧症状的患者预后更佳。”³⁴西雅图儿童医院在其网站上设立了一个专题，专门教育那些可能因孩子体温稍有升高而惊慌失措的家长：“发烧会启动身体的免疫系统，帮助身体抵抗感染。100° 到 104° 华氏度之间的正常发烧对患病儿童有益。”³⁵

But that’s where the science ends and reality takes over.

但科学的界限就此终结，现实占据主导地位。

Fever is almost universally seen as a bad thing. They’re treated with drugs like Tylenol to reduce them as quickly as they appear. Despite millions of years of evolution as a defense mechanism, no parent, no patient, few doctors, and certainly no drug company views fever as anything but a misfortune that should be eliminated.

发烧几乎被普遍视为一件坏事。人们会用泰诺之类的药物来治疗，以便在发烧出现时尽快退烧。尽管发烧作为一种防御机制已经进化了数百万年，但所有家长、所有患者、所有医生，当然还有所有制药公司，都认为发烧不应该是一种不幸，应该被彻底根除。

These views do not match the known science. One study was blunt: “Treatment of fever is common in the ICU setting and likely related to standard dogma rather than evidence-based practice.”³⁶ Howard Markel, director of the Center for the History of Medicine, once said of fever phobia: “These are cultural practices that spread just as widely as the infectious diseases that are behind them.”³⁷

这些观点与已知的科学不符。一项研究直言不讳：“在ICU环境中，发烧的治疗很常见，而且很可能与标准教条有关，而非循证实践。”³⁶ 医学史中心主任霍华德·马克尔曾这样评价发烧恐惧症：“这些文化习俗的传播范围与其背后的传染病一样广泛。”³⁷

Why does this happen? If fevers are beneficial, why do we fight them so universally?

为什么会发生这种情况？如果发烧有益，为什么我们却普遍地抗拒它？

I don’t think it’s complicated: Fevers hurt. And people don’t want to hurt.

我觉得这没什么复杂的：发烧很疼，而且人们不想疼。

That’s it.

就是这样。

A doctor’s goal is not just to cure disease. It’s to cure disease within the confines of what’s reasonable and tolerable to the patient. Fevers can have marginal benefits in fighting infection, but they hurt. And I go to the doctor to stop hurting. I don’t care about double-blind studies when I’m shivering under a blanket. If you have a pill that can make a fever stop, give it to me now.

医生的目标不仅仅是治愈疾病，而是在患者合理且可耐受的范围内治愈疾病。发烧对抗感染或许能带来些许益处，但却很疼。我去看医生就是为了缓解疼痛。我躲在毯子里瑟瑟发抖，根本不在乎双盲研究。如果你有退烧药，现在就给我。

It may be rational to want a fever if you have an infection. But it’s not reasonable.

如果你感染了，发烧可能是合理的，但这并不合理。

That philosophy—aiming to be reasonable instead of rational—is one more people should consider when making decisions with their money.

这种追求合理而非理性的理念是人们在用钱做决定时应该考虑的。

Academic finance is devoted to finding the mathematically optimal investment strategies. My own theory is that, in the real world, people do not want the mathematically optimal strategy. They want the strategy that maximizes for how well they sleep at night.

学术金融致力于寻找数学上最优的投资策略。我自己的理论是，在现实世界中，人们想要的并非数学上最优的策略，而是能够最大程度提升睡眠质量的策略。

Harry Markowitz won the Nobel Prize for exploring the mathematical tradeoff between risk and return. He was once asked how he invested his own money, and described his portfolio allocation in the 1950s, when his models were first developed:

哈里·马科维茨因探索风险与回报之间的数学权衡而获得诺贝尔奖。有人曾问他如何投资自己的资金，他描述了自己在20世纪50年代（他的模型首次开发时）的投资组合配置：

I visualized my grief if the stock market went way up and I wasn’t in it—or if it went way down and I was completely in it. My intention was to minimize my future regret. So I split my contributions 50/50 between bonds and equities.

我设想了如果股市大幅上涨而我没有参与，或者股市大幅下跌而我完全参与其中，我的悲伤会如何。我的目的是尽量减少未来的遗憾。所以我把我的资金分成两部分，一半投资于债券，一半投资于股票。

Markowitz eventually changed his investment strategy, diversifying the mix. But two things here are important.

马科维茨最终改变了他的投资策略，实现了投资组合的多元化。但这里有两点很重要。

One is that “minimizing future regret” is hard to rationalize on paper but easy to justify in real life. A rational investor makes decisions based on numeric facts. A reasonable investor makes them in a conference room surrounded by co-workers you want to think highly of you, with a spouse you don’t want to let down, or judged against the silly but realistic competitors that are your brother-in-law, your neighbor, and your own personal doubts. Investing has a social component that’s often ignored when viewed through a strictly financial lens.

一是“尽量减少未来的遗憾”在纸面上难以合理化，但在现实生活中却很容易证明。理性的投资者会根据数字事实做出决策。理性的投资者会在会议室里做出决策，周围都是你希望自己被高度评价的同事，有你不想让配偶失望的伴侣，或者被那些愚蠢但现实的竞争对手——你的姐夫、邻居和你自己的疑虑——评判。投资本身就具有社会因素，而从严格的金融视角来看，这一点常常被忽视。

The second is that this is fine. Jason Zweig, who conducted the interview when Markowitz described how he invested, later reflected:

第二，这没什么问题。在 Markowitz 描述他的投资方式时，Jason Zweig 进行了采访，后来他反思道：

My own view is that people are neither rational nor irrational. We are human. We don’t like to think harder than we need to, and we have unceasing demands on our attention. Seen in that light, there’s nothing surprising about the fact that the pioneer of modern portfolio theory built his initial portfolio with so little regard for his own research. Nor is it surprising that he adjusted it later.³⁸

我个人的观点是，人既非理性也非非理性。我们是凡人。我们不喜欢过度思考，而且我们的注意力总是被无休止地占据。从这个角度来看，现代投资组合理论的先驱在构建其最初的投资组合时，如此少地考虑自己的研究成果，也就不足为奇了。他后来对其进行调整也同样不足为奇。³⁸

Markowitz is neither rational or irrational. He’s reasonable.

马科维茨既不理性，也不非理性。他是通情达理的。

What’s often overlooked in finance is that something can be technically true but contextually nonsense.

在金融领域经常被忽视的是，有些事情从技术上来说可能是正确的，但从具体情况来看却毫无意义。

In 2008 a pair of researchers from Yale published a study arguing young savers should supercharge their retirement accounts using two-to-one margin (two dollars of debt for every dollar of their own money) when buying stocks. It suggests investors taper that leverage as they age, which lets a saver take more risk when they’re young and can handle a magnified market rollercoaster, and less when they’re older.

2008年，耶鲁大学的两位研究人员发表了一项研究，认为年轻的储户在购买股票时应该使用二比一的保证金（即每投资一美元自有资金，就投资两美元的债务）来增加退休账户的资金。该研究建议投资者随着年龄的增长逐渐减少杠杆，这样储户在年轻时可以承担更多风险，从而能够应对剧烈的市场波动；而年老后，风险承担则会减少。

Even if using leverage left you wiped out when you were young (if you use two-to-one margin a 50% market drop leaves you with nothing) the researchers showed savers would still be better off in the long run so long as they picked themselves back up, followed the plan, and kept saving in a two-to-one leveraged account the day after being wiped out.

即使使用杠杆让你在年轻时倾家荡产（如果你使用二比一的保证金，市场下跌 50% 会让你一无所有），研究人员表明，只要储蓄者重新振作起来，遵循计划，并在倾家荡产后的第二天继续在二比一的杠杆账户中储蓄，从长远来看，他们的状况仍然会更好。

The math works on paper. It’s a rational strategy.

理论上来说，数学是可行的。这是一个理性的策略。

But it’s almost absurdly unreasonable.

但这几乎是荒谬至极的。

No normal person could watch 100% of their retirement account evaporate and be so unphased that they carry on with the strategy undeterred. They’d quit, look for a different option, and perhaps sue their financial advisor.

没有哪个正常人会眼睁睁地看着自己的退休账户100%蒸发，却依然无动于衷，继续执行这个策略。他们会选择辞职，寻找其他选择，甚至起诉他们的理财顾问。

The researchers argued that when using their strategy “the expected retirement wealth is 90% higher compared to life-cycle funds.” It is also 100% less reasonable.

研究人员认为，采用他们的策略时，“预期退休财富比生命周期基金高出 90%。”而且，其合理性也降低了 100%。

There is, in fact, a rational reason to favor what look like irrational decisions.

事实上，支持看似非理性的决定是有理性的理由的。

Here’s one: Let me suggest that you love your investments.

其中一条是：我建议你热爱你的投资。

This is not traditional advice. It’s almost a badge of honor for investors to claim they’re emotionless about their investments, because it seems rational.

这不是传统的建议。对于投资者来说，声称自己对投资不带感情几乎是一种荣誉，因为这看起来很理性。

But if lacking emotions about your strategy or the stocks you own increases the odds you’ll walk away from them when they become difficult, what looks like rational thinking becomes a liability. The reasonable investors who love their technically imperfect strategies have an edge, because they’re more likely to stick with those strategies.

但如果对你的策略或持有的股票缺乏情感，就会增加你在遇到困境时抛售的可能性，那么看似理性的思考就成了负担。那些喜欢技术上不完美的策略的理性投资者拥有优势，因为他们更有可能坚持这些策略。

There are few financial variables more correlated to performance than commitment to a strategy during its lean years—both the amount of performance and the odds of capturing it over a given period of time. The historical odds of making money in U.S. markets are 50/50 over one-day periods, 68% in one-year periods, 88% in 10-year periods, and (so far) 100% in 20-year periods. Anything that keeps you in the game has a quantifiable advantage.

很少有财务变量比在低迷时期对策略的投入与业绩的关联性更强——既包括业绩的多少，也包括特定时期内获利的概率。历史上，在美国市场，单日盈利的概率为50%，一年期为68%，十年期为88%，而（迄今为止）二十年期为100%。任何能让你保持竞争力的因素都具有可量化的优势。

If you view “do what you love” as a guide to a happier life, it sounds like empty fortune cookie advice. If you view it as the thing providing the endurance necessary to put the quantifiable odds of success in your favor, you realize it should be the most important part of any financial strategy.

如果你把“做你喜欢的事”视为通往更幸福生活的指南，这听起来就像空洞的幸运饼干建议。如果你把它视为提供必要毅力、将可量化的成功概率转化为优势的动力，你就会意识到它应该是任何财务策略中最重要的部分。

Invest in a promising company you don’t care about, and you might enjoy it when everything’s going well. But when the tide inevitably turns you’re suddenly losing money on something you’re not interested in. It’s a double burden, and the path of least resistance is to move onto something else. If you’re passionate about the company to begin with—you love the mission, the product, the team, the science, whatever—the inevitable down times when you’re losing money or the company needs help are blunted by the fact that at least you feel like you’re part of something meaningful. That can be the necessary motivation that prevents you from giving up and moving on.

投资一家你并不关心的、前景光明的公司，或许在一切顺利的时候你会很开心。但当形势不可避免地逆转时，你却突然因为不感兴趣的事情而亏损。这无疑是双重负担，阻力最小的途径就是转向其他方向。如果你一开始就对这家公司充满热情——你热爱它的使命、产品、团队、科学等等——那么，即使公司不可避免的出现亏损或需要帮助，你至少会觉得自己参与了一件有意义的事情，这也能减轻你的痛苦。这可能是阻止你放弃并继续前进的必要动力。

There are several other times when it’s fine to be reasonable instead of rational with money.

还有很多时候，对待金钱采取合理态度而不是理性态度也是可以的。

There’s a well-documented “home bias,” where people prefer to invest in companies from the country they live in while ignoring the other 95%+ of the planet. It’s not rational, until you consider that investing is effectively giving money to strangers. If familiarity helps you take the leap of faith required to remain backing those strangers, it’s reasonable.

众所周知，存在一种“本土偏好”，即人们倾向于投资自己所在国家的公司，而忽略了地球上其他95%以上的国家。这种想法并不合理，除非你考虑到投资实际上就是在向陌生人送钱。如果熟悉能帮助你迈出继续支持这些陌生人的第一步，那么这种想法就合情合理。

Day trading and picking individual stocks is not rational for most investors—the odds are heavily against your success. But they’re both reasonable in small amounts if they scratch an itch hard enough to leave the rest of your more diversified investments alone. Investor Josh Brown, who advocates and mostly owns diversified funds, once explained why he also owns a smattering of individual stocks: “I’m not buying individual stocks because I think I’m going to generate alpha [outperformance]. I just love stocks and have ever since I was 20 years old. And it’s my money, I get to do whatever.” Quite reasonable.

对大多数投资者来说，日内交易和挑选个股并非理性之举——成功率极低。但如果它们能有效解决你的痛点，让你对其他更多元化的投资保持距离，那么少量投资还是合理的。倡导多元化基金且主要持有该基金的投资者乔希·布朗（Josh Brown）曾解释过自己为何也持有少量个股：“我买个股不是因为我觉得能获得超额收益（alpha，即超越预期）。我只是喜欢股票，从20岁起就一直如此。而且这是我的钱，我可以随心所欲。” 相当合理。

Most forecasts about where the economy and the stock market are heading next are terrible, but making forecasts is reasonable. It’s hard to wake up in the morning telling yourself you have no clue what the future holds, even if it’s true. Acting on investment forecasts is dangerous. But I get why people try to predict what will happen next year. It’s human nature. It’s reasonable.

大多数关于经济和股市未来走向的预测都很糟糕，但做出预测本身是合理的。早上醒来告诉自己对未来一无所知，即使预测是真的，也很难受。根据投资预测采取行动很危险。但我理解人们为什么试图预测明年会发生什么。这是人之常情，也是合理的。

Jack Bogle, the late founder of Vanguard, spent his career on a crusade to promote low-cost passive index investing. Many thought it interesting that his son found a career as an active, high-fee hedge fund and mutual fund manager. Bogle—the man who said high-fee funds violate “the humble rules of arithmetic”—invested some of his own money in his son’s funds. What’s the explanation?

已故先锋集团创始人杰克·博格（Jack Bogle）毕生致力于推广低成本被动指数投资。许多人觉得他的儿子从事主动型高收费对冲基金和共同基金经理的职业颇有意思。博格——那个声称高收费基金违反“卑微的算术规则”的人——将自己的部分资金投资于儿子的基金。这究竟是怎么回事呢？

“We do some things for family reasons,” Bogle told The Wall Street Journal. “If it’s not consistent, well, life isn’t always consistent.”³⁹

“我们做某些事情是出于家庭原因，”博格告诉《华尔街日报》。“如果不能始终如一，那么生活就不可能始终如一。”³⁹

Indeed, it rarely is.

事实上，这种情况很少发生。

#↩

#↩

Stanford professor Scott Sagan once said something everyone who follows the economy or investment markets should hang on their wall: “Things that have never happened before happen all the time.”

斯坦福大学教授斯科特·萨根 (Scott Sagan) 曾经说过一句话，每个关注经济或投资市场的人都应该把它挂在自家墙上：“从未发生过的事情总是会发生。”

History is mostly the study of surprising events. But it is often used by investors and economists as an unassailable guide to the future.

历史主要是对令人惊讶的事件的研究。但它常常被投资者和经济学家用作预测未来的可靠指南。

Do you see the irony?

你看出其中的讽刺意味了吗？

Do you see the problem?

你看到问题了吗？

It is smart to have a deep appreciation for economic and investing history. History helps us calibrate our expectations, study where people tend to go wrong, and offers a rough guide of what tends to work. But it is not, in any way, a map of the future.

深入了解经济和投资历史是明智之举。历史能帮助我们调整预期，研究人们容易犯的错误，并提供一些行之有效的粗略指南。但它绝不是未来的地图。

A trap many investors fall into is what I call “historians as prophets” fallacy: An overreliance on past data as a signal to future conditions in a field where innovation and change are the lifeblood of progress.

许多投资者陷入的一个陷阱就是我所说的“历史学家作为先知”谬误：在一个创新和变革是进步命脉的领域，过度依赖过去的数据作为未来状况的信号。

You can’t blame investors for doing this. If you view investing as a hard science, history should be a perfect guide to the future. Geologists can look at a billion years of historical data and form models of how the earth behaves. So can meteorologists. And doctors—kidneys operate the same way in 2020 as they did in 1020.

你不能责怪投资者这样做。如果你把投资视为一门硬科学，那么历史应该是指引未来的完美指南。地质学家可以研究十亿年的历史数据，并建立地球行为的模型。气象学家也可以。医生也是如此——2020年的肾脏运作方式与1020年的肾脏运作方式相同。

But investing is not a hard science. It’s a massive group of people making imperfect decisions with limited information about things that will have a massive impact on their wellbeing, which can make even smart people nervous, greedy and paranoid.

但投资并非一门深奥的科学。它是一群人基于有限的信息，做出不完美的决策，而这些信息将对他们的福祉产生重大影响，即使是聪明人也会因此变得紧张、贪婪和偏执。

Richard Feynman, the great physicist, once said, “Imagine how much harder physics would be if electrons had feelings.” Well, investors have feelings. Quite a few of them. That’s why it’s hard to predict what they’ll do next based solely on what they did in the past.

伟大的物理学家理查德·费曼曾经说过：“想象一下，如果电子有感情，物理学会变得多么困难。” 投资者是有感情的，而且相当多。这就是为什么我们很难仅根据他们过去的表现来预测他们下一步的行动。

The cornerstone of economics is that things change over time, because the invisible hand hates anything staying too good or too bad indefinitely. Investor Bill Bonner once described how Mr. Market works: “He’s got a ‘Capitalism at Work’ T-shirt on and a sledgehammer in his hand.” Few things stay the same for very long, which means we can’t treat historians as prophets.

经济学的基石是事物会随着时间而变化，因为“看不见的手”讨厌任何事物无限期地保持过好或过坏。投资者比尔·邦纳（Bill Bonner）曾这样描述“市场先生”的运作方式：“他穿着一件‘资本主义在运作’的T恤，手里拿着一把大锤。”很少有事物能长时间保持不变，这意味着我们不能把历史学家当作先知。

The most important driver of anything tied to money is the stories people tell themselves and the preferences they have for goods and services. Those things don’t tend to sit still. They change with culture and generation. They’re always changing and always will.

任何与金钱相关的事物，最重要的驱动力都在于人们讲述自己的故事，以及他们对商品和服务的偏好。这些东西往往不会一成不变。它们会随着文化和世代的更迭而改变。它们一直在变化，并且永远都会变化。

The mental trick we play on ourselves here is an over-admiration of people who have been there, done that, when it comes to money. Experiencing specific events does not necessarily qualify you to know what will happen next. In fact it rarely does, because experience leads to overconfidence more than forecasting ability.

我们玩弄的心理把戏，就是在金钱问题上过度崇拜那些有经验、有成就的人。经历过特定事件并不一定能让你预知接下来会发生什么。事实上，这种情况很少发生，因为经验更容易让人过度自信，而不是预测能力。

Investor Michael Batnick once explained this well. Confronted with the argument that few investors are prepared for rising interest rates because they’ve never experienced them—the last big period of rising interest rates occurred almost 40 years ago—he argued that it didn’t matter, because experiencing or even studying what happened in the past might not serve as any guide to what will happen when rates rise in the future:

投资者迈克尔·巴特尼克（Michael Batnick）曾对此做出过很好的解释。面对这样的观点：很少有投资者为利率上升做好准备，因为他们从未经历过——上一次利率大幅上升发生在近40年前——巴特尼克辩称，这无关紧要，因为经历甚至研究过去的情况，可能无法预示未来利率上升的情况：

So what? Will the current rate hike look like the last one, or the one before that? Will different asset classes behave similarly, the same, or the exact opposite?

那么，情况又如何？本次加息会像上次加息，还是像上一次加息？不同资产类别的表现会相似、相同，还是截然相反？

On the one hand, people that have been investing through the events of 1987, 2000 and 2008 have experienced a lot of different markets. On the other hand, isn’t it possible that this experience can lead to overconfidence? Failing to admit you’re wrong? Anchoring to previous outcomes?

一方面，经历过1987年、2000年和2008年事件的投资者经历了许多不同的市场。另一方面，这种经历是否可能导致过度自信？不愿承认错误？固守过往业绩？

Two dangerous things happen when you rely too heavily on investment history as a guide to what’s going to happen next.

当你过度依赖投资历史来预测下一步会发生什么时，就会发生两件危险的事情。

1. You’ll likely miss the outlier events that move the needle the most.

1. 您可能会错过最能影响事件的异常事件。

The most important events in historical data are the big outliers, the record-breaking events. They are what move the needle in the economy and the stock market. The Great Depression. World War II. The dot-com bubble. September 11th. The housing crash of the mid-2000s. A handful of outlier events play an enormous role because they influence so many unrelated events in their wake.

历史数据中最重要的事件是那些巨大的异常值，那些破纪录的事件。它们推动着经济和股市的走势。例如大萧条、第二次世界大战、互联网泡沫、9·11事件以及2000年代中期的房地产崩盘。少数异常事件发挥着巨大的作用，因为它们影响了其后许多不相关的事件。

Fifteen billion people were born in the 19th and 20th centuries. But try to imagine how different the global economy—and the whole world—would be today if just seven of them never existed:

19世纪和20世纪诞生了150亿人口。但试想一下，如果其中七个国家从未存在过，今天的全球经济——乃至整个世界——将会有多么不同：

Adolf Hitler

阿道夫·希特勒

Joseph Stalin

约瑟夫·斯大林

Mao Zedong

Mao Zedong

Gavrilo Princip

加夫里洛·普林西普

Thomas Edison

托马斯·爱迪生

Bill Gates

比尔·盖茨

Martin Luther King

马丁·路德·金

I’m not even sure that’s the most meaningful list. But almost everything about the world today—from borders to technology to social norms—would be different if these seven people hadn’t left their mark. Another way to put this is that 0.00000000004% of people were responsible for perhaps the majority of the world’s direction over the last century.

我甚至不确定这份名单是否最有意义。但如果这七个人没有留下自己的印记，当今世界的几乎所有事物——从边界到技术再到社会规范——都会有所不同。换句话说，在过去的一个世纪里，0.00004% 的人或许决定了世界的大部分方向。

The same goes for projects, innovations, and events. Imagine the last century without:

项目、创新和活动也是如此。想象一下上个世纪如果没有：

The Great Depression

大萧条

World War II

第二次世界大战

The Manhattan Project

曼哈顿计划

Vaccines

疫苗

Antibiotics

抗生素

ARPANET

阿帕网

September 11th

9月11日

The fall of the Soviet Union

苏联解体

How many projects and events occurred in the 20th century? Billions, trillions—who knows. But those eight alone impacted the world orders upon orders of magnitude more than others.

20世纪发生了多少项目和事件？数十亿，数万亿——谁知道呢。但仅这八个项目和事件就对世界秩序的影响就远超其他项目和事件。

The thing that makes tail events easy to underappreciate is how easy it is to underestimate how things compound. How, for example, 9/11 prompted the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates, which helped drive the housing bubble, which led to the financial crisis, which led to a poor jobs market, which led tens of millions to seek a college education, which led to $1.6 trillion in student loans with a 10.8% default rate. It’s not intuitive to link 19 hijackers to the current weight of student loans, but that’s what happens in a world driven by a few outlier tail events.

尾部事件之所以容易被低估，是因为我们很容易低估事态的复合效应。例如，9·11事件促使美联储降息，进而助长了房地产泡沫，进而引发金融危机，进而导致就业市场低迷，迫使数千万人寻求大学教育，最终导致学生贷款总额高达1.6万亿美元，违约率高达10.8%。将19名劫机者与当前的学生贷款负担联系起来并不直观，但在一个由一些异常尾部事件驱动的世界里，情况就是这样的。

The majority of what’s happening at any given moment in the global economy can be tied back to a handful of past events that were nearly impossible to predict.

全球经济中任何特定时刻发生的大部分事情都可以追溯到过去发生的一些几乎无法预测的事件。

The most common plot of economic history is the role of surprises. The reason surprises occur is not because our models are wrong or our intelligence is low. It’s because the odds that Adolf Hitler’s parents argued on the evening nine months before he was born were the same as them conceiving a child. Technology is hard to predict because Bill Gates may have died from polio if Jonas Salk got cranky and gave up on his quest to find a vaccine. The reason we couldn’t predict the student loan growth is because an airport security guard may have confiscated a hijacker’s knife on 9/11. That’s all there is to it.

经济史中最常见的情节就是意外。意外发生的原因并非我们的模型错误或智力低下，而是因为阿道夫·希特勒父母在他出生前九个月晚上吵架的概率与他们怀孕的概率相同。科技发展难以预测，因为如果乔纳斯·索尔克暴躁起来并放弃研发疫苗，比尔·盖茨可能就会死于脊髓灰质炎。我们无法预测学生贷款增长的原因，是因为机场保安可能在9/11事件中没收了劫机者的刀。仅此而已。

The problem is that we often use events like the Great Depression and World War II to guide our views of things like worst-case scenarios when thinking about future investment returns. But those record-setting events had no precedent when they occurred. So the forecaster who assumes the worst (and best) events of the past will match the worst (and best) events of the future is not following history; they’re accidentally assuming that the history of unprecedented events doesn’t apply to the future.

问题在于，在思考未来投资回报时，我们常常会用大萧条和二战之类的事件来指导我们对最坏情况的看法。但这些创纪录的事件在发生时并没有先例。因此，那些假设过去最坏（和最好）事件与未来最坏（和最好）事件相符的预测者，并非遵循历史；他们只是无意地假设了历史上前所未有的事件并不适用于未来。

Nassim Taleb writes in his book Fooled By Randomness:

纳西姆·塔勒布在他的书《随机致富的傻瓜》中写道：

In Pharaonic Egypt … scribes tracked the high-water mark of the Nile and used it as an estimate for a future worst-case scenario. The same can be seen in the Fukushima nuclear reactor, which experienced a catastrophic failure in 2011 when a tsunami struck. It had been built to withstand the worst past historical earthquake, with the builders not imagining much worse—and not thinking that the worst past event had to be a surprise, as it had no precedent.

在法老时代的埃及……抄写员追踪尼罗河的最高水位线，并以此作为对未来最坏情况的预估。福岛核反应堆也体现了同样的规律，它在2011年海啸袭击时发生了灾难性的故障。这座核反应堆的建造目标是抵御历史上最严重的地震，建造者们并没有想象到更糟糕的情况——也没有想到过去最糟糕的事件一定是意外，因为它是史无前例的。

This is not a failure of analysis. It’s a failure of imagination. Realizing the future might not look anything like the past is a special kind of skill that is not generally looked highly upon by the financial forecasting community.

这不是分析的失败，而是想象力的失败。意识到未来可能与过去截然不同是一种特殊的技能，但金融预测界通常并不看重这种技能。

At a 2017 dinner I attended in New York, Daniel Kahneman was asked how investors should respond when our forecasts are wrong. He said:

2017年，我在纽约参加了一场晚宴，有人问丹尼尔·卡尼曼，当我们的预测出错时，投资者应该如何应对。他说：

Whenever we are surprised by something, even if we admit that we made a mistake, we say, ‘Oh I’ll never make that mistake again.’ But, in fact, what you should learn when you make a mistake because you did not anticipate something is that the world is difficult to anticipate. That’s the correct lesson to learn from surprises: that the world is surprising.

每当我们被某事所震惊时，即使我们承认自己犯了错误，我们也会说：“哦，我再也不会犯同样的错误了。” 但事实上，当你因为没有预料到某事而犯错时，你应该学到的是，这个世界很难预料。这才是从意外中汲取的正确教训：世界总是充满惊喜。

The correct lesson to learn from surprises is that the world is surprising. Not that we should use past surprises as a guide to future boundaries; that we should use past surprises as an admission that we have no idea what might happen next.

从意外中汲取的正确教训是，世界总是充满意外。我们不应该以过去的意外为指引，去预测未来的边界；而应该以过去的意外为依据，承认我们根本不知道接下来会发生什么。

The most important economic events of the future—things that will move the needle the most—are things that history gives us little to no guide about. They will be unprecedented events. Their unprecedented nature means we won’t be prepared for them, which is part of what makes them so impactful. This is true for both scary events like recessions and wars, and great events like innovation.

未来最重要的经济事件——那些将带来最大影响的事件——是历史几乎无法提供任何参考的事件。它们将是前所未有的事件。它们的前所未有的性质意味着我们不会为它们做好准备，而这正是它们如此具有影响力的原因之一。无论是经济衰退和战争等令人恐惧的事件，还是创新等重大事件，都是如此。

I’m confident in that prediction because surprises moving the needle the most is the one forecast that’s been accurate at virtually every point in history.

我对这个预测很有信心，因为“最能影响形势的意外”这个预测在历史上几乎每个时刻都是准确的。

2. History can be a misleading guide to the future of the economy and stock market because it doesn’t account for structural changes that are relevant to today’s world.

2. 历史可能会误导人们对经济和股市未来的预测，因为它没有考虑到与当今世界相关的结构性变化。

Consider a few big ones.

考虑几个大的。

The 401(k) is 42 years old. The Roth IRA is younger, created in the 1990s. So personal financial advice and analysis about how Americans save for retirement today is not directly comparable to what made sense just a generation ago. We have new options. Things changed.

401(k) 已有 42 年历史。罗斯个人退休账户 (Roth IRA) 则更年轻，创建于 20 世纪 90 年代。因此，关于当今美国人如何为退休储蓄的个人理财建议和分析，与上一代人的做法已无法直接比较。我们有了新的选择。情况发生了变化。

Or take venture capital. It barely existed 25 years ago. There are single venture capital funds today that are larger than the entire industry was a generation ago.⁴⁰ In his memoir, Nike founder Phil Knight wrote about his early days in business:

或者以风险投资为例。25年前，它几乎不存在。如今，单个风险投资基金的规模就比上一代人整个行业的规模还要大。耐克创始人菲尔·奈特在回忆录中写道，他早年的商业生涯：

There was no such thing as venture capital. An aspiring young entrepreneur had very few places to turn, and those places were all guarded by risk-averse gatekeepers with zero imagination. In other words, bankers.

那时根本就不存在风险投资。一个胸怀抱负的年轻创业者几乎没有什么机会可以寻求帮助，而这些机会都被那些厌恶风险、缺乏想象力的守门人把守着。换句话说，就是银行家。

What this means, in effect, is that all historical data going back just a few decades about how startups are financed is out of date. What we know about investment cycles and startup failure rates is not a deep base of history to learn from, because the way companies are funded today is such a new historical paradigm.

这实际上意味着，所有关于初创企业融资方式的历史数据（哪怕只是几十年前）都已过时。我们对投资周期和初创企业失败率的了解，并没有深厚的历史基础可供借鉴，因为如今企业的融资方式已经是全新的历史范式。

Or take public markets. The S&P 500 did not include financial stocks until 1976; today, financials make up 16% of the index. Technology stocks were virtually nonexistent 50 years ago. Today, they’re more than a fifth of the index. Accounting rules have changed over time. So have disclosures, auditing, and the amount of market liquidity. Things changed.

或者以公开市场为例。标准普尔500指数直到1976年才纳入金融股；如今，金融股占该指数的16%。50年前，科技股几乎不存在。如今，它们占该指数的五分之一以上。会计规则随着时间的推移而变化。信息披露、审计和市场流动性也发生了变化。一切都变了。

The time between U.S. recessions has changed dramatically over the last 150 years:

过去 150 年来，美国经济衰退的间隔时间发生了巨大变化：

The average time between recessions has grown from about two years in the late 1800s to five years in the early 20th century to eight years over the last half-century.

经济衰退之间的平均间隔时间已从 19 世纪末的两年左右增加到 20 世纪初的五年，再增加到过去半个世纪的八年。

As I write this it looks like we’re going into recession—12 years since the last recession began in December 2007. That’s the longest gap between recessions since before the Civil War.

在我写这篇文章的时候，我们似乎正陷入经济衰退——自 2007 年 12 月上一次经济衰退开始以来已经过去了 12 年。这是自内战以来两次经济衰退之间间隔最长的一次。

There are plenty of theories on why recessions have become less frequent. One is that the Fed is better at managing the business cycle, or at least extending it. Another is that heavy industry is more prone to boom-and-bust overproduction than the service industries that dominated the last 50 years. The pessimistic view is that we now have fewer recessions, but when they occur they are more powerful than before. For our argument it doesn’t particularly matter what caused the change. What matters is that things clearly changed.

关于经济衰退为何减少，有很多理论。一种理论认为，美联储更擅长管理商业周期，或者至少延长了周期。另一种理论认为，与过去50年占主导地位的服务业相比，重工业更容易出现繁荣与萧条交替出现的生产过剩。悲观的观点认为，我们现在的经济衰退次数减少了，但一旦发生，其威力却比以往更大。对于我们的观点而言，导致这种变化的原因并不特别重要。重要的是，情况显然发生了变化。

To show how these historic changes should affect investing decisions, consider the work of a man many believe to be one of the greatest investment minds of all time: Benjamin Graham.

为了说明这些历史性变化将如何影响投资决策，我们来看一下本杰明·格雷厄姆 (Benjamin Graham) 的作品，他被许多人认为是有史以来最伟大的投资头脑之一。

Graham’s classic book, The Intelligent Investor, is more than theory. It gives practical directions like formulas investors can use to make smart investing decisions.

格雷厄姆的经典著作《聪明的投资者》不仅仅是理论，它还提供了实用的指导，例如投资者可以用来做出明智投资决策的公式。

I read Graham’s book when I was a teenager, learning about investing for the first time. The formulas presented in the book were appealing to me, because they were literally step-by-step instructions on how to get rich. Just follow the instructions. It seemed so easy.

我十几岁的时候读了格雷厄姆的书，第一次接触投资。书中提出的公式很吸引我，因为它们实际上是一步一步教你如何致富。只要按照说明去做就行了。看起来很容易。

But something becomes clear when you try applying some of these formulas: few of them actually work.

但是当你尝试应用其中一些公式时，就会发现有些东西确实有效：它们中很少有真正起作用的。

Graham advocated purchasing stocks trading for less than their net working assets—basically cash in the bank minus all debts. This sounds great, but few stocks actually trade that cheaply anymore—other than, say, a penny stock accused of accounting fraud.

格雷厄姆主张购买交易价格低于其净运营资产（基本上是银行现金减去所有债务）的股票。这听起来很棒，但实际上很少有股票的交易价格如此便宜——除非是被指控会计欺诈的低价股。

One of Graham’s criteria instructs conservative investors to avoid stocks trading for more than 1.5 times book value. If you followed this rule over the last decade you would have owned almost nothing but insurance and bank stocks. There is no world where that is OK.

格雷厄姆的标准之一是建议保守型投资者避免购买市净率超过1.5倍的股票。如果你在过去十年里遵循这条规则，你几乎就只持有保险和银行股了。在任何情况下，这种做法都是不可接受的。

The Intelligent Investor is one of the greatest investing books of all time. But I don’t know a single investor who has done well implementing Graham’s published formulas. The book is full of wisdom—perhaps more than any other investment book ever published. But as a how-to guide, it’s questionable at best.

《聪明的投资者》是有史以来最伟大的投资书籍之一。但我认识的投资者中，没有一个能很好地运用格雷厄姆发表的公式。这本书充满了智慧——或许比迄今为止出版的任何投资书籍都更甚。但作为一本操作指南，它充其量也值得怀疑。

What happened? Was Graham a showman who sounded good but whose advice didn’t work? Not at all. He was a wildly successful investor himself.

发生了什么？格雷厄姆是不是个爱表演的人，他的建议听起来不错，但最终却行不通？根本不是。他本人就是一位非常成功的投资者。

But he was practical. And he was a true contrarian. He wasn’t so wedded to investing ideas that he’d stick with them when too many other investors caught onto those theories, making them so popular as to render their potential useless. Jason Zweig—who annotated a later version of Graham’s book—once wrote:

但他很务实，而且是一位真正的逆向投资者。他不会执着于某个投资理念，以至于当太多其他投资者追随这些理论，使它们变得如此流行，以至于其潜力变得毫无用处时，他仍然坚持这些投资理念。杰森·茨威格（Jason Zweig）——他为格雷厄姆的这本书的后期版本做了注释——曾写道：

Graham was constantly experimenting and retesting his assumptions and seeking out what works—not what worked yesterday but what works today. In each revised edition of The Intelligent Investor, Graham discarded the formulas he presented in the previous edition and replaced them with new ones, declaring, in a sense, that “those do not work anymore, or they do not work as well as they used to; these are the formulas that seem to work better now.”

格雷厄姆不断地试验和重新检验他的假设，寻找行之有效的方法——不是昨天有效的方法，而是今天有效的方法。在《聪明的投资者》的每一版修订中，格雷厄姆都会摒弃前版中提出的公式，并用新的公式取而代之，在某种意义上宣称“那些公式不再有效，或者不像以前那么有效了；这些公式现在似乎更有效了。”

One of the common criticisms made of Graham is that all the formulas in the 1972 edition are antiquated. The only proper response to this criticism is to say: “Of course they are! They are the ones he used to replace the formulas in the 1965 edition, which replaced the formulas in the 1954 edition, which, in turn, replaced the ones from the 1949 edition, which were used to augment the original formulas that he presented in Security Analysis in 1934.”

对格雷厄姆最常见的批评之一是，1972年版中的所有公式都过时了。对此批评唯一恰当的回应是：“当然过时了！他用这些公式取代了1965年版中的公式，而1965年版中的公式又取代了1954年版中的公式，1954年版中的公式又取代了1949年版中的公式，而1949年版中的公式则用来补充他在1934年《证券分析》中提出的原始公式。”

Graham died in 1976. If the formulas he advocated were discarded and updated five times between 1934 and 1972, how relevant do you think they are in 2020? Or will be in 2050?

格雷厄姆于1976年去世。如果他所倡导的公式在1934年至1972年间被抛弃并更新了五次，你认为这些公式在2020年还有多大意义？或者在2050年还会有吗？

Just before he died Graham was asked whether detailed analysis of individual stocks—a tactic he became famous for—remained a strategy he favored. He answered:

格雷厄姆去世前，有人问他，对个股进行细致分析——他赖以成名的策略——是否仍然是他所推崇的策略。他回答道：

In general, no. I am no longer an advocate of elaborate techniques of security analysis in order to find superior value opportunities. This was a rewarding activity, say, 40 years ago, when our textbook was first published. But the situation has changed a great deal since then.⁴¹

总的来说，不是。我不再提倡为了寻找更佳价值机会而使用复杂的证券分析技巧。比如说，40年前，当我们的教科书首次出版时，这曾是一项有益的活动。但自那时起，情况发生了很大变化。⁴¹

What changed was: Competition grew as opportunities became well known; technology made information more accessible; and industries changed as the economy shifted from industrial to technology sectors, which have different business cycles and capital uses.

变化的是：随着机遇逐渐为人所知，竞争也随之加剧；技术使信息更加容易获取；随着经济从工业领域转向技术领域，行业也发生了变化，而技术领域有着不同的商业周期和资本用途。

Things changed.

事情发生了变化。

An interesting quirk of investing history is that the further back you look, the more likely you are to be examining a world that no longer applies to today. Many investors and economists take comfort in knowing their forecasts are backed up by decades, even centuries, of data. But since economies evolve, recent history is often the best guide to the future, because it’s more likely to include important conditions that are relevant to the future.

投资历史的一个有趣之处在于，你回顾得越久远，就越有可能审视一个已不再适用于当今的世界。许多投资者和经济学家欣慰地知道，他们的预测有数十年甚至数百年的数据作为支撑。但由于经济在不断发展，近期历史往往是预测未来的最佳指南，因为它更有可能包含与未来相关的重要条件。

There’s a common phrase in investing, usually used mockingly, that “It’s different this time.” If you need to rebut someone who’s predicting the future won’t perfectly mirror the past, say, “Oh, so you think it’s different this time?” and drop the mic. It comes from investor John Templeton’s view that “The four most dangerous words in investing are, ‘it’s different this time.’”

投资界有句常用语，通常用来调侃：“这次不一样了”。如果你需要反驳那些预测未来不会完全复制过去的人，就说：“哦，所以你认为这次不一样了？”然后放下麦克风。这句话出自投资者约翰·邓普顿的观点：“投资中最危险的四个字就是‘这次不一样了’。”

Templeton, though, admitted that it is different at least 20% of the time. The world changes. Of course it does. And those changes are what matter most over time. Michael Batnick put it: “The twelve most dangerous words in investing are, ‘The four most dangerous words in investing are, ‘it’s different this time.’”

然而，邓普顿承认，至少有20%的时间情况会有所不同。世界在变化，这当然会发生。而这些变化才是随着时间的推移最重要的。迈克尔·巴特尼克说：“投资中最危险的十二个词是‘这次不一样了’。”

That doesn’t mean we should ignore history when thinking about money. But there’s an important nuance: The further back in history you look, the more general your takeaways should be. General things like people’s relationship to greed and fear, how they behave under stress, and how they respond to incentives tend to be stable in time. The history of money is useful for that kind of stuff.

这并不意味着我们在思考金钱时应该忽略历史。但有一个重要的细微差别：你回顾的历史越久远，你的结论就应该越具有普遍性。诸如人们与贪婪和恐惧的关系、他们在压力下的行为以及他们对激励的反应等一般性因素往往会随着时间的推移而保持稳定。货币的历史对于这类事情很有用。

But specific trends, specific trades, specific sectors, specific causal relationships about markets, and what people should do with their money are always an example of evolution in progress. Historians are not prophets.

但特定的趋势、特定的交易、特定的行业、市场中特定的因果关系，以及人们应该如何运用自己的资金，始终都是进化过程的体现。历史学家并非先知。

The question, then, is how should we think about and plan for the future? Let’s take a look in the next chapter.

那么，我们应该如何思考和规划未来？让我们在下一章探讨。

#↩

#↩

Some of the best examples of smart financial behavior can be found in an unlikely place: Las Vegas casinos.

一些最明智的金融行为的例子可以在一个意想不到的地方找到：拉斯维加斯赌场。

Not among all players, of course. But a tiny group of blackjack players who practice card counting can teach ordinary people something extraordinarily important about managing money: the importance of room for error.

当然，并非所有玩家都如此。但一小部分练习算牌的二十一点玩家可以教会普通人一些关于理财的极其重要的事情：容错空间的重要性。

The fundamentals of blackjack card counting are simple:

二十一点算牌的基本原理很简单：

No one can know with certainty what card the dealer will draw next.

没有人能够确切地知道发牌者下一张牌会抽出什么牌。

But by tracking what cards have already been dealt you can calculate what cards remain in the deck.

但是通过追踪已经发出的牌，您可以计算出牌堆中还剩下哪些牌。

Doing so can tell you the odds of a particular card being drawn by the dealer.

这样做可以告诉你发牌人抽出某张牌的几率。

As a player, you bet more when the odds of getting a card you want are in your favor and less when they are against you.

作为一名玩家，当获得您想要的牌的几率对您有利时，您会下更大的赌注，而当获得您想要的牌的几率对您不利时，您会下更少的赌注。

The mechanics of how this is done don’t matter here. What matters is that a blackjack card counter knows they are playing a game of odds, not certainties. In any particular hand they think they have a good chance of being right, but know there’s a decent chance they’re wrong. It might sound strange given their profession, but their strategy relies entirely on humility—humility that they don’t know, and cannot know exactly what’s going to happen next, so play their hand accordingly. The card counting system works because it tilts the odds ever so slightly from the house to the player. But bet too heavily even when the odds seem in your favor and, if you’re wrong, you might lose so much that you don’t have enough money to keep playing.

在这里，实现这一过程的机制并不重要。重要的是，玩二十一点的算牌者知道他们玩的是概率游戏，而不是确定性游戏。在任何一手牌中，他们都认为自己很有可能猜对，但也知道自己错的可能性也很大。考虑到他们的职业，这听起来可能很奇怪，但他们的策略完全依赖于谦逊——谦逊是因为他们不知道，也无法确切知道接下来会发生什么，所以他们会相应地出牌。算牌系统之所以有效，是因为它会让赔率从庄家稍微倾斜到玩家。但是，即使赔率对你有利，也不要下注过大，如果你错了，你可能会损失惨重，以至于没有足够的钱继续玩下去。

There is never a moment when you’re so right that you can bet every chip in front of you. The world isn’t that kind to anyone—not consistently, anyways. You have to give yourself room for error. You have to plan on your plan not going according to plan.

你永远不会有那么一刻，完全正确到可以把面前的所有筹码都押上。这个世界对任何人都不会那么友善——至少不会一直如此。你必须给自己留出犯错的空间。你必须为你的计划做好准备，而不是按照计划进行。

Kevin Lewis, a successful card counter portrayed in the book Bringing Down the House, wrote more about this philosophy:

凯文·刘易斯 (Kevin Lewis) 是《Bringing Down the House》一书中描述的一位成功的算牌者，他对这一哲学进行了更详细的阐述：

Although card counting is statistically proven to work, it does not guarantee you will win every hand—let alone every trip you make to the casino. We must make sure that we have enough money to withstand any swings of bad luck.

虽然统计学证明算牌有效，但它并不能保证你每手牌都赢，更不用说每次去赌场都能赢了。我们必须确保自己有足够的钱来抵御任何厄运。

Let’s assume you have roughly a 2 percent edge over the casino. That still means the casino will win 49 percent of the time. Therefore, you need to have enough money to withstand any variant swings against you. A rule of thumb is that you should have at least a hundred basic units. Assuming you start with ten thousand dollars, you could comfortably play a hundred-dollar unit.

假设你比赌场大约有2%的优势。但这仍然意味着赌场赢的概率是49%。因此，你需要有足够的资金来应对任何不利于你的波动。一个经验法则是，你应该至少拥有100个基本单位。假设你以1万美元起步，那么你可以轻松地玩100美元的单位。

History is littered with good ideas taken too far, which are indistinguishable from bad ideas. The wisdom in having room for error is acknowledging that uncertainty, randomness, and chance—“unknowns”—are an ever-present part of life. The only way to deal with them is by increasing the gap between what you think will happen and what can happen while still leaving you capable of fighting another day.

历史上充斥着好主意被过度运用的例子，这些好主意与坏主意并无二致。留有容错空间的智慧在于承认不确定性、随机性和偶然性——“未知”——是生活中始终存在的一部分。应对它们的唯一方法是，在仍然拥有战斗力的情况下，扩大你认为会发生的事情与可能发生的事情之间的差距。

Benjamin Graham is known for his concept of margin of safety. He wrote about it extensively and in mathematical detail. But my favorite summary of the theory came when he mentioned in an interview that “the purpose of the margin of safety is to render the forecast unnecessary.”

本杰明·格雷厄姆以其“安全边际”的概念而闻名。他对此进行了广泛而详尽的数学阐述。但我最喜欢的是他在一次采访中提到的“安全边际的目的是让预测变得不必要”。

It’s hard to overstate how much power lies in that simple statement.

无论怎样强调这句简单的话语的力量都是不为过的。

Margin of safety—you can also call it room for error or redundancy—is the only effective way to safely navigate a world that is governed by odds, not certainties. And almost everything related to money exists in that kind of world.

安全边际——也可以称之为容错空间或冗余空间——是在这个由概率而非确定性主宰的世界里安全航行的唯一有效途径。几乎所有与金钱相关的事物都存在于这样的世界里。

Forecasting with precision is hard. This is obvious to the card counter, because no one could possibly know where a particular card lies in a shuffled deck. It’s less obvious to someone asking, “What will the average annual return of the stock market be over the next 10 years?” or “On what date will I be able to retire?” But they are fundamentally the same. The best we can do is think about odds.

精准预测并非易事。对于算牌者来说，这一点显而易见，因为没人能知道洗好的牌堆里哪张牌是真的。但对于那些问“未来10年股市年均回报率是多少？”或“我什么时候能退休？”的人来说，预测结果可能就没那么明显了。但本质上，它们是一样的。我们能做的最好的事情就是思考概率。

Graham’s margin of safety is a simple suggestion that we don’t need to view the world in front of us as black or white, predictable or a crapshoot. The grey area—pursuing things where a range of potential outcomes are acceptable—is the smart way to proceed.

格雷厄姆的安全边际理论简单明了地告诉我们，我们无需将眼前的世界视为非黑即白、可预测或充满不确定性的事物。灰色地带——追求一系列可接受的潜在结果——才是明智的行事之道。

But people underestimate the need for room for error in almost everything they do that involves money. Stock analysts give their clients price targets, not price ranges. Economic forecasters predict things with precise figures; rarely broad probabilities. The pundit who speaks in unshakable certainties will gain a larger following than the one who says “We can’t know for sure,” and speaks in probabilities.⁴²

但人们几乎在所有涉及金钱的事情中都低估了容错空间的必要性。股票分析师给客户的是目标价，而不是价格区间。经济预测者用精确的数字来预测，很少使用大致的概率。那些用不可动摇的确定性说话的专家，会比那些说“我们无法确定”、只说概率的专家获得更大的追随者。⁴²

We do this in all kinds of financial endeavors, especially those related to our own decisions. Harvard psychologist Max Bazerman once showed that when analyzing other people’s home renovation plans, most people estimate the project will run between 25% and 50% over budget.⁴³ But when it comes to their own projects, people estimate that renovations will be completed on time and at budget. Oh, the eventual disappointment.

我们在各种财务活动中都会这样做，尤其是那些与我们自己做决定相关的活动。哈佛大学心理学家马克斯·巴泽曼曾经指出，在分析别人的房屋装修计划时，大多数人估计项目会超出预算 25% 到 50%。⁴³ 但当涉及到自己的项目时，人们估计装修会按时按预算完成。唉，最终的失望。

Two things cause us to avoid room for error. One is the idea that somebody must know what the future holds, driven by the uncomfortable feeling that comes from admitting the opposite. The second is that you’re therefore doing yourself harm by not taking actions that fully exploit an accurate view of that future coming true.

有两件事会让我们回避犯错的空间。其一，认为一定有人知道未来会发生什么，这种想法源于承认事实与事实相反所带来的不适感。其二，如果你不采取行动，充分利用对未来成真的准确预期，那么你就会对自己造成伤害。

But room for error is underappreciated and misunderstood. It’s often viewed as a conservative hedge, used by those who don’t want to take much risk or aren’t confident in their views. But when used appropriately, it’s quite the opposite.

然而，容错空间却被低估和误解了。它常常被视为一种保守的对冲策略，被那些不愿承担太大风险或对自己的观点缺乏信心的人所使用。但如果运用得当，它的作用恰恰相反。

Room for error lets you endure a range of potential outcomes, and endurance lets you stick around long enough to let the odds of benefiting from a low-probability outcome fall in your favor. The biggest gains occur infrequently, either because they don’t happen often or because they take time to compound. So the person with enough room for error in part of their strategy (cash) to let them endure hardship in another (stocks) has an edge over the person who gets wiped out, game over, insert more tokens, when they’re wrong.

容错空间让你能够承受各种可能的结果，而忍耐力让你能够坚持足够长的时间，让低概率结果的收益对你有利。最大的收益并不常见，要么是因为它们不常见，要么是因为它们需要时间才能复利。因此，在策略（现金）中拥有足够容错空间，能够承受另一策略（股票）中遭遇困境的人，比那些在犯错时惨败、游戏结束、投入更多代币的人更有优势。

Bill Gates understood this well. When Microsoft was a young company, he said he “came up with this incredibly conservative approach that I wanted to have enough money in the bank to pay a year’s worth of payroll even if we didn’t get any payments coming in.” Warren Buffett expressed a similar idea when he told Berkshire Hathaway shareholders in 2008: “I have pledged—to you, the rating agencies and myself—to always run Berkshire with more than ample cash ... When forced to choose, I will not trade even a night’s sleep for the chance of extra profits.”⁴⁴

比尔·盖茨深谙此道。微软成立之初，他曾表示“我制定了极其保守的策略，即使我们没有任何收入，我也希望银行账户里有足够的钱来支付一年的工资”。沃伦·巴菲特在2008年对伯克希尔·哈撒韦公司股东发表讲话时也表达了类似的想法：“我向你们、评级机构以及我自己承诺，我将始终以充足的现金来运营伯克希尔……如果被迫做出选择，我甚至不会为了额外盈利的机会而牺牲哪怕一晚的安眠。”⁴⁴

There are a few specific places for investors to think about room for error.

有几个特定的地方需要投资者考虑容错空间。

One is volatility. Can you survive your assets declining by 30%? On a spreadsheet, maybe yes—in terms of actually paying your bills and staying cash-flow positive. But what about mentally? It is easy to underestimate what a 30% decline does to your psyche. Your confidence may become shot at the very moment opportunity is at its highest. You—or your spouse—may decide it’s time for a new plan, or new career. I know several investors who quit after losses because they were exhausted. Physically exhausted. Spreadsheets are good at telling you when the numbers do or don’t add up. They’re not good at modeling how you’ll feel when you tuck your kids in at night wondering if the investment decisions you’ve made were a mistake that will hurt their future. Having a gap between what you can technically endure versus what’s emotionally possible is an overlooked version of room for error.

一是波动性。你的资产减少 30% 你能承受吗？在电子表格上，也许可以——就实际支付账单和保持现金流为正而言。但精神上呢？人们很容易低估 30% 的下降对你心理的影响。在机会最高的时刻，你的信心可能会受到打击。你——或者你的配偶——可能会决定是时候制定新计划或开始新职业了。我认识几个投资者在亏损后退出，因为他们筋疲力尽。身体上的疲惫。电子表格擅长告诉你数字什么时候对了，什么时候不对了。但它们不擅长模拟当你晚上给孩子掖好被子时你会有何感受，你会想你所做的投资决定是否是一个会损害他们未来的错误。技术上可以承受的和情感上可能承受的之间的差距是一种被忽视的容错空间。

Another is saving for retirement. We can look at history and see, for example, that the U.S. stock market has returned an annual average of 6.8% after inflation since the 1870s. It’s a reasonable first approximation to use that as an estimate of what to expect on your own diversified portfolio when saving for retirement. You can use those return assumptions to back into the amount of money you’ll need to save each month to achieve your target nestegg.

另一个是退休储蓄。我们可以回顾历史，例如，自19世纪70年代以来，美国股市扣除通货膨胀因素后的年均回报率为6.8%。用这个数字来估算你的多元化投资组合在退休储蓄时的预期收益是一个合理的初步估计。你可以利用这些回报假设来推算出你每月需要储蓄多少才能达到目标储蓄目标。

But what if future returns are lower? Or what if long-term history is a good estimate of the long-term future, but your target retirement date ends up falling in the middle of a brutal bear market, like 2009? What if a future bear market scares you out of stocks and you end up missing a future bull market, so the returns you actually earn are less than the market average? What if you need to cash out your retirement accounts in your 30s to pay for a medical mishap?

但如果未来回报率较低呢？或者，如果长期历史数据能够准确预测长期未来，但你的目标退休日期恰逢残酷的熊市，例如2009年，那该怎么办？如果未来的熊市吓得你抛售股票，而你最终错过了未来的牛市，最终实际获得的回报低于市场平均水平，那该怎么办？如果你在30多岁时需要提取退休账户资金来支付医疗费用，那该怎么办？

The answer to those what ifs is, “You won’t be able to retire like you once predicted.” Which can be a disaster.

这些“如果”的答案是：“你将无法像你曾经预测的那样退休。”这可能是一场灾难。

The solution is simple: Use room for error when estimating your future returns. This is more art than science. For my own investments, which I’ll describe more in chapter 20, I assume the future returns I’ll earn in my lifetime will be ⅓ lower than the historic average. So I save more than I would if I assumed the future will resemble the past. It’s my margin of safety. The future may be worse than ⅓ lower than the past, but no margin of safety offers a 100% guarantee. A one-third buffer is enough to allow me to sleep well at night. And if the future does resemble the past, I’ll be pleasantly surprised. “The best way to achieve felicity is to aim low,” says Charlie Munger. Wonderful.

解决方案很简单：在估算未来回报时，要留出容错空间。这与其说是科学，不如说是艺术。就我自己的投资而言（我将在第20章详细描述），我假设我一生中未来的回报将比历史平均水平低三分之一。因此，如果我假设未来与过去相似，我会比实际储蓄更多。这就是我的安全边际。未来可能比过去低三分之一还要糟糕，但没有哪个安全边际能保证100%的收益。三分之一的缓冲空间足以让我晚上睡个好觉。如果未来真的与过去相似，我会感到惊喜。“获得幸福的最好方法是把目标定得低一些，”查理·芒格说。真是太棒了。

An important cousin of room for error is what I call optimism bias in risk-taking, or “Russian roulette should statistically work” syndrome: An attachment to favorable odds when the downside is unacceptable in any circumstances.

容错空间的一个重要表亲是我所说的冒险中的乐观偏见，或“俄罗斯轮盘赌在统计上应该有效”综合症：当在任何情况下不利因素都是不可接受的时，仍执着于有利的赔率。

Nassim Taleb says, “You can be risk loving and yet completely averse to ruin.” And indeed, you should.

纳西姆·塔勒布 (Nassim Taleb) 说过：“你可以热爱风险，但又完全厌恶毁灭。” 事实上，你应该这样做。

The idea is that you have to take risk to get ahead, but no risk that can wipe you out is ever worth taking. The odds are in your favor when playing Russian roulette. But the downside is not worth the potential upside. There is no margin of safety that can compensate for the risk.

其理念是，你必须承担风险才能取得成功，但任何可能让你倾家荡产的风险都不值得冒。玩俄罗斯轮盘赌时，胜算对你有利。但风险带来的负面影响远不及潜在的收益。没有任何安全边际能够弥补风险。

Same with money. The odds of many lucrative things are in your favor. Real estate prices go up most years, and during most years you’ll get a paycheck every other week. But if something has 95% odds of being right, the 5% odds of being wrong means you will almost certainly experience the downside at some point in your life. And if the cost of the downside is ruin, the upside the other 95% of the time likely isn’t worth the risk, no matter how appealing it looks.

金钱也是如此。很多赚钱机会的概率对你有利。房地产价格大多数年份都会上涨，而且大多数年份你每隔一周就能拿到一笔薪水。但如果某件事有95%的概率是正确的，那么5%的概率是错误的，这意味着你几乎肯定会在人生的某个时刻遭遇失败。如果失败的代价是毁灭，那么剩下的95%的时间里，无论它看起来多么诱人，成功的可能性可能都不值得你冒险。

Leverage is the devil here. Leverage—taking on debt to make your money go further—pushes routine risks into something capable of producing ruin. The danger is that rational optimism most of the time masks the odds of ruin some of the time. The result is we systematically underestimate risk. Housing prices fell 30% last decade. A few companies defaulted on their debt. That’s capitalism. It happens. But those with high leverage had a double wipeout: Not only were they left broke, but being wiped out erased every opportunity to get back in the game at the very moment opportunity was ripe. A homeowner wiped out in 2009 had no chance of taking advantage of cheap mortgage rates in 2010. Lehman Brothers had no chance of investing in cheap debt in 2009. They were done.

杠杆在这里是魔鬼。杠杆——通过举债让资金跑得更远——会将常规风险推向可能造成毁灭的境地。危险在于，理性的乐观主义大多数时候会掩盖破产的可能性。结果就是我们系统性地低估了风险。过去十年，房价下跌了30%。一些公司拖欠了债务。这就是资本主义。这种情况会发生。但那些高杠杆的人却遭遇了双重打击：他们不仅破产了，而且在机会成熟的时候，他们失去了所有重返市场的机会。2009年破产的房主根本没有机会在2010年利用低利率抵押贷款。雷曼兄弟在2009年也没有机会投资廉价债务。他们完蛋了。

To get around this, I think of my own money as barbelled. I take risks with one portion and am terrified with the other. This is not inconsistent, but the psychology of money would lead you to believe that it is. I just want to ensure I can remain standing long enough for my risks to pay off. You have to survive to succeed. To repeat a point we’ve made a few times in this book: The ability to do what you want, when you want, for as long as you want, has an infinite ROI.

为了解决这个问题，我把自己的钱想象成杠铃状。一部分钱我承担风险，另一部分钱我却心存恐惧。这本身并不矛盾，但金钱心理学会让你相信它矛盾。我只是想确保自己能够坚持足够长的时间，直到我的风险获得回报。你必须生存下来才能成功。重申一下我们在本书中多次提到的观点：能够随时随地做自己想做的事情，拥有无限的投资回报率。

Room for error does more than just widen the target around what you think might happen. It also helps protect you from things you’d never imagine, which can be the most troublesome events we face.

容错空间不仅仅是扩大你认为可能发生的情况的范围，它还能帮助你避免那些你从未想象过的事情，而这些事情可能是我们面临的最棘手的事件。

The Battle of Stalingrad during World War II was the largest battle in history. With it came equally staggering stories of how people dealt with risk.

第二次世界大战期间的斯大林格勒战役是历史上规模最大的战役。这场战役也讲述了人们如何应对风险的惊人故事。

One came in late 1942, when a German tank unit sat in reserve on grasslands outside the city. When tanks were desperately needed on the front lines, something happened that surprised everyone: Almost none of them worked.

一次发生在1942年末，当时一支德国坦克部队在城外的草地上作为预备队驻扎。当时前线急需坦克，却发生了一件令所有人震惊的事情：几乎没有一辆坦克能够发挥作用。

Out of 104 tanks in the unit, fewer than 20 were operable. Engineers quickly found the issue. Historian William Craig writes: “During the weeks of inactivity behind the front lines, field mice had nested inside the vehicles and eaten away insulation covering the electrical systems.”

该部队104辆坦克中，只有不到20辆能够使用。工程师们很快就发现了问题所在。历史学家威廉·克雷格写道：“在前线后方停工的几周里，田鼠在坦克里筑巢，腐蚀了覆盖电气系统的绝缘层。”

The Germans had the most sophisticated equipment in the world. Yet there they were, defeated by mice.

德国人拥有世界上最先进的装备，但他们还是被老鼠打败了。

You can imagine their disbelief. This almost certainly never crossed their minds. What kind of tank designer thinks about mouse protection? Not a reasonable one. And not one who studied tank history.

你可以想象他们当时的难以置信。他们几乎肯定从来没想过这个问题。哪个坦克设计师会考虑防鼠？肯定不合理，而且肯定没研究过坦克历史。

But these kinds of things happen all the time. You can plan for every risk except the things that are too crazy to cross your mind. And those crazy things can do the most harm, because they happen more often than you think and you have no plan for how to deal with them.

但这类事情时有发生。你可以为所有风险做好计划，唯独那些你根本想不到的疯狂之事除外。而那些疯狂之事往往危害最大，因为它们发生的频率超乎你的想象，而且你根本无从应对。

In 2006 Warren Buffett announced a search for his eventual replacement. He said he needed someone “genetically programmed to recognize and avoid serious risks, including those never before encountered.”⁴⁵

2006年，沃伦·巴菲特宣布寻找他的最终继任者。他说，他需要一个“天生就能识别并规避重大风险，包括那些从未遇到过的风险”的人。⁴⁵

I have seen this skill at work with startups my firm, Collaborative Fund, has backed. Ask a founder to list the biggest risks they face, and the usual suspects are mentioned. But beyond the predictable struggles of running a startup, here are a few issues we’ve dealt with among our portfolio companies:

我在我的公司 Collaborative Fund 投资的初创公司中见证了这种技巧的运用。如果让创始人列出他们面临的最大风险，他们通常会提到一些常见的风险。但除了运营初创公司可能遇到的种种困难之外，以下是我们投资组合中遇到的一些问题：

Water pipes broke, flooding and ruining a company’s office.

水管破裂，导致水淹并毁坏了一家公司的办公室。

A company’s office was broken into three times.

一家公司的办公室被闯入三次。

A company was kicked out of its manufacturing plant.

一家公司被赶出了制造厂。

A store was shut down after a customer called the health department because she didn’t like that another customer brought a dog inside.

一名顾客打电话给卫生部门，因为她不喜欢另一位顾客带狗进店，于是这家商店被关闭了。

A CEO’s email was spoofed in the middle of a fundraise that required all of his attention.

一位首席执行官在筹集资金的过程中，他的电子邮箱被伪造了，他需要全神贯注地关注这件事。

A founder had a mental breakdown.

一位创始人精神崩溃了。

Several of these events were existential to the company’s future. But none were foreseeable, because none had previously happened to the CEOs dealing with these problems—or anyone else they knew, for that matter. It was unchartered territory.

这些事件中，有几件对公司的未来至关重要。但它们都无法预见，因为之前处理这些问题的CEO——或者说，他们认识的其他人——都没有遇到过类似的情况。这是一个未知的领域。

Avoiding these kinds of unknown risks is, almost by definition, impossible. You can’t prepare for what you can’t envision.

几乎可以肯定地说，避免这些未知的风险是不可能的。你无法为无法预见的事情做好准备。

If there’s one way to guard against their damage, it’s avoiding single points of failure.

如果有一种方法可以防止其造成损害，那就是避免单点故障。

A good rule of thumb for a lot of things in life is that everything that can break will eventually break. So if many things rely on one thing working, and that thing breaks, you are counting the days to catastrophe. That’s a single point of failure.

生活中很多事情都有一个经验法则：所有可能损坏的东西最终都会损坏。所以，如果很多事情都依赖于一个部件的运转，而这个部件坏了，你就是在数着日子等着灾难的到来。这就是单点故障。

Some people are remarkably good at avoiding single points of failure. Most critical systems on airplanes have backups, and the backups often have backups. Modern jets have four redundant electrical systems. You can fly with one engine and technically land with none, as every jet must be capable of stopping on a runway with its brakes alone, without thrust reverse from its engines. Suspension bridges can similarly lose many of their cables without falling.

有些人非常擅长避免单点故障。飞机上的大多数关键系统都有备份，而且备份系统通常还有备份。现代喷气式飞机拥有四个冗余电气系统。你可以用一个引擎飞行，但从技术上讲，即使没有引擎也能着陆，因为每架喷气式飞机都必须能够仅靠刹车在跑道上停下来，而无需引擎反推。同样，悬索桥即使失去许多缆绳也不会倒塌。

The biggest single point of failure with money is a sole reliance on a paycheck to fund short-term spending needs, with no savings to create a gap between what you think your expenses are and what they might be in the future.

财务方面最大的失败点是仅仅依靠薪水来满足短期支出需求，而没有储蓄来弥补您认为的支出和未来可能的支出之间的差距。

The trick that often goes overlooked—even by the wealthiest—is what we saw in chapter 10: realizing that you don’t need a specific reason to save. It’s fine to save for a car, or a home, or for retirement. But it’s equally important to save for things you can’t possibly predict or even comprehend—the financial equivalent of field mice.

即使是最富有的人也常常忽略的一个技巧，就是我们在第十章中看到的：意识到你不需要一个特定的理由来储蓄。为买车、买房或为退休储蓄是可以的。但同样重要的是，为你无法预测甚至无法理解的事情储蓄——就像财务上的田鼠一样。

Predicting what you’ll use your savings for assumes you live in a world where you know exactly what your future expenses will be, which no one does. I save a lot, and I have no idea what I’ll use the savings for in the future. Few financial plans that only prepare for known risks have enough margin of safety to survive the real world.

预测你的储蓄用途，假设你生活在一个能够准确了解未来支出的世界，而实际上没有人知道。我存了很多钱，但我不知道未来会怎么用。很少有只针对已知风险的财务计划，能够拥有足够的安全边际，在现实世界中生存下来。

In fact, the most important part of every plan is planning on your plan not going according to plan.

事实上，每个计划最重要的部分是计划如何进行，而不是按照计划进行。

Now, let me show you how this applies to you.

现在，让我向你展示一下这对你有何影响。

#↩

#↩

Igrew up with a friend who came from neither privilege nor natural intellect, but was the hardest-working guy I knew. These people have a lot to teach because they have an unfiltered understanding of every inch of the road to success.

我有一个朋友，他既没有优越的出身，也没有天赋异禀的才智，但却是我认识的最勤奋的人。这些人有很多值得我学习的地方，因为他们对通往成功之路的每一步都拥有透彻的理解。

His life’s mission and dream as a teenager was to be a doctor. To say the odds were stacked against him is being charitable. No reasonable person at the time would consider it a possibility.

他青少年时期的人生使命和梦想就是成为一名医生。说他当时的处境很艰难，这已经算是客气了。当时没有一个理性的人会认为这有可能。

But he pushed. And—a decade older than his classmates—he eventually became a doctor.

但他坚持不懈。最终，他成为了一名医生——比他的同学们大十岁。

How much fulfillment comes from starting from nothing, bulldozing your way to the top of medical school, and achieving one of the most noble professions against all odds?

从零开始，一路奋战到医学院的顶尖，克服重重困难，获得最崇高的职业之一，这能给你带来多大的成就感？

I spoke to him a few years ago. The conversation went like this:

几年前我和他聊过。对话如下：

Me: “Long time no talk! How you doi—”

我：“好久不见！你好吗——”

Him: “Awful career.”

他：“糟糕的职业生涯。”

Me: “Haha, well—”

我：“哈哈，好吧——”

Him: “Awful career, man.”

他：“这职业生涯太糟糕了，伙计。”

This went on for 10 minutes. The stress and hours had worn him into the ground. He seemed as disappointed in where he is today as he was driven toward where he wanted to be 15 years ago.

这种情况持续了10分钟。压力和时间的流逝让他精疲力竭。他似乎对如今的处境感到失望，就像15年前他朝着梦想的方向前进一样。

An underpinning of psychology is that people are poor forecasters of their future selves.

心理学的一个基本原理是，人们无法预测自己的未来。

Imagining a goal is easy and fun. Imagining a goal in the context of the realistic life stresses that grow with competitive pursuits is something entirely different.

设想一个目标很容易，也很有趣。但在现实生活压力不断增长、竞争加剧的背景下设想一个目标，则是完全不同的另一回事。

This has a big impact on our ability to plan for future financial goals.

这对我们规划未来财务目标的能力有很大影响。
