Every five-year-old boy wants to drive a tractor when they grow up. Few jobs look better in the eyes of a young boy whose idea of a good job begins and ends with “Vroom vroom, beep beep, big tractor, here I come!”

每个五岁的男孩都梦想长大后能开拖拉机。在小男孩眼里，很少有工作比拖拉机更好，因为他对好工作的理解就是“呜呜呜，嘟嘟，大拖拉机，我来了！”

Then many grow up and realize that driving a tractor maybe isn’t the best career. Maybe they want something more prestigious or lucrative.

后来，很多人长大后意识到，开拖拉机或许不是最好的职业。也许他们想要一些更有声望或更赚钱的工作。

So as a teenager they dream of being a lawyer. Now they think—they know—their plan is set. Law school and its costs, here we come.

所以，他们十几岁的时候就梦想成为一名律师。现在，他们认为——他们知道——他们的计划已经确定了。法学院及其费用，我们来了。

Then, as a lawyer, they face such long working hours that they rarely see their families.

然后，作为一名律师，他们面临着漫长的工作时间，以至于很少能见到家人。

So perhaps they take a lower-paying job with flexible hours. Then they realize that childcare is so expensive that it consumes most of their paycheck, and they opt to be a stay-at-home parent. This, they conclude, is finally the right choice.

所以，他们或许会选择一份薪水较低、工作时间灵活的工作。后来，他们意识到照顾孩子的费用太高，几乎占了他们工资的一半，于是决定做全职妈妈。最终，他们得出结论，这才是正确的选择。

Then, at age 70, they realize that a lifetime of staying home means they’re unprepared to afford retirement.

然后，到了 70 岁时，他们意识到一辈子呆在家里意味着他们还没有准备好退休。

Many of us wind through life on a similar trajectory. Only 27% of college grads have a job related to their major, according to the Federal Reserve.⁴⁶ Twenty-nine percent of stay-at-home parents have a college degree.⁴⁷ Few likely regret their education, of course. But we should acknowledge that a new parent in their 30s may think about life goals in a way their 18-year-old self making career goals would never imagine.

我们许多人的人生轨迹都大同小异。根据美联储的数据，只有27%的大学毕业生从事与专业相关的工作。⁴⁶ 29%的全职父母拥有大学学位。⁴⁷ 当然，很少有人会后悔自己的教育。但我们应该承认，30多岁的新手父母看待人生目标的方式，可能是他们18岁时自己设定的职业目标无法想象的。

Long-term financial planning is essential. But things change—both the world around you, and your own goals and desires. It is one thing to say, “We don’t know what the future holds.” It’s another to admit that you, yourself, don’t know today what you will even want in the future. And the truth is, few of us do. It’s hard to make enduring long-term decisions when your view of what you’ll want in the future is likely to shift.

长期财务规划至关重要。但世事变迁——你周围的世界，以及你自己的目标和愿望。说“我们不知道未来会怎样”是一回事，承认自己今天甚至不知道未来想要什么又是另一回事。事实上，我们中很少有人知道。当你对未来目标的看法可能随时改变时，很难做出持久的长期决策。

The End of History Illusion is what psychologists call the tendency for people to be keenly aware of how much they’ve changed in the past, but to underestimate how much their personalities, desires, and goals are likely to change in the future. Harvard psychologist Daniel Gilbert once said:

“历史终结论”错觉是心理学家们对这种倾向的描述：人们敏锐地意识到自己过去发生了多大的变化，却低估了自己性格、欲望和目标在未来可能发生的变化。哈佛大学心理学家丹尼尔·吉尔伯特曾说过：

At every stage of our lives we make decisions that will profoundly influence the lives of the people we’re going to become, and then when we become those people, we’re not always thrilled with the decisions we made. So young people pay good money to get tattoos removed that teenagers paid good money to get. Middle-aged people rushed to divorce people who young adults rushed to marry. Older adults work hard to lose what middle-aged adults worked hard to gain. On and on and on.⁴⁸

在我们人生的每个阶段，我们都会做出一些决定，这些决定将深刻地影响我们未来成为的人。而当我们成为那样的人时，我们并不总是对当初的决定感到满意。所以，年轻人会花大价钱去除青少年时期花大价钱纹的纹身。中年人会急着离婚，而年轻人则会急着结婚。老年人努力工作，却失去了中年人努力获得的东西。如此等等。⁴⁸

“All of us,” he said, “are walking around with an illusion—an illusion that history, our personal history, has just come to an end, that we have just recently become the people that we were always meant to be and will be for the rest of our lives.” We tend to never learn this lesson. Gilbert’s research shows people from age 18 to 68 underestimate how much they will change in the future.

他说：“我们所有人都怀着一种幻觉——一种幻觉，以为历史，我们个人的历史，刚刚结束，以为我们刚刚成为我们注定要成为的、并将在余生中一直保持的那种人。” 我们往往永远学不会这个道理。吉尔伯特的研究表明，18岁到68岁的人低估了自己未来会发生多大的变化。

You can see how this can impact a long-term financial plan. Charlie Munger says the first rule of compounding is to never interrupt it unnecessarily. But how do you not interrupt a money plan—careers, investments, spending, budgeting, whatever—when what you want out of life changes? It’s hard. Part of the reason people like Ronald Read—the wealthy janitor we met earlier in the book—and Warren Buffett become so successful is because they kept doing the same thing for decades on end, letting compounding run wild. But many of us evolve so much over a lifetime that we don’t want to keep doing the same thing for decades on end. Or anything close to it. So rather than one 80-something-year lifespan, our money has perhaps four distinct 20-year blocks.

你可以看到这会对长期财务计划产生怎样的影响。查理·芒格说，复利的第一条规则是永远不要无缘无故地打断它。但是当你对生活的期望发生变化时，你该如何不打断你的金钱计划——职业、投资、支出、预算等等？这很难。像罗纳德·里德（我们在本书前面遇到的富有的看门人）和沃伦·巴菲特这样的人之所以如此成功，部分原因是他们几十年来一直在做同样的事情，让复利肆意发展。但是我们中的许多人在一生中都发生了很大的变化，我们不想几十年来一直做同样的事情。或者任何接近它的事情。因此，我们的金钱寿命不是 80 多年，而是可能有四个不同的 20 年区块。

I know young people who purposefully live austere lives with little income, and they’re perfectly happy with it. Then there are those who work their tails off to pay for a life of luxury, and they’re perfectly happy with that. Both have risks—the former risks being unprepared to raise a family or fund retirement, the latter risks regret that you spent your youthful and healthy years in a cubicle.

我认识一些年轻人，他们刻意过着简朴的生活，收入微薄，但他们对此非常满意。还有一些人拼命工作，过着奢侈的生活，他们也对此非常满意。这两种情况都有风险——前者可能会让你没有能力养家糊口或为退休生活做好准备，而后者可能会让你后悔自己年轻健康的青春年华是在格子间里度过的。

There is no easy solution to this problem. Tell a five-year-old boy he should be a lawyer instead of a tractor driver and he will disagree with every cell in his body.

这个问题没有简单的解决办法。告诉一个五岁的小男孩，他应该当一名律师而不是拖拉机司机，他会全身心地反对。

But there are two things to keep in mind when making what you think are long-term decisions.

但是，当你做出长期决策时，有两件事需要牢记。

We should avoid the extreme ends of financial planning. Assuming you’ll be happy with a very low income, or choosing to work endless hours in pursuit of a high one, increases the odds that you’ll one day find yourself at a point of regret. The fuel of the End of History Illusion is that people adapt to most circumstances, so the benefits of an extreme plan—the simplicity of having hardly anything, or the thrill of having almost everything—wear off. But the downsides of those extremes—not being able to afford retirement, or looking back at a life spent devoted to chasing dollars—become enduring regrets. Regrets are especially painful when you abandon a previous plan and feel like you have to run in the other direction twice as fast to make up for lost time.

我们应该避免财务规划走极端。假设自己对很低的收入感到满意，或者选择无休止地工作以追求高收入，都会增加你有一天后悔的可能性。“历史终结论”幻觉的根源在于，人们会适应大多数情况，因此极端计划的好处——几乎一无所有时的轻松，或者几乎拥有一切时的刺激——会逐渐消失。但这些极端的弊端——无法负担退休生活，或者回首过去为追逐金钱而度过的一生——会成为挥之不去的遗憾。当你放弃之前的计划，感觉必须以两倍的速度转向另一个方向才能弥补失去的时间时，后悔会尤其痛苦。

Compounding works best when you can give a plan years or decades to grow. This is true for not only savings but careers and relationships. Endurance is key. And when you consider our tendency to change who we are over time, balance at every point in your life becomes a strategy to avoid future regret and encourage endurance.

当你能制定一个数年甚至数十年的增长计划时，复利策略的效果最佳。这不仅适用于储蓄，也适用于事业和人际关系。忍耐力至关重要。考虑到我们自身的倾向会随着时间推移而改变，平衡人生的每个阶段就成为一种避免未来后悔并鼓励忍耐力的策略。

Aiming, at every point in your working life, to have moderate annual savings, moderate free time, no more than a moderate commute, and at least moderate time with your family, increases the odds of being able to stick with a plan and avoid regret than if any one of those things fall to the extreme sides of the spectrum.

在你职业生涯的每一个阶段，都力争拥有适度的年度储蓄、适度的空闲时间、不超过适度的通勤时间以及至少适度的与家人相处的时间，与任何一项都落入极端情况相比，这会增加坚持计划并避免后悔的可能性。

We should also come to accept the reality of changing our minds. Some of the most miserable workers I’ve met are people who stay loyal to a career only because it’s the field they picked when deciding on a college major at age 18. When you accept the End of History Illusion, you realize that the odds of picking a job when you’re not old enough to drink that you will still enjoy when you’re old enough to qualify for Social Security are low.

我们也应该接受改变想法的现实。我遇到过一些最痛苦的工作者，他们之所以忠于一份职业，仅仅因为那是他们18岁大学选择专业时选择的方向。当你接受“历史终结论”的幻觉时，你就会意识到，在未到法定饮酒年龄时选择的工作，在达到法定领取社会保障金的年龄后仍然能享受这份工作的几率很低。

The trick is to accept the reality of change and move on as soon as possible.

诀窍是接受变化的现实并尽快继续前进。

Jason Zweig, the Wall Street Journal investment columnist, worked with psychologist Daniel Kahneman on writing Kahneman’s book Thinking, Fast and Slow. Zweig once told a story about a personality quirk of Kahneman’s that served him well: “Nothing amazed me more about Danny than his ability to detonate what we had just done,” Zweig wrote. He and Kahneman could work endlessly on a chapter, but:

《华尔街日报》投资专栏作家杰森·茨威格曾与心理学家丹尼尔·卡尼曼合作撰写了卡尼曼的著作《思考，快与慢》。茨威格曾讲过一个故事，讲述卡尼曼的一个性格怪癖，这个怪癖对他很有帮助：“丹尼最让我惊讶的就是他能够颠覆我们刚刚完成的事情，”茨威格写道。他和卡尼曼可以无休止地写一个章节，但是：

The next thing you know, [Kahneman] sends a version so utterly transformed that it is unrecognizable: It begins differently, it ends differently, it incorporates anecdotes and evidence you never would have thought of, it draws on research that you’ve never heard of.

接下来你知道的，[卡尼曼]发送了一个完全不同的版本，它以不同的方式开始，以不同的方式结束，它包含了你从未想过的轶事和证据，它借鉴了你从未听说过的研究。

“When I asked Danny how he could start again as if we had never written an earlier draft,” Zweig continued, “he said the words I’ve never forgotten: ‘I have no sunk costs.’”⁴⁹

“当我问丹尼，他如何才能重新开始，就好像我们从未写过之前的草稿一样，”茨威格继续说道，“他说了一句我永远不会忘记的话：‘我没有沉没成本。’”⁴⁹

Sunk costs—anchoring decisions to past efforts that can’t be refunded—are a devil in a world where people change over time. They make our future selves prisoners to our past, different, selves. It’s the equivalent of a stranger making major life decisions for you.

沉没成本——将决策锚定在过去无法弥补的过去努力之上——在这个随着时间推移而改变的世界里，简直就是魔鬼。它让我们未来的自己成为过去不同自我的囚徒。这相当于一个陌生人替你做了人生中的重大决定。

Embracing the idea that financial goals made when you were a different person should be abandoned without mercy versus put on life support and dragged on can be a good strategy to minimize future regret.

接受这样的观点：当你还是另一个人时制定的财务目标应该被毫不留情地抛弃，而不是被置于生命支持系统之中并被拖延下去，这可能是减少未来遗憾的一个好策略。

The quicker it’s done, the sooner you can get back to compounding.

做得越快，你就能越快恢复复合。

Next, let’s talk about compounding’s price of admission.

接下来我们来谈谈复利的入场费。

#↩

#↩

Everything has a price, and the key to a lot of things with money is just figuring out what that price is and being willing to pay it.

任何事物都有其代价，而很多与金钱有关的事情的关键就在于弄清楚这个代价是什么，并愿意支付它。

The problem is that the price of a lot of things is not obvious until you’ve experienced them firsthand, when the bill is overdue.

问题是，很多东西的价格都是不明显的，直到你亲身体验过，账单过期时才知道。

General Electric was the largest company in the world in 2004, worth a third of a trillion dollars. It had either been first or second each year for the previous decade, capitalism’s shining example of corporate aristocracy.

通用电气是2004年全球最大的公司，市值达三分之一万亿美元。过去十年，它每年都稳居榜首或第二，堪称资本主义企业贵族的光辉典范。

Then everything fell to pieces.

然后一切都崩溃了。

The 2008 financial crisis sent GE’s financing division—which supplied more than half the company’s profits—into chaos. It was eventually sold for scrap. Subsequent bets in oil and energy were disasters, resulting in billions in writeoffs. GE stock fell from $40 in 2007 to $7 by 2018.

2008年的金融危机让通用电气的融资部门（该部门贡献了公司一半以上的利润）陷入混乱。最终，该部门被当作废品出售。随后，通用电气在石油和能源领域的投资更是惨败，导致数十亿美元的资产减值。通用电气股价从2007年的40美元跌至2018年的7美元。

Blame placed on CEO Jeff Immelt—who ran the company since 2001—was immediate and harsh. He was criticized for his leadership, his acquisitions, cutting the dividend, laying off workers and—of course—the plunging stock price. Rightly so: those rewarded with dynastic wealth when times are good hold the burden of responsibility when the tide goes out. He stepped down in 2017.

自2001年以来执掌该公司的首席执行官杰夫·伊梅尔特立即遭到严厉指责。他因领导能力不足、收购、削减股息、裁员以及——当然——股价暴跌而受到批评。这理所当然：那些在景气时期拥有家族财富的人，在景气衰退时要承担责任。他于2017年卸任。

But Immelt said something insightful on his way out.

但伊梅尔特在离任时说了一些有见地的话。

Responding to critics who said his actions were wrong and what he should have done was obvious, Immelt told his successor, “Every job looks easy when you’re not the one doing it.”

有人批评伊梅尔特的行为是错误的，他应该做什么都是显而易见的。对此，伊梅尔特对他的继任者说：“当你不是在做这件事的时候，每项工作看起来都很容易。”

Every job looks easy when you’re not the one doing it because the challenges faced by someone in the arena are often invisible to those in the crowd.

当你不是做这件事的人时，每项工作看起来都很容易，因为竞技场上某个人所面临的挑战往往是人群中的人看不到的。

Dealing with the conflicting demands of sprawling bloat, short-term investors, regulators, unions, and entrenched bureaucracy is not only hard to do, but it’s hard to even recognize the severity of the problems until you’re the one dealing with them. Immelt’s successor, who lasted 14 months, learned this as well.

处理日益膨胀的机构、短期投资者、监管机构、工会以及根深蒂固的官僚机构之间相互冲突的需求，不仅困难重重，而且除非你亲自处理这些问题，否则很难意识到问题的严重性。伊梅尔特的继任者在任仅14个月，他也深有体会。

Most things are harder in practice than they are in theory. Sometimes this is because we’re overconfident. More often it’s because we’re not good at identifying what the price of success is, which prevents us from being able to pay it.

大多数事情在实践中比在理论上更难。有时这是因为我们过于自信。更多的时候，是因为我们不善于识别成功的代价，这让我们无力承担。

The S&P 500 increased 119-fold in the 50 years ending 2018. All you had to do was sit back and let your money compound. But, of course, successful investing looks easy when you’re not the one doing it.

截至2018年的50年间，标准普尔500指数上涨了119倍。你只需要静静地等待，让你的资金增值。当然，如果你不是投资人，成功的投资看起来很容易。

“Hold stocks for the long run,” you’ll hear. It’s good advice.

你会听到这样的话：“长期持有股票。”这的确是个好建议。

But do you know how hard it is to maintain a long-term outlook when stocks are collapsing?

但你知道当股市崩盘时，保持长期展望有多么困难吗？

Like everything else worthwhile, successful investing demands a price. But its currency is not dollars and cents. It’s volatility, fear, doubt, uncertainty, and regret—all of which are easy to overlook until you’re dealing with them in real time.

如同其他所有有价值的事物一样，成功的投资也需要付出代价。但它的货币并非金钱，而是波动、恐惧、怀疑、不确定性和遗憾——所有这些在你真正面对它们之前都很容易被忽视。

The inability to recognize that investing has a price can tempt us to try to get something for nothing. Which, like shoplifting, rarely ends well.

无法认识到投资是有代价的，会诱使我们试图不劳而获。这就像商店偷窃一样，很少有好结果。

Say you want a new car. It costs $30,000. You have three options: 1) Pay $30,000 for it, 2) find a cheaper used one, or 3) steal it. In this case, 99% of people know to avoid the third option, because the consequences of stealing a car outweigh the upside.

假设你想买一辆新车，售价3万美元。你有三个选择：1）支付3万美元；2）找一辆更便宜的二手车；3）偷车。在这种情况下，99%的人都知道要避免第三种选择，因为偷车的后果大于好处。

But say you want to earn an 11% annual return over the next 30 years so you can retire in peace. Does this reward come free? Of course not. The world is never that nice. There’s a price tag, a bill that must be paid. In this case it’s a never-ending taunt from the market, which gives big returns and takes them away just as fast. Including dividends the Dow Jones Industrial Average returned about 11% per year from 1950 to 2019, which is great. But the price of success during this period was dreadfully high. The shaded lines in the chart show when it was at least 5% below its previous all-time high.

但是，假设你想在未来30年内获得11%的年回报率，这样你就可以安心退休了。这份回报是免费的吗？当然不是。世界从来都不是那么美好。它有代价，有必须付出的代价。在这种情况下，市场永无止境地嘲讽你，它给予你丰厚的回报，也同样迅速地收回。包括股息在内，道琼斯工业平均指数从1950年到2019年的年回报率约为11%，这已经很不错了。但在此期间，成功的代价也高得吓人。图表中的阴影线显示，它至少比之前的历史高点低了5%。

This is the price of market returns. The fee. It is the cost of admission. And it hurts.

这就是市场回报的代价。这笔费用。这是入场费。而且很伤人。

Like most products, the bigger the returns, the higher the price. Netflix stock returned more than 35,000% from 2002 to 2018, but traded below its previous all-time high on 94% of days. Monster Beverage returned 319,000% from 1995 to 2018—among the highest returns in history—but traded below its previous high 95% of the time during that period.

与大多数产品一样，回报越高，价格越高。Netflix 的股票在 2002 年至 2018 年期间回报率超过 35,000%，但 94% 的交易日交易价格低于其历史最高价。Monster Beverage 在 1995 年至 2018 年期间回报率为 319,000%，位列历史最高回报率之列，但在此期间 95% 的交易价格低于其历史最高价。

Now here’s the important part. Like the car, you have a few options: You can pay this price, accepting volatility and upheaval. Or you can find an asset with less uncertainty and a lower payoff, the equivalent of a used car. Or you can attempt the equivalent of grand-theft auto: Try to get the return while avoiding the volatility that comes along with it.

现在到了关键部分。就像汽车一样，你有几个选择：你可以支付这个价格，接受波动和动荡。或者，你可以找到一种不确定性更低、收益更低的资产，比如一辆二手车。或者，你可以尝试类似“侠盗猎车手”的做法：努力获得回报，同时避免随之而来的波动。

Many people in investing choose the third option. Like a car thief—though well-meaning and law-abiding—they form tricks and strategies to get the return without paying the price. They trade in and out. They attempt to sell before the next recession and buy before the next boom. Most investors with even a little experience know that volatility is real and common. Many then take what seems like the next logical step: trying to avoid it.

许多投资者选择第三种方式。就像偷车贼一样——尽管他们心怀善意且遵纪守法——他们也会想方设法获取回报，而无需付出代价。他们进进出出。他们试图在下一次经济衰退前卖出，在下一次繁荣前买入。大多数稍有经验的投资者都知道，波动是真实存在的，而且很常见。于是，许多人采取了看似合乎逻辑的下一步：试图规避波动。

But the Money Gods do not look highly upon those who seek a reward without paying the price. Some car thieves will get away with it. Many more will be caught and punished.

但财神对那些贪图回报却不付出代价的人并不看好。有些偷车贼会逍遥法外，但更多的人会被抓获并受到惩罚。

Same thing with investing.

投资也是一样。

Morningstar once looked at the performance of tactical mutual funds, whose strategy is to switch between stocks and bonds at opportune times, capturing market returns with lower downside risk.⁵⁰ They want the returns without paying the price. The study focused on the mid-2010 through late 2011 period, when U.S. stock markets went wild on fears of a new recession and the S&P 500 declined more than 20%. This is the exact kind of environment the tactical funds are supposed to work in. It was their moment to shine.

晨星公司曾研究过战术型共同基金的表现，这类基金的策略是在适当时机在股票和债券之间切换，以较低的下行风险获取市场回报。⁵⁰ 他们想要回报，却不愿付出代价。这项研究聚焦于2010年中期至2011年末，当时美国股市因对新一轮经济衰退的担忧而疯狂，标准普尔500指数下跌超过20%。这正是战术型基金应该在的环境中发挥作用。这正是它们闪耀光芒的时刻。

There were, by Morningstar’s count, 112 tactical mutual funds during this period. Only nine had better risk-adjusted returns than a simple 60/40 stock-bond fund. Less than a quarter of the tactical funds had smaller maximum drawdowns than the leave-it-alone index. Morningstar wrote: “With a few exceptions, [tactical funds] gained less, were more volatile, or were subject to just as much downside risk” as the hands-off fund.

据晨星统计，在此期间共有112只战术型共同基金。其中只有9只的风险调整后收益优于简单的60/40股票债券基金。不到四分之一的战术型基金的最大回撤小于不干预型指数。晨星写道：“除了少数例外，[战术型基金]的收益低于不干预型基金，波动性更大，或者下行风险与不干预型基金一样大。”

Individual investors fall for this when making their own investments, too. The average equity fund investor underperformed the funds they invested in by half a percent per year, according to Morningstar—the result of buying and selling when they should have just bought and held.⁵¹

个人投资者在进行投资时也会犯同样的错误。晨星公司的数据表明，股票基金投资者的平均年回报率比其投资的基金低0.5个百分点——这是因为他们在应该买入并持有的时候却买入并卖出。⁵¹

The irony is that by trying to avoid the price, investors end up paying double.

具有讽刺意味的是，为了避免损失，投资者最终付出了双倍的代价。

Back to GE. One of its many faults stems from an era under former CEO Jack Welch. Welch became famous for ensuring quarterly earnings per share beat Wall Street estimates. He was the grandmaster. If Wall Street analysts expected $0.25 per share, Jack would deliver $0.26 no matter the state of business or the economy. He’d do that by massaging the numbers—that description is charitable—often pulling gains from future quarters into the current quarter to make the obedient numbers salute their master.

回到通用电气。该公司的众多弊端之一源于前首席执行官杰克·韦尔奇执掌时期。韦尔奇因确保季度每股收益超过华尔街预期而闻名。他堪称大师。如果华尔街分析师预期每股收益0.25美元，那么无论业务状况或经济状况如何，韦尔奇都会将每股收益控制在0.26美元。他会通过修改数据（这种描述还算客气）来做到这一点——通常会将未来几个季度的收益计入本季度，以使那些听话的数字向他们的“大师”致敬。

Forbes reported one of dozens of examples: “[General Electric] for two years in a row ‘sold’ locomotives to unnamed financial partners instead of end users in transactions that left most of the risks of ownership with GE.”⁵²

《福布斯》报道了数十个案例之一：“[通用电气]连续两年将机车‘出售’给未具名的金融合作伙伴，而不是最终用户，这种交易将大部分所有权风险留给了通用电气。”⁵²

Welch never denied this game. He wrote in his book Straight From the Gut:

韦尔奇从未否认过这种游戏。他在《直击内心》一书中写道：

The response of our business leaders to the crises was typical of the GE culture. Even though the books had closed on the quarter, many immediately offered to pitch in to cover the [earnings] gap. Some said they could find an extra $10 million, $20 million, and even $30 million from their business to offset the surprise.

我们业务领导对危机的反应体现了通用电气的典型文化。尽管本季度已经结账，但许多人还是立即主动提出要出钱来弥补（盈利）缺口。有些人说，他们可以从业务部门额外拿出1000万美元、2000万美元甚至3000万美元来弥补这一意外。

The result was that under Welch’s leadership, stockholders didn’t have to pay the price. They got consistency and predictability—a stock that surged year after year without the surprises of uncertainty. Then the bill came due, like it always does. GE shareholders have suffered through a decade of mammoth losses that were previously shielded by accounting maneuvers. The penny gains of Welch’s era became dime losses today.

结果是，在韦尔奇的领导下，股东无需付出代价。他们获得了一致性和可预测性——股价年复一年飙升，没有出现不确定性带来的意外。然后，账单一如既往地到期了。通用电气的股东们经历了十年的巨额亏损，而这些亏损此前都通过会计手段得以掩盖。韦尔奇时代微薄的收益，如今却变成了巨额亏损。

The strangest example of this comes from failed mortgage giants Freddie Mac and Fannie Mae, which in the early 2000s were caught under-reporting current earnings by billions of dollars with the intention of spreading those gains out over future periods to give investors the illusion of smoothness and predictability.⁵³ The illusion of not having to pay the price.

最奇怪的例子来自破产的抵押贷款巨头房地美和房利美。21 世纪初，这两家公司被发现少报了数十亿美元的当期收益，意图将这些收益分摊到未来期间，给投资者一种平稳和可预测的错觉。⁵³ 一种不必付出代价的错觉。

The question is: Why do so many people who are willing to pay the price of cars, houses, food, and vacations try so hard to avoid paying the price of good investment returns?

问题是：为什么那么多愿意为汽车、房屋、食物和假期付出代价的人却如此努力地避免付出良好投资回报的代价？

The answer is simple: The price of investing success is not immediately obvious. It’s not a price tag you can see, so when the bill comes due it doesn’t feel like a fee for getting something good. It feels like a fine for doing something wrong. And while people are generally fine with paying fees, fines are supposed to be avoided. You’re supposed to make decisions that preempt and avoid fines. Traffic fines and IRS fines mean you did something wrong and deserve to be punished. The natural response for anyone who watches their wealth decline and views that drop as a fine is to avoid future fines.

答案很简单：投资成功的代价并非显而易见。它不是看得见的价格标签，所以账单到期时，你不会觉得这是获得好东西的费用，而像是做错事的罚款。虽然人们通常不介意支付费用，但罚款是应该避免的。你应该做出预先决定，避免罚款。交通罚款和国税局罚款意味着你做错了事，理应受到惩罚。对于那些眼睁睁看着财富缩水，并将财富缩水视为罚款的人来说，自然的反应就是避免未来的罚款。

It sounds trivial, but thinking of market volatility as a fee rather than a fine is an important part of developing the kind of mindset that lets you stick around long enough for investing gains to work in your favor.

这听起来微不足道，但将市场波动视为费用而不是罚款是培养这种心态的重要组成部分，这种心态可以让您坚持足够长的时间以使投资收益对您有利。

Few investors have the disposition to say, “I’m actually fine if I lose 20% of my money.” This is doubly true for new investors who have never experienced a 20% decline.

很少有投资者会说：“即使我损失了 20% 的钱，我也没什么问题。”对于从未经历过 20% 亏损的新投资者来说，情况尤其如此。

But if you view volatility as a fee, things look different.

但如果你把波动性视为一种费用，情况就不同了。

Disneyland tickets cost $100. But you get an awesome day with your kids you’ll never forget. Last year more than 18 million people thought that fee was worth paying. Few felt the $100 was a punishment or a fine. The worthwhile tradeoff of fees is obvious when it’s clear you’re paying one.

迪士尼乐园门票100美元。但你和孩子们一起度过了难忘的美好一天。去年，超过1800万人认为这笔费用值得支付。很少有人认为这100美元是惩罚或罚款。当你明确知道要支付费用时，这些费用的得失就显而易见了。

Same with investing, where volatility is almost always a fee, not a fine.

投资也是一样，波动性几乎总是一种费用，而不是罚款。

Market returns are never free and never will be. They demand you pay a price, like any other product. You’re not forced to pay this fee, just like you’re not forced to go to Disneyland. You can go to the local county fair where tickets might be $10, or stay home for free. You might still have a good time. But you’ll usually get what you pay for. Same with markets. The volatility/uncertainty fee—the price of returns—is the cost of admission to get returns greater than low-fee parks like cash and bonds.

市场回报从来都不是免费的，也永远不会免费。它们会要求你付出代价，就像任何其他产品一样。你不会被迫支付这笔费用，就像你不会被迫去迪士尼乐园一样。你可以去当地的乡村集市，门票可能要10美元，或者你可以免费待在家里。你或许仍然会玩得很开心。但你通常会得到你付出的回报。市场也是如此。波动性/不确定性费用——回报的价格——是为了获得比现金和债券等低收费公园更高的回报而支付的入场费。

The trick is convincing yourself that the market’s fee is worth it. That’s the only way to properly deal with volatility and uncertainty—not just putting up with it, but realizing that it’s an admission fee worth paying.

诀窍在于说服自己，市场的费用是值得的。这是妥善应对波动性和不确定性的唯一方法——不仅仅是忍受，而是意识到这是一笔值得支付的入场费。

There’s no guarantee that it will be. Sometimes it rains at Disneyland.

没人能保证一定会下雨。迪士尼乐园有时会下雨。

But if you view the admission fee as a fine, you’ll never enjoy the magic.

但如果你把入场费视为罚款，你就永远无法享受到其中的魔力。

Find the price, then pay it.

找到价格，然后支付。

#↩

#↩

The implosion of the dot-com bubble in the early 2000s reduced household wealth by $6.2 trillion.

21 世纪初互联网泡沫的破灭导致家庭财富减少了 6.2 万亿美元。

The end of the housing bubble cut away more than $8 trillion.

房地产泡沫的破裂导致资产损失超过8万亿美元。

It’s hard to overstate how socially devastating financial bubbles can be. They ruin lives.

金融泡沫对社会的破坏力无论怎样强调都不为过。它毁掉了人们的生活。

Why do these things happen?

为什么会发生这些事情？

And why do they keep happening?

为什么这些事情会不断发生？

Why can’t we learn our lessons?

我们为什么不能吸取教训？

The common answer here is that people are greedy, and greed is an indelible feature of human nature.

这里常见的答案是，人是贪婪的，贪婪是人性中不可磨灭的特征。

That may be true, and it’s a good enough answer for most. But remember from chapter 1: no one is crazy. People make financial decisions they regret, and they often do so with scarce information and without logic. But the decisions made sense to them when they were made. Blaming bubbles on greed and stopping there misses important lessons about how and why people rationalize what in hindsight look like greedy decisions.

这或许没错，对大多数人来说，这已经足够了。但请记住第一章的内容：没有人是疯子。人们会做出后悔的财务决策，而且通常是在信息匮乏、缺乏逻辑的情况下做出的。但这些决策在当时对他们来说都是合理的。将泡沫归咎于贪婪，并止步于此，错失了重要的教训：人们如何以及为何会将事后看来看似贪婪的决策合理化。

Part of why bubbles are hard to learn from is that they are not like cancer, where a biopsy gives us a clear warning and diagnosis. They are closer to the rise and fall of a political party, where the outcome is known in hindsight but the cause and blame are never agreed upon.

泡沫之所以难以汲取教训，部分原因在于它不像癌症，活检就能给出明确的警告和诊断。它更像一个政党的兴衰，事后诸葛亮，结果可想而知，但其原因和责任却始终悬而未决。

Competition for investment returns is fierce, and someone has to own every asset at every point in time. That means the mere idea of bubbles will always be controversial, because no one wants to think they own an overvalued asset. In hindsight we’re more likely to point cynical fingers than to learn lessons.

投资回报竞争异常激烈，总得有人在任何时间点都持有所有资产。这意味着，仅仅是“泡沫”这个概念就永远充满争议，因为没人愿意认为自己持有的资产估值过高。事后看来，我们更有可能愤世嫉俗地指责他人，而不是汲取教训。

I don’t think we’ll ever be able to fully explain why bubbles occur. It’s like asking why wars occur—there are almost always several reasons, many of them conflicting, all of them controversial.

我认为我们永远无法完全解释泡沫产生的原因。这就像问战争爆发的原因一样——几乎总是有多种原因，其中许多原因相互矛盾，所有原因都充满争议。

It’s too complicated a subject for simple answers.

这个问题太复杂了，无法用简单的方法回答。

But let me propose one reason they happen that both goes overlooked and applies to you personally: Investors often innocently take cues from other investors who are playing a different game than they are.

但是，让我提出一个发生这种情况的原因，这个原因既被忽视又适用于您个人：投资者经常天真地从玩着不同游戏的其他投资者那里获得暗示。

An idea exists in finance that seems innocent but has done incalculable damage.

金融领域存在一种看似无害但却造成了无法估量的损失的想法。

It’s the notion that assets have one rational price in a world where investors have different goals and time horizons.

这种观点认为，在投资者拥有不同目标和时间范围的世界中，资产都有一个合理的价格。

Ask yourself: How much should you pay for Google stock today?

问问自己：今天您应该为谷歌股票支付多少钱？

The answer depends on who “you” are.

答案取决于“你”是谁。

Do you have a 30-year time horizon? Then the smart price to pay involves a sober analysis of Google’s discounted cash flows over the next 30 years.

你有30年的投资眼光吗？那么明智的做法是冷静分析谷歌未来30年的折现现金流。

Are you looking to cash out within 10 years? Then the price to pay can be figured out by an analysis of the tech industry’s potential over the next decade and whether Google management can execute on its vision.

你想在10年内套现吗？那么，你需要付出的代价可以通过分析未来十年科技行业的潜力以及谷歌管理层能否实现其愿景来计算。

Are you looking to sell within a year? Then pay attention to Google’s current product sales cycles and whether we’ll have a bear market.

你想在一年内出售吗？那就关注谷歌当前的产品销售周期，看看是否会迎来熊市。

Are you a day trader? Then the smart price to pay is “who cares?” because you’re just trying to squeeze a few bucks out of whatever happens between now and lunchtime, which can be accomplished at any price.

你是日内交易者吗？那么明智的做法是“谁在乎呢？”因为你只是想从现在到午餐时间之间发生的任何事情中榨取一些钱，而这可以不惜任何代价来实现。

When investors have different goals and time horizons—and they do in every asset class—prices that look ridiculous to one person can make sense to another, because the factors those investors pay attention to are different.

当投资者拥有不同的目标和时间范围时（他们在每个资产类别中都有不同的目标和时间范围），一个人认为荒谬的价格对另一个人来说可能很有意义，因为投资者关注的因素是不同的。

Take the dot-com bubble in the 1990s.

以 20 世纪 90 年代的互联网泡沫为例。

People can look at Yahoo! stock in 1999 and say “That was crazy! A zillion times revenue! The valuation made no sense!”

人们可以看看雅虎1999年的股票，然后说：“那太疯狂了！市值是收入的无数倍！这个估值毫无意义！”

But many investors who owned Yahoo! stock in 1999 had time horizons so short that it made sense for them to pay a ridiculous price. A day trader could accomplish what they need whether Yahoo! was at $5 a share or $500 a share as long as it moved in the right direction that day. And it did, for years.

但许多在1999年持有雅虎股票的投资者眼光短浅，因此支付如此高昂的价格也合情合理。无论雅虎股价是5美元还是500美元，只要当天股价朝着正确的方向发展，日内交易者就能获得所需的收益。而且，多年来，雅虎股价一直如此。

An iron rule of finance is that money chases returns to the greatest extent that it can. If an asset has momentum—it’s been moving consistently up for a period of time—it’s not crazy for a group of short-term traders to assume it will keep moving up. Not indefinitely; just for the short period of time they need it to. Momentum attracts short-term traders in a reasonable way.

金融界有一条铁律：金钱会尽其所能地追逐回报。如果一项资产拥有动量——它在一段时间内持续上涨——那么一群短期交易者认为它会持续上涨并不疯狂。它不会无限期地上涨；只是在他们需要的短时间内上涨。动量以合理的方式吸引着短期交易者。

Then it’s off to the races.

然后就开始比赛了。

Bubbles form when the momentum of short-term returns attracts enough money that the makeup of investors shifts from mostly long term to mostly short term.

当短期回报的势头吸引到足够的资金，导致投资者的构成从主要关注长期投资转向主要关注短期投资时，就会形成泡沫。

That process feeds on itself. As traders push up short-term returns, they attract even more traders. Before long—and it often doesn’t take long—the dominant market price-setters with the most authority are those with shorter time horizons.

这个过程会自我循环。随着交易员推高短期回报，他们会吸引更多的交易员。不久之后——通常不会很久——那些目光短浅的人就会成为市场中最具权威的定价者。

Bubbles aren’t so much about valuations rising. That’s just a symptom of something else: time horizons shrinking as more short-term traders enter the playing field.

泡沫与其说是估值上升，不如说是另一种现象的征兆：随着更多短期交易者进入市场，投资期限正在缩短。

It’s common to say the dot-com bubble was a time of irrational optimism about the future. But one of the most common headlines of that era was announcing record trading volume, which is what happens when investors are buying and selling in a single day. Investors—particularly the ones setting prices—were not thinking about the next 20 years. The average mutual fund had 120% annual turnover in 1999, meaning they were, at most, thinking about the next eight months. So were the individual investors who bought those mutual funds. Maggie Mahar wrote in her book Bull!:

人们常说，互联网泡沫时期是对未来非理性乐观的时期。但那个时代最常见的新闻之一，莫过于宣布交易量创历史新高，这指的是投资者在一天内买入和卖出股票。投资者——尤其是那些制定价格的投资者——并没有考虑未来20年。1999年，共同基金的平均年换手率为120%，这意味着他们最多只考虑未来8个月。购买这些共同基金的个人投资者也是如此。玛吉·马哈尔在她的著作《牛市！》（Bull!）中写道：

By the mid-nineties, the press had replaced annual scorecards with reports that appeared every three months. The change spurred investors to chase performance, rushing to buy the funds at the top of the charts, just when they were most expensive.

到了九十年代中期，媒体用每三个月发布一次的报告取代了年度评分卡。这一变化促使投资者追逐业绩，在股价最高的时候争相购买排名靠前的基金。

This was the era of day trading, short-term option contracts, and up-to-the minute market commentary. It’s not the kind of thing you’d associate with long-term views.

那是一个充斥着日内交易、短期期权合约和最新市场评论的时代。这些都不是你能联想到长期观点的东西。

The same thing happened during the housing bubble of the mid-2000s.

21世纪初的房地产泡沫时期也发生过同样的事情。

It’s hard to justify paying $700,000 for a two-bedroom Florida track home to raise your family in for the next 10 years. But it makes perfect sense if you plan on flipping the home in a few months into a market with rising prices to make a quick profit. Which is exactly what many people were doing during the bubble.

很难说要花70万美元买一套佛罗里达的两居室跑道房，供家人在未来10年里居住。但如果你打算在几个月内把房子转手卖给房价上涨的市场，快速获利，那就完全说得通了。而这正是泡沫时期许多人的做法。

Data from Attom, a company that tracks real estate transactions, shows the number of houses in America that sold more than once in a 12-month period—they were flipped—rose fivefold during the bubble, from 20,000 in the first quarter of 2000 to over 100,000 in the first quarter of 2004.⁵⁴ Flipping plunged after the bubble to less than 40,000 per quarter, where it’s roughly remained since.

跟踪房地产交易的公司 Attom 的数据显示，在泡沫时期，美国 12 个月内售出不止一次的房屋数量（即被转卖的房屋数量）增长了五倍，从 2000 年第一季度的 20,000 套增加到 2004 年第一季度的 100,000 多套。⁵⁴ 泡沫破裂后，转卖数量暴跌至每季度不足 40,000 套，此后基本保持在这个水平。

Do you think these flippers cared about long-term price-to-rent ratios? Or whether the prices they paid were backed up by long-term income growth? Of course not. Those numbers weren’t relevant to their game. The only thing that mattered to flippers was that the price of the home would be more next month than it was this month. And for many years, it was.

你认为这些炒房者会在意长期的房租比吗？或者他们支付的价格是否有长期收入增长作为支撑？当然不会。这些数字对他们来说无关紧要。对炒房者来说，唯一在乎的是下个月的房价会比这个月高。多年来，情况确实如此。

You can say a lot about these investors. You can call them speculators. You can call them irresponsible. You can shake your head at their willingness to take huge risks.

你可以对这些投资者说三道四。你可以称他们为投机者。你可以说他们不负责任。你可以对他们愿意承担巨大风险的行为摇头。

But I don’t think you can call all of them irrational.

但我不认为你可以说它们全都是无理性的。

The formation of bubbles isn’t so much about people irrationally participating in long-term investing. They’re about people somewhat rationally moving toward short-term trading to capture momentum that had been feeding on itself.

泡沫的形成与其说是人们非理性地参与长期投资，不如说是人们为了抓住原本自我滋生的势头，而在一定程度上理性地转向短期交易。

What do you expect people to do when momentum creates a big short-term return potential? Sit and watch patiently? Never. That’s not how the world works. Profits will always be chased. And short-term traders operate in an area where the rules governing long-term investing—particularly around valuation—are ignored, because they’re irrelevant to the game being played.

当动量创造巨大的短期回报潜力时，你指望人们做什么？静观其变？绝不可能。世界不是这样运转的。利润总是被追逐的。而短期交易者所处的领域，长期投资的规则——尤其是估值规则——被忽视，因为它们与正在进行的游戏无关。

That’s where things get interesting, and where the problems begin.

这就是事情变得有趣之处，也是问题开始的地方。

Bubbles do their damage when long-term investors playing one game start taking their cues from those short-term traders playing another.

当玩一种游戏的长期投资者开始从玩另一种游戏的短期交易者那里获得线索时，泡沫就会造成损害。

Cisco stock rose 300% in 1999 to $60 per share. At that price the company was valued at $600 billion, which is insane. Few actually thought it was worth that much; the day-traders were just having their fun. Economist Burton Malkiel once pointed out that Cisco’s implied growth rate at that valuation meant it would become larger than the entire U.S. economy within 20 years.

1999年，思科股价上涨300%，达到每股60美元。当时，该公司的估值高达6000亿美元，简直疯狂。几乎没有人真正想到它值这么多钱；短线交易者只是在寻开心。经济学家伯顿·马尔基尔曾指出，思科在当时估值下的隐含增长率意味着，20年内，其规模将超过整个美国经济。

But if you were a long-term investor in 1999, $60 was the only price available to buy. And many people were buying it at that price. So you may have looked around and said to yourself, “Wow, maybe these other investors know something I don’t.” Maybe you went along with it. You even felt smart about it.

但如果你是1999年的长期投资者，60美元是唯一可以买入的价格。而且很多人都以这个价格买入。所以你可能会环顾四周，心想：“哇，也许其他投资者知道一些我不知道的事情。” 也许你会顺势买入。你甚至觉得自己很聪明。

What you don’t realize is that the traders who were setting the marginal price of the stock were playing a different game than you were. Sixty dollars a share was a reasonable price for the traders, because they planned on selling the stock before the end of the day, when its price would probably be higher. But sixty dollars was a disaster in the making for you, because you planned on holding shares for the long run.

你没有意识到的是，设定股票边际价格的交易员和你玩的可不一样。每股60美元对交易员来说是一个合理的价格，因为他们计划在收盘前卖出股票，那时股价可能会更高。但对你来说，每股60美元就是一场灾难，因为你打算长期持有股票。

These two investors rarely even know that each other exist. But they’re on the same field, running toward each other. When their paths blindly collide, someone gets hurt. Many finance and investment decisions are rooted in watching what other people do and either copying them or betting against them. But when you don’t know why someone behaves like they do you won’t know how long they’ll continue acting that way, what will make them change their mind, or whether they’ll ever learn their lesson.

这两位投资者几乎不知道彼此的存在。但他们却在同一领域，彼此追逐。当他们的道路盲目碰撞时，总会有人受伤。许多金融和投资决策都源于观察他人的行为，要么效仿，要么与他们做空。但当你不知道某人为何如此行事时，你就无法知道他们会继续这种行为多久，什么会让他们改变主意，或者他们是否会吸取教训。

When a commentator on CNBC says, “You should buy this stock,” keep in mind that they do not know who you are. Are you a teenager trading for fun? An elderly widow on a limited budget? A hedge fund manager trying to shore up your books before the quarter ends? Are we supposed to think those three people have the same priorities, and that whatever level a particular stock is trading at is right for all three of them?

当CNBC的评论员说“你应该买这只股票”时，请记住，他们并不了解你。你是为了好玩而交易的青少年？还是预算有限的老寡妇？还是想在季度结束前巩固业绩的对冲基金经理？难道我们应该认为这三个人有相同的优先事项，并且无论某只股票的交易价格处于什么水平，对他们三个人来说都是合适的吗？

It’s crazy.

这太疯狂了。

It’s hard to grasp that other investors have different goals than we do, because an anchor of psychology is not realizing that rational people can see the world through a different lens than your own. Rising prices persuade all investors in ways the best marketers envy. They are a drug that can turn value-conscious investors into dewy-eyed optimists, detached from their own reality by the actions of someone playing a different game than they are.

很难理解其他投资者的目标与我们不同，因为心理学的一个支柱就是没有意识到理性的人会用与你不同的视角看待世界。价格上涨会以连最优秀的营销人员都羡慕的方式说服所有投资者。价格上涨就像一剂毒药，能把注重价值的投资者变成天真的乐观主义者，因为玩着与他们不同游戏的人的行为而脱离了自身的现实。

Being swayed by people playing a different game can also throw off how you think you’re supposed to spend your money. So much consumer spending, particularly in developed countries, is socially driven: subtly influenced by people you admire, and done because you subtly want people to admire you.

受玩不同游戏的人影响，也会影响你对花钱方式的理解。很多消费者的支出，尤其是在发达国家，都是受社会驱动的：潜移默化地受到你仰慕的人的影响，而你这样做，是因为你潜移默化地希望别人仰慕你。

But while we can see how much money other people spend on cars, homes, clothes, and vacations, we don’t get to see their goals, worries, and aspirations. A young lawyer aiming to be a partner at a prestigious law firm might need to maintain an appearance that I, a writer who can work in sweatpants, have no need for. But when his purchases set my own expectations, I’m wandering down a path of potential disappointment because I’m spending the money without the career boost he’s getting. We might not even have different styles. We’re just playing a different game. It took me years to figure this out.

然而，我们虽然能看到别人在汽车、房屋、服装和度假上花了多少钱，却看不到他们的目标、担忧和抱负。一位志在成为知名律所合伙人的年轻律师可能需要维持一种形象，而我，一个可以穿着运动裤工作的作家，却不需要。但当他的购买行为设定了我的预期时，我却走上了一条潜在的失望之路，因为我花了钱，却没有看到他获得的职业提升。我们甚至可能风格迥异。我们只是玩着不同的游戏。我花了好几年才明白这一点。

A takeaway here is that few things matter more with money than understanding your own time horizon and not being persuaded by the actions and behaviors of people playing different games than you are.

这里的要点是，对于金钱来说，没有什么比了解自己的时间范围以及不被与你玩不同游戏的人的行为和举止所说服更重要。

The main thing I can recommend is going out of your way to identify what game you’re playing.

我最推荐的一点是，你要仔细辨别自己在玩什么游戏。

It’s surprising how few of us do. We call everyone investing money “investors” like they’re basketball players, all playing the same game with the same rules. When you realize how wrong that notion is you see how vital it is to simply identify what game you’re playing. How I invest my own money is detailed in chapter 20, but years ago I wrote out “I am a passive investor optimistic in the world’s ability to generate real economic growth and I’m confident that over the next 30 years that growth will accrue to my investments.”

令人惊讶的是，我们中很少有人这样做。我们把所有投资的人都称为“投资者”，就像篮球运动员一样，大家都在玩同样的游戏，遵循同样的规则。当你意识到这种想法是多么错误时，你就会明白，明确自己在玩什么游戏是多么重要。我如何投资自己的钱在第20章有详细说明，但几年前我曾写道：“我是一个被动投资者，对世界创造实际经济增长的能力持乐观态度，我相信未来30年，这种增长将惠及我的投资。”

This might seem quaint, but once you write that mission statement down you realize everything that’s unrelated to it—what the market did this year, or whether we’ll have a recession next year—is part of a game I’m not playing. So I don’t pay attention to it, and am in no danger of being persuaded by it.

这听起来可能有点古怪，但一旦你写下这份使命宣言，你就会意识到，所有与之无关的事情——今年市场表现如何，或者明年是否会陷入经济衰退——都是我玩的一场游戏的一部分，我可没玩过。所以我不关注它，也不会被它说服。

Next, let’s talk about pessimism.

接下来我们来谈谈悲观主义。

#↩

#↩

“For reasons I have never understood, people like to hear that the world is going to hell.”

“出于我永远无法理解的原因，人们喜欢听到世界正在走向地狱。”

—Historian Deirdre McCloskey

—历史学家迪尔德丽·麦克洛斯基

Optimism is the best bet for most people because the world tends to get better for most people most of the time.

对于大多数人来说，乐观是最好的选择，因为大多数时候，世界对于大多数人来说都会变得越来越好。

But pessimism holds a special place in our hearts. Pessimism isn’t just more common than optimism. It also sounds smarter. It’s intellectually captivating, and it’s paid more attention than optimism, which is often viewed as being oblivious to risk.

但悲观主义在我们心中占据着特殊的地位。悲观主义不仅比乐观主义更常见，而且听起来也更睿智。它富有智慧，比乐观主义更受关注，而乐观主义通常被认为是对风险的漠视。

Before we go further we should define what optimism is. Real optimists don’t believe that everything will be great. That’s complacency. Optimism is a belief that the odds of a good outcome are in your favor over time, even when there will be setbacks along the way. The simple idea that most people wake up in the morning trying to make things a little better and more productive than wake up looking to cause trouble is the foundation of optimism. It’s not complicated. It’s not guaranteed, either. It’s just the most reasonable bet for most people, most of the time. The late statistician Hans Rosling put it differently: “I am not an optimist. I am a very serious possibilist.”

在进一步探讨之前，我们应该先定义一下什么是乐观。真正的乐观主义者不会相信一切都会好起来。那是一种自满。乐观是一种信念，相信即使一路上会遇到挫折，好结果的概率也会随着时间的推移而对你有利。大多数人清晨醒来，都会努力让事情变得更好、更高效，而不是一醒来就想着制造麻烦，这个简单的理念就是乐观主义的基石。它并不复杂，也并非万无一失。它只是大多数人在大多数时候最合理的选择。已故统计学家汉斯·罗斯林对此有不同的看法：“我不是乐观主义者。我是一个非常严肃的可能性主义者。”

Now we can discuss optimism’s more compelling sibling: pessimism.

现在我们可以讨论一下乐观主义更引人注目的兄弟：悲观主义。

December 29th, 2008.

2008年12月29日。

The worst year for the economy in modern history is about to close. Stock markets around the world had collapsed. The global financial system was on day-to-day life support. Unemployment was surging.

现代史上经济最糟糕的一年即将结束。全球股市崩盘。全球金融体系日渐衰败，失业率飙升。

As things looked like they couldn’t get worse, The Wall Street Journal published a story arguing that we hadn’t seen anything yet. It ran a front-page article on the outlook of a Russian professor named Igor Panarin whose economic views rival the flair of science fiction writers.

眼看形势似乎不会恶化，《华尔街日报》却刊登了一篇报道，称我们还没看到任何迹象。该报头版刊登了俄罗斯教授伊戈尔·帕纳林的观点，他的经济观点堪比科幻小说家的天分。

The Journal wrote:

《华尔街日报》写道：

Around the end of June 2010, or early July, [Panarin] says, the U.S. will break into six pieces—with Alaska reverting to Russian control ... California will form the nucleus of what he calls “The Californian Republic,” and will be part of China or under Chinese influence. Texas will be the heart of “The Texas Republic,” a cluster of states that will go to Mexico or fall under Mexican influence. Washington, D.C., and New York will be part of an “Atlantic America” that may join the European Union. Canada will grab a group of Northern states Prof. Panarin calls “The Central North American Republic.” Hawaii, he suggests, will be a protectorate of Japan or China, and Alaska will be subsumed into Russia.⁵⁵

帕纳林教授认为，到2010年6月底或7月初，美国将分裂成六块——阿拉斯加将回归俄罗斯控制……加利福尼亚将成为他所谓的“加利福尼亚共和国”的核心，并将成为中国的一部分或受中国影响。德克萨斯将成为“德克萨斯共和国”的核心，这片区域内的几个州将并入墨西哥或受墨西哥影响。华盛顿特区和纽约州将成为“大西洋美洲”的一部分，该区域可能加入欧盟。加拿大将获得一组北方州，帕纳林教授称之为“中北美共和国”。他暗示，夏威夷将成为日本或中国的保护国，而阿拉斯加将被并入俄罗斯。

This was not the ramblings of a backroom blog or tinfoil-hat newsletter. This was on the front page of the most prestigious financial newspaper in the world.

这不是什么幕后博客或锡帽通讯里的胡言乱语。这是世界上最负盛名的财经报纸的头版。

It is fine to be pessimistic about the economy. It’s even OK to be apocalyptic. History is full of examples of countries experiencing not just recessions, but disintegrations.

对经济感到悲观是可以的，甚至悲观到末日也无妨。历史上有很多国家不仅经历衰退，甚至走向崩溃。

The interesting thing about Panarin-type stories is that their polar opposite—forecasts of outrageous optimism—are rarely taken as seriously as prophets of doom.

帕纳林式故事的有趣之处在于，它们的对立面——过分乐观的预测——很少像末日预言家那样被认真对待。

Take Japan in the late 1940s. The nation was gutted by defeat from World War II in every way—economically, industrially, culturally, socially. A brutal winter in 1946 caused a famine that limited food to less than 800 calories per person per day.⁵⁶

以20世纪40年代末的日本为例。二战的失败让这个国家在经济、工业、文化和社会等各个方面都遭受重创。1946年的一个严冬引发了一场饥荒，导致每人每日食物摄入量不足800卡路里。⁵⁶

Imagine if a Japanese academic had written a newspaper article during this time that said:

想象一下，如果一位日本学者在这段时间写了一篇报纸文章，其中写道：

Chin up, everyone. Within our lifetime our economy will grow to almost 15 times the size it was before the end of the war. Our life expectancy will nearly double. Our stock market will produce returns like any country in history has rarely seen. We will go more than 40 years without ever seeing unemployment top 6%. We will become a world leader in electronic innovation and corporate managerial systems. Before long we will be so rich that we will own some of the most prized real estate in the United States. Americans, by the way, will be our closest ally and will try to copy our economic insights.

大家振作起来。在我们有生之年，我们的经济规模将增长到战前水平的近15倍。我们的预期寿命将几乎翻一番。我们的股市将产生历史上任何国家都罕见的回报。我们将在未来40多年里，失业率从未超过6%。我们将在电子创新和企业管理系统方面成为世界领先者。不久之后，我们将变得如此富有，拥有美国一些最珍贵的房地产。顺便说一句，美国人将成为我们最亲密的盟友，并将试图复制我们的经济智慧。

They would have been summarily laughed out of the room and asked to seek a medical evaluation.

他们肯定会被立即嘲笑并被要求去寻求医疗评估。

Keep in mind the description above is what actually happened in Japan in the generation after the war. But the mirror opposite of Panarin looks absurd in a way a forecast of doom doesn’t.

请记住，以上描述是战后一代日本实际发生的事情。但与帕纳林截然相反的情况，却以一种末日预言所不具备的方式显得荒谬。

Pessimism just sounds smarter and more plausible than optimism.

悲观主义听起来比乐观主义更聪明、更合理。

Tell someone that everything will be great and they’re likely to either shrug you off or offer a skeptical eye. Tell someone they’re in danger and you have their undivided attention.

如果你告诉别人一切都会好起来，他们很可能会对你不屑一顾，或者对你报以怀疑的眼光。但如果你告诉别人他们正处于危险之中，他们就会全神贯注地听你说话。

If a smart person tells me they have a stock pick that’s going to rise 10-fold in the next year, I will immediately write them off as full of nonsense.

如果一个聪明人告诉我，他们选的一只股票明年会涨 10 倍，我会立即认为他们在胡说八道。

If someone who’s full of nonsense tells me that a stock I own is about to collapse because it’s an accounting fraud, I will clear my calendar and listen to their every word.

如果有人胡言乱语地告诉我，我持有的股票即将崩盘，因为这是一个会计欺诈行为，我会清空我的日程表，认真听取他们的每一句话。

Say we’ll have a big recession and newspapers will call you. Say we’re headed for average growth and no one particularly cares. Say we’re nearing the next Great Depression and you’ll get on TV. But mention that good times are ahead, or markets have room to run, or that a company has huge potential, and a common reaction from commentators and spectators alike is that you are either a salesman or comically aloof of risks.

假设我们将遭遇严重经济衰退，报纸会给你打电话。假设我们正走向平均增长，也没人特别关心。假设我们即将迎来下一次大萧条，你就会上电视。但如果你提到好日子即将到来，或者市场还有上涨空间，或者某家公司潜力巨大，评论员和旁观者通常会觉得你要么是个推销员，要么就是对风险漠不关心。

The investing newsletter industry has known this for years, and is now populated by prophets of doom despite operating in an environment where the stock market has gone up 17,000-fold in the last century (including dividends).

投资通讯行业多年来一直都知道这一点，尽管在上个世纪股市已经上涨了 17,000 倍（包括股息）的环境下，投资通讯行业现在仍然充斥着末日预言家。

This is true beyond finance. Matt Ridley wrote in his book The Rational Optimist:

这在金融领域之外同样适用。马特·里德利在他的《理性乐观派》一书中写道：

A constant drumbeat of pessimism usually drowns out any triumphalist song ... If you say the world has been getting better you may get away with being called naïve and insensitive. If you say the world is going to go on getting better, you are considered embarrassingly mad. If, on the other hand, you say catastrophe is imminent, you may expect a McArthur genius award or even the Nobel Peace Prize. In my own adult lifetime ... the fashionable reasons for pessimism changed, but the pessimism was constant.

持续不断的悲观主义鼓声通常会淹没任何胜利者的歌声……如果你说世界一直在变得更好，你或许会被说成天真和麻木不仁。如果你说世界会继续变得更好，你又会被认为是令人尴尬的疯子。另一方面，如果你说灾难即将来临，你或许会期待获得麦克阿瑟天才奖，甚至诺贝尔和平奖。在我成年的一生中……悲观主义的流行理由变了，但悲观主义始终如一。

“Every group of people I ask thinks the world is more frightening, more violent, and more hopeless—in short, more dramatic—than it really is,” Hans Rosling wrote in his book Factfulness.

汉斯·罗斯林在他的《事实》一书中写道：“我问到的每一群人都认为这个世界比实际情况更可怕、更暴力、更绝望——简而言之，更戏剧化。”

When you realize how much progress humans can make during a lifetime in everything from economic growth to medical breakthroughs to stock market gains to social equality, you would think optimism would gain more attention than pessimism. And yet.

当你意识到人类一生中在经济增长、医学突破、股市上涨和社会平等等各个领域取得的巨大进步时，你可能会认为乐观主义比悲观主义更受关注。然而，

The intellectual allure of pessimism has been known for ages. John Stuart Mill wrote in the 1840s: “I have observed that not the man who hopes when others despair, but the man who despairs when others hope, is admired by a large class of persons as a sage.”

悲观主义的智识魅力由来已久。约翰·斯图尔特·密尔在19世纪40年代写道：“我观察到，被一大群人视为圣贤的人，并非在别人绝望时抱有希望的人，而是在别人充满希望时绝望的人。”

The question is, why? And how does it impact how we think about money?

问题是，为什么？这会如何影响我们对金钱的看法？

Let’s repeat the premise that no one is crazy.

让我们重申一下这个前提：没有人是疯子。

There are valid reasons why pessimism is seductive when dealing with money. It just helps to know what they are to ensure we don’t take them too far.

在处理金钱问题时，悲观主义的诱惑是有充分理由的。了解这些理由有助于我们避免过度悲观。

Part of it is instinctual and unavoidable. Kahneman says the asymmetric aversion to loss is an evolutionary shield. He writes:

这部分是出于本能，无法避免。卡尼曼认为，对损失的不对称厌恶是一种进化的盾牌。他写道：

When directly compared or weighted against each other, losses loom larger than gains. This asymmetry between the power of positive and negative expectations or experiences has an evolutionary history. Organisms that treat threats as more urgent than opportunities have a better chance to survive and reproduce.

当直接比较或权衡时，损失比收益更大。这种积极和消极预期或经历力量之间的不对称，由来已久。那些将威胁视为比机遇更紧迫的生物体，拥有更好的生存和繁衍机会。

But a few other things make financial pessimism easy, common, and more persuasive than optimism.

但其他一些因素使得金融悲观主义变得容易、普遍，并且比乐观主义更有说服力。

One is that money is ubiquitous, so something bad happening tends to affect everyone and captures everyone’s attention.

一是金钱无处不在，所以发生不好的事情往往会影响到每个人，并引起每个人的关注。

That isn’t true of, say, weather. A hurricane barreling down on Florida poses no direct risk to 92% of Americans. But a recession barreling down on the economy could impact every single person—including you, so pay attention.

但天气情况就不一样了。一场席卷佛罗里达的飓风不会对92%的美国人构成直接风险。但一场席卷经济的经济衰退可能会影响到每个人——包括你，所以一定要注意。

This goes for something as specific as the stock market. More than half of all American households directly own stocks.⁵⁷ Even among those that don’t, the stock market’s gyrations are promoted so heavily in the media that the Dow Jones Industrial Average might be the stock-less household’s most-watched economic barometer.

这对于像股票市场这样具体的事物也适用。超过一半的美国家庭直接持有股票。⁵⁷ 即使在那些没有股票的家庭中，股票市场的波动也受到媒体的大力宣传，以至于道琼斯工业平均指数可能是那些没有股票的家庭中最受关注的经济晴雨表。

Stocks rising 1% might be briefly mentioned in the evening news. But a 1% fall will be reported in bold, all-caps letters usually written in blood red. The asymmetry is hard to avoid.

股市上涨1%可能会在晚间新闻中被简短提及。但下跌1%则会以粗体大写字母（通常是血红色）报道。这种不对称很难避免。

And while few question or try to explain why the market went up—isn’t it supposed to go up?—there is almost always an attempt to explain why it went down.

尽管很少有人质疑或试图解释市场为何上涨（难道它不应该上涨吗？），但几乎总是有人试图解释市场为何下跌。

Are investors worried about economic growth?

投资者是否担心经济增长？

Did the Fed screw things up again?

美联储又把事情搞砸了吗？

Are politicians making bad decisions?

政客们是否做出了错误的决定？

Is there another shoe to drop?

还有另一只鞋子要掉下来吗？

Narratives about why a decline occurred make them easier to talk about, worry about, and frame a story around what you think will happen next—usually, more of the same.

关于为什么会发生衰退的叙述使得人们更容易谈论、担心，并围绕你认为接下来会发生的事情构建一个故事——通常，接下来会发生更多相同的事情。

Even if you don’t own stocks, those kind of things will grab your attention. Only 2.5% of Americans owned stocks on the eve of the great crash of 1929 that sparked the Great Depression. But the majority of Americans—if not the world—watched in amazement as the market collapsed, wondering what it signaled about their own fate. This was true whether you were a lawyer or a farmer or a car mechanic.

即使你不持有股票，这类事情也会引起你的注意。在引发大萧条的1929年大崩盘前夕，只有2.5%的美国人持有股票。但大多数美国人——如果不是全世界的话——都惊呆地看着市场崩盘，想知道这预示着他们自己的命运。无论你是律师、农民还是汽车修理工，情况都是如此。

Historian Eric Rauchway writes:

历史学家 Eric Rauchway 写道：

This fall in value immediately afflicted only a few Americans. But so closely had the others watched the market and regarded it as an index of their fates that they suddenly stopped much of their economic activity. As the economist Joseph Schumpeter later wrote, “people felt that the ground under their feet was giving way.”⁵⁸

这次价值下跌立即影响到的只有少数美国人。但其他人如此密切地关注着市场，并将其视为自身命运的指标，以至于他们突然停止了大部分经济活动。正如经济学家约瑟夫·熊彼特后来所写，“人们感觉脚下的土地正在崩塌。”⁵⁸

There are two topics that will affect your life whether you are interested in them or not: money and health. While health issues tend to be individual, money issues are more systemic. In a connected system where one person’s decisions can affect everyone else, it’s understandable why financial risks gain a spotlight and capture attention in a way few other topics can.

无论你是否感兴趣，有两个话题都会影响你的生活：金钱和健康。健康问题往往因人而异，而金钱问题则更具系统性。在一个互联互通的系统中，一个人的决定会影响到其他人，因此，金融风险之所以能成为焦点并受到关注，是其他话题难以比拟的，这一点也就不难理解了。

Another is that pessimists often extrapolate present trends without accounting for how markets adapt.

另一个原因是悲观主义者经常推断当前的趋势，而不考虑市场如何适应。

In 2008 environmentalist Lester Brown wrote: “By 2030 China would need 98 million barrels of oil a day. The world is currently producing 85 million barrels a day and may never produce much more than that. There go the world’s oil reserves.”⁵⁹

2008年，环保主义者莱斯特·布朗写道：“到2030年，中国每天将需要9800万桶石油。目前全球每天的产量为8500万桶，而且可能永远不会超过这个数字。世界石油储备就这样没了。”⁵⁹

He’s right. The world would run out of oil in that scenario.

他说得对。那样的话，世界石油就用完了。

But that’s not how markets work.

但市场并不是这样运作的。

There is an iron law in economics: extremely good and extremely bad circumstances rarely stay that way for long because supply and demand adapt in hard-to-predict ways.

经济学中有一条铁律：极好和极坏的情况很少会持续很长时间，因为供求关系的调整方式难以预测。

Consider what happened to oil immediately after Brown’s prediction.

想想布朗做出预测后石油市场立即发生了什么。

Oil prices surged in 2008 as growing global demand—much of it from China—crept up to potential output. A barrel of oil sold for $20 in 2001 and $138 by 2008.⁶⁰

2008年，随着全球需求（其中大部分来自中国）不断增长，石油价格飙升至潜在产量。2001年，每桶石油售价为20美元，到2008年则达到138美元。⁶⁰

The new price meant drilling oil was like pulling gold out of the ground. The incentives for oil producers changed dramatically. Hard-to-tap oil supplies that weren’t worth the fight at $20 a barrel—the cost of drilling didn’t offset the price you could sell it for—became the bonanza of a lifetime now that you could sell a barrel for $138.

新价格意味着钻探石油就像从地下挖出金子一样。石油生产商的动机发生了巨大变化。原本难以开采的石油资源，在每桶20美元的价格下不值得争夺——钻探成本还不足以抵消其售价——如今却变成了千载难逢的宝藏，因为每桶石油的售价已经达到了138美元。

That sparked a surge of new fracking and horizontal drilling technologies.

这引发了新的水力压裂和水平钻井技术的兴起。

The Earth has had roughly the same amount of oil reserves for all of human history. And we’ve known where the big oil deposits are for some time. What changes is the technology we have that lets us economically pull the stuff out of the ground. Oil historian Daniel Yergin writes: “86% of oil reserves in the United States are the result not of what is estimated at time of discovery but of the revisions” that come when our technology improves.

纵观整个人类历史，地球的石油储量大致相同。我们早就知道大型石油矿藏在哪里。改变这一切的是我们拥有的技术，使我们能够经济地从地下开采石油。石油历史学家丹尼尔·耶金写道：“美国86%的石油储量并非来自发现时的估算，而是来自技术进步带来的修正。”

That’s what happened as fracking took off in 2008. In the United States alone oil production went from roughly five million barrels per day in 2008 to 13 million by 2019.⁶¹ World oil production is now over 100 million barrels per day—some 20% above what Brown assumed was the high mark.

这就是 2008 年水力压裂技术兴起后发生的情况。仅在美国，石油产量就从 2008 年的每天约 500 万桶增长到 2019 年的 1300 万桶⁶¹。目前，世界石油产量每天超过 1 亿桶，比布朗假设的最高水平高出约 20%。

To a pessimist extrapolating oil trends in 2008, of course things looked bad. To a realist who understood that necessity is the mother of all invention, it was far less scary.

对于一个预测2008年石油走势的悲观主义者来说，情况当然很糟糕。但对于一个懂得“需要是一切发明之母”的现实主义者来说，情况远没有那么可怕。

Assuming that something ugly will stay ugly is an easy forecast to make. And it’s persuasive, because it doesn’t require imagining the world changing. But problems correct and people adapt. Threats incentivize solutions in equal magnitude. That’s a common plot of economic history that is too easily forgotten by pessimists who forecast in straight lines.

假设糟糕的事情会持续糟糕，这很容易预测。而且这种预测很有说服力，因为它不需要想象世界会发生变化。但问题会得到解决，人们会适应。威胁会以同等程度激励解决方案。这是经济史上常见的现象，却很容易被那些预测直线的悲观主义者所遗忘。

A third is that progress happens too slowly to notice, but setbacks happen too quickly to ignore.

第三，进步太慢，难以察觉；挫折却来得太快，难以忽视。

There are lots of overnight tragedies. There are rarely overnight miracles.

一夜之间发生的悲剧很多，但一夜之间发生的奇迹却很少。

On January 5th, 1889, the Detroit Free Press pushed back against the long-held dream that man could one day fly like a bird. Airplanes, the paper wrote, “appear impossible”:

1889年1月5日，《底特律自由新闻报》驳斥了人类长期以来的梦想——有朝一日人类能像鸟一样飞翔。该报写道，飞机“似乎不可能实现”：

The smallest possible weight of a flying machine, with the necessary fuel and engineer, could not be less than 300 or 400 pounds … but there is a low limit of weight, certainly not much beyond fifty pounds, beyond which it is impossible for an animal to fly. Nature has reached this limit, and with her utmost effort has failed to pass it.

飞行器加上必要的燃料和发动机，其最小重量不可能低于300或400磅……但重量也有一个下限，肯定不会超过50磅，超过这个下限，动物就不可能飞行。大自然已经达到了这个极限，尽管竭尽全力，却依然无法超越。

Six months later, Orville Wright dropped out of high school to help his brother, Wilbur, tinker in their backyard shed to build a printing press. It was the brothers’ first joint invention. It would not be their last.

六个月后，奥维尔·莱特高中辍学，帮助弟弟威尔伯在自家后院的棚子里修修补补，造了一台印刷机。这是兄弟俩的第一个共同发明，但这绝不会是他们的最后一个。

If you had to make a list of the most important inventions of the 20th century, the airplane would be at least top five, if not number one. The airplane changed everything. It started world wars, it ended world wars. It connected the world, bridging gaps between cities and rural communities; oceans and countries.

如果要列出20世纪最重要的发明，飞机即使不能排第一，也至少能排进前五。飞机改变了一切。它引发了世界大战，也结束了世界大战。它连接了世界，弥合了城乡之间、海洋与国家之间的差距。

But the story of the Wright Brothers’ quest to build the first plane has a fascinating twist.

但莱特兄弟制造第一架飞机的故事却有一个令人着迷的转折。

After they conquered flight, no one seemed to notice. Nobody seemed to care.

在他们征服飞行之后，似乎没有人注意到，也没有人在意。

In his 1952 book on American history, Frederick Lewis Allen wrote:

弗雷德里克·刘易斯·艾伦 (Frederick Lewis Allen) 在其 1952 年出版的美国历史书中写道：

Several years went by before the public grasped what the Wrights were doing; people were so convinced that flying was impossible that most of those who saw them flying about Dayton [Ohio] in 1905 decided that what they had seen must be some trick without significance—somewhat as most people today would regard a demonstration of, say, telepathy. It was not until May, 1908—nearly four and a half years after the Wright’s first flight—that experienced reporters were sent to observe what they were doing, experienced editors gave full credence to these reporters’ excited dispatches, and the world at last woke up to the fact that human flight had been successfully accomplished.

过了好几年，公众才明白莱特兄弟究竟在做什么；人们坚信飞行是不可能的，以至于1905年在代顿（俄亥俄州）看到莱特兄弟飞行的大多数人都认为，他们看到的只是某种毫无意义的花招——有点像今天大多数人认为的心灵感应之类的演示。直到1908年5月——莱特兄弟首飞近四年半后——经验丰富的记者才被派去观察他们的飞行，经验丰富的编辑们完全相信了这些记者激动人心的报道，世界终于意识到人类已经成功飞行。

Even after people caught on to the plane’s wonder, they underestimated it for years.

即使人们意识到了这架飞机的奇妙，他们仍然低估了它多年。

First it was seen mainly as a military weapon. Then a rich person’s toy. Then, perhaps, used to transport a few people.

起初，它主要被视为一种军事武器。后来，它成了富人的玩具。再后来，或许还被用来运送一些人。

The Washington Post wrote in 1909: “There will never be such a thing as commercial aerial freighters. Freight will continue to drag its slow weight across the patient earth.” The first cargo plane took off five months later.

《华盛顿邮报》在1909年写道：“永远不会有商用空中货运飞机这种东西。货运将继续拖着它缓慢的重量穿越这片耐心的土地。” 五个月后，第一架货机起飞。

Now compare that slow, years-long awakening to becoming optimistic about the airplane to how quickly people pay attention to drivers of pessimism, like a corporate bankruptcy.

现在，将人们对飞机的乐观态度缓慢地、持续数年的时间与人们对悲观情绪驱动因素（如公司破产）的关注速度进行比较。

Or a major war.

或者一场大战。

Or a plane crash. Some of the first mentions of the Wright’s plane came in 1908 when an Army Lieutenant named Thomas Selfridge was killed during a demonstration flight.⁶²

又或者飞机失事。莱特兄弟的飞机最早出现在1908年，当时一位名叫托马斯·塞尔弗里奇的陆军中尉在一次演示飞行中丧生。⁶²

Growth is driven by compounding, which always takes time. Destruction is driven by single points of failure, which can happen in seconds, and loss of confidence, which can happen in an instant.

增长是由复利驱动的，而复利总是需要时间的。而破坏则是由单点故障驱动的，单点故障可能在几秒钟内发生，而信心的丧失则可能在一瞬间发生。

It’s easier to create a narrative around pessimism because the story pieces tend to be fresher and more recent. Optimistic narratives require looking at a long stretch of history and developments, which people tend to forget and take more effort to piece together.

围绕悲观主义创作叙事更容易，因为故事片段往往更新鲜、更近期。乐观主义叙事则需要回顾漫长的历史和发展，而人们往往会忘记这些，并需要付出更多努力才能拼凑起来。

Consider the progress of medicine. Looking at the last year will do you little good. Any single decade won’t do much better. But looking at the last 50 years will show something extraordinary. For example, the age-adjusted death rate per capita from heart disease has declined more than 70% since 1965, according to the National Institute of Health.⁶³ A 70% decline in heart-disease death is enough to save something like half a million American lives per year. Picture the population of Atlanta saved every year. But since that progress happened so slowly, it captures less attention than quick, sudden losses like terrorism, plane crashes, or natural disasters. We could have a Hurricane Katrina five times a week, every week—imagine how much attention that would receive—and it would not offset the number of annual lives saved by the decline in heart disease in the last 50 years.

想想医学的进步。只看去年的记录对你没有多大帮助。任何一个十年也不会有太大进步。但回顾过去 50 年，我们会看到一些非凡的发现。例如，根据美国国立卫生研究院的数据，自 1965 年以来，年龄调整后的人均心脏病死亡率下降了 70% 以上。⁶³ 心脏病死亡人数下降 70% 足以每年挽救大约 50 万美国人的生命。想象一下每年拯救亚特兰大人口的生命。但由于这种进步来得太慢，它引起的关注不如恐怖主义、飞机失事或自然灾害等快速、突发的损失。即使我们每周都会遭遇五次卡特里娜飓风——想象一下那会引起多少关注——它也无法抵消过去 50 年心脏病死亡率下降所挽救的生命。

This same thing applies to business, where it takes years to realize how important a product or company is, but failures can happen overnight.

同样的事情也适用于商业，人们需要花费数年的时间才能意识到产品或公司的重要性，但失败可能在一夜之间发生。

And in stock markets, where a 40% decline that takes place in six months will draw congressional investigations, but a 140% gain that takes place over six years can go virtually unnoticed.

在股票市场，六个月内发生的 40% 的下跌将引发国会调查，但六年内发生的 140% 的上涨可能几乎不会被注意到。

And in careers, where reputations take a lifetime to build and a single email to destroy.

在职业生涯中，声誉需要一生的时间才能建立，而毁掉它却只需一封电子邮件。

The short sting of pessimism prevails while the powerful pull of optimism goes unnoticed.

悲观主义的短暂刺痛盛行，而乐观主义的强大吸引力却被忽视。

This underscores an important point made previously in this book: In investing you must identify the price of success—volatility and loss amid the long backdrop of growth—and be willing to pay it.

这强调了本书前面提出的一个重要观点：在投资时，你必须确定成功的代价——长期增长背景下的波动和损失——并愿意付出代价。

In 2004 The New York Times interviewed Stephen Hawking, the scientist whose incurable motor-neuron disease left him paralyzed and unable to talk at age 21.

2004 年，《纽约时报》采访了科学家史蒂芬·霍金，他因患无法治愈的运动神经元疾病而在 21 岁时瘫痪并且无法说话。

Through his computer, Hawking told the interviewer how excited he was to sell books to lay people.

霍金通过电脑告诉采访者，他对向普通人出售书籍感到多么兴奋。

“Are you always this cheerful?” the Times asked.

《泰晤士报》问道：“你总是这么开朗吗？”

“My expectations were reduced to zero when I was 21. Everything since then has been a bonus,” he replied.

“当我 21 岁时，我的期望降为零。从那时起，一切都是意外的收获，”他回答道。

Expecting things to be great means a best-case scenario that feels flat. Pessimism reduces expectations, narrowing the gap between possible outcomes and outcomes you feel great about.

期待事情会好转意味着最好的情况会让人感觉平淡无奇。悲观主义会降低预期，缩小可能的结果与你感觉良好的结果之间的差距。

Maybe that’s why it’s so seductive. Expecting things to be bad is the best way to be pleasantly surprised when they’re not.

也许这就是它如此诱人的原因。期待事情变糟，是当事情并非如此时获得惊喜的最好方法。

Which, ironically, is something to be optimistic about.

具有讽刺意味的是，这是一件值得乐观的事情。

Now, a short story about stories.

现在，讲一个关于故事的短篇故事。

#↩

#↩

Imagine an alien dispatched to Earth. His job is to keep tabs on our economy.

想象一下一个外星人被派往地球，他的工作就是监视我们的经济。

He circles above New York City, trying to size up the economy and how it changed between 2007 and 2009.

他在纽约市上空盘旋，试图评估这里的经济状况以及它在 2007 年至 2009 年期间发生的变化。

On New Year’s Eve 2007 he hovers over Times Square. He sees tens of thousands of happy partygoers surrounded by bright lights, monstrous billboards, fireworks, and TV cameras.

2007年新年前夜，他徘徊在时代广场上空。他看到成千上万的欢乐派对参与者被璀璨的灯光、巨大的广告牌、烟火和电视摄像机包围着。

He comes back to Times Square on New Year’s Eve 2009. He sees tens of thousands of happy partygoers surrounded by bright lights, monstrous billboards, fireworks, and TV cameras.

2009 年除夕夜，他回到时代广场。他看到数以万计的欢乐聚会者被明亮的灯光、巨大的广告牌、烟花和电视摄像机包围着。

It looks about the same. He cannot see much difference.

看起来差不多。他看不出有什么区别。

He sees roughly the same number of New Yorkers hustling around the city. Those people are surrounded by the same number of office buildings, which house the same number of desks with the same number of computers, hooked up to the same number of internet connections.

他看到数量大致相同的纽约人在这座城市忙碌地奔波。这些人周围环绕着同样数量的办公楼，楼里摆放着同样数量的办公桌、同样数量的电脑，连接着同样数量的互联网连接。

Outside the city he sees the same number of factories and warehouses, connected by the same highways, carrying the same number of trucks.

在城外，他看到同样数量的工厂和仓库，由同样的高速公路连接，运载着同样数量的卡车。

He gets a little closer to the ground and sees the same universities teaching the same topics and handing out the same degrees to the same number of people.

他更加贴近实际情况，看到同样的大学教授同样的课程，向同样数量的人颁发同样的学位。

He sees the same number of patents protecting the same groundbreaking ideas.

他看到同样数量的专利保护着同样的突破性创意。

He notices that technology has improved. Everyone in 2009 carries smartphones that didn’t exist in 2007. Computers are now faster. Medicine is better. Cars get better gas mileage. Solar and fracking technology has advanced. Social media has grown exponentially.

他注意到科技进步了。2009年，每个人都带着2007年还不存在的智能手机。现在的电脑速度更快了。医疗质量更好了。汽车的燃油经济性也提高了。太阳能和水力压裂技术也取得了进步。社交媒体呈指数级增长。

As he flies around the country he sees the same. Around the globe, more of the same.

当他飞往全国各地时，他看到的也是同样的景象。在世界各地，类似的情况更多。

The economy is in about the same shape, maybe even better, in 2009 as it was in 2007, he concludes.

他总结道，2009 年的经济状况与 2007 年大致相同，甚至可能更好。

Then he looks at the numbers.

然后他看了看数字。

He’s shocked that U.S. households are $16 trillion poorer in 2009 than they were in 2007.

令他震惊的是，2009 年美国家庭的财富比 2007 年减少了 16 万亿美元。

He’s dumbfounded that 10 million more Americans are unemployed.

令他震惊的是，又有 1000 万美国人失业。

He’s in disbelief when he learns the stock market is worth half of what it was two years before.

当他得知股市价值只有两年前的一半时，他简直不敢相信。

He can’t believe that people’s forecast of their economic potential has plunged.

他不敢相信人们对其经济潜力的预测竟然大幅下降。

“I don’t get it,” he says. “I’ve seen the cities. I’ve looked at the factories. You guys have the same knowledge, the same tools, the same ideas. Nothing has changed! Why are you poorer? Why are you more pessimistic?”

“我不明白，”他说。“我看过城市，也看过工厂。你们的知识、工具、理念都一样。什么都没变！为什么你们更穷了？为什么你们更悲观了？”

There was one change the alien couldn’t see between 2007 and 2009: The stories we told ourselves about the economy.

2007年至2009年间，有一个变化是外星人无法察觉的：我们自己讲述的有关经济的故事。

In 2007, we told a story about the stability of housing prices, the prudence of bankers, and the ability of financial markets to accurately price risk.

2007年，我们讲述了一个关于房价稳定、银行家谨慎以及金融市场准确定价风险的能力的故事。

In 2009 we stopped believing that story.

2009年我们不再相信这个故事。

That’s the only thing that changed. But it made all the difference in the world.

这是唯一改变的事情。但它却带来了天壤之别。

Once the narrative that home prices will keep rising broke, mortgage defaults rose, then banks lost money, then they reduced lending to other businesses, which led to layoffs, which led to less spending, which led to more layoffs, and on and on.

一旦房价将持续上涨的说法被打破，抵押贷款违约率就会上升，银行就会亏损，然后它们就会减少对其他企业的贷款，这会导致裁员，进而导致支出减少，进而导致更多裁员，如此反复。

Other than clinging to a new narrative, we had an identical—if not greater—capacity for wealth and growth in 2009 as we did in 2007. Yet the economy suffered its worst hit in 80 years.

除了坚持新的叙事之外，2009 年我们的财富和增长能力与 2007 年相同（甚至更强）。然而，经济却遭受了 80 年来最严重的打击。

This is different from, say, Germany in 1945, whose manufacturing base had been obliterated. Or Japan in the 2000s, whose working-age population was shrinking. That’s tangible economic damage. In 2009 we inflicted narrative damage on ourselves, and it was vicious. It’s one of the most potent economic forces that exists.

这与1945年的德国不同，当时德国的制造业基础已被摧毁。这与21世纪初的日本不同，当时日本的劳动年龄人口正在减少。这都是实实在在的经济损失。2009年，我们给自己造成了“叙事性伤害”，而且非常严重。这是现存最强大的经济力量之一。

When we think about the growth of economies, businesses, investments and careers, we tend to think about tangible things—how much stuff do we have and what are we capable of?

当我们考虑经济、企业、投资和职业的增长时，我们倾向于考虑有形的东西——我们拥有多少东西，我们能做什么？

But stories are, by far, the most powerful force in the economy. They are the fuel that can let the tangible parts of the economy work, or the brake that holds our capabilities back.

但迄今为止，故事才是经济中最强大的力量。它们是推动经济实体运作的燃料，也是阻碍我们能力发展的刹车。

At the personal level, there are two things to keep in mind about a story-driven world when managing your money.

从个人层面来说，在故事驱动的世界中管理你的资金时，有两件事需要牢记。

1. The more you want something to be true, the more likely you are to believe a story that overestimates the odds of it being true.

1. 你越希望某件事是真的，你就越有可能相信一个高估了它真实性的故事。

What was the happiest day of your life?

你一生中最快乐的一天是哪一天？

The documentary How to Live Forever asks that innocent question to a centenarian who offered an amazing response.

纪录片《如何永生》向一位百岁老人提出了这个天真的问题，而这位老人给出了令人惊讶的回答。

“Armistice Day,” she said, referring to the 1918 agreement that ended World War I.

她说：“停战纪念日”，指的是 1918 年结束第一次世界大战的协议。

“Why?” the producer asks.

“为什么？”制片人问道。

“Because we knew there would be no more wars ever again,” she says.

“因为我们知道不会再有战争了，”她说。

World War II began 21 years later, killing 75 million people.

21年后，第二次世界大战爆发，造成7500万人死亡。

There are many things in life that we think are true because we desperately want them to be true.

生活中有很多事情我们认为是真的，因为我们迫切希望它们是真的。

I call these things “appealing fictions.” They have a big impact on how we think about money—particularly investments and the economy.

我把这些东西称为“吸引人的虚构”。它们对我们看待金钱——尤其是投资和经济——的方式有着巨大的影响。

An appealing fiction happens when you are smart, you want to find solutions, but face a combination of limited control and high stakes.

当你很聪明，想要找到解决方案，但又面临控制有限和高风险的局面时，就会出现一个有吸引力的虚构故事。

They are extremely powerful. They can make you believe just about anything.

它们极其强大，几乎可以让你相信任何事情。

Take a short example.

举一个简单的例子。

Ali Hajaji’s son was sick. Elders in his Yemeni village proposed a folk remedy: shove the tip of a burning stick through his son’s chest to drain the sickness from his body.

阿里·哈贾吉的儿子病了。也门村里的长老们提出了一种民间疗法：用一根燃烧的木棍尖端刺穿儿子的胸膛，以排出体内的病气。

After the procedure, Hajaji told The New York Times: “When you have no money, and your son is sick, you’ll believe anything.”⁶⁴

手术后，哈贾吉告诉《纽约时报》：“当你身无分文，而你的儿子又生病时，你什么都会相信。”⁶⁴

Medicine predates useful medicine by thousands of years. Before the scientific method and the discovery of germs there was blood-letting, starvation therapy, cutting holes in your body to let the evils out, and other treatments that did nothing but hasten your demise.

医学比实用医学的出现早了数千年。在科学方法和细菌发现之前，就存在放血疗法、绝食疗法、在身体上开孔放出病菌等疗法，而这些疗法只会加速死亡。

It seems crazy. But if you desperately need a solution and a good one isn’t known or readily available to you, the path of least resistance is toward Hajaji’s reasoning: willing to believe anything. Not just try anything, but believe it.

这听起来似乎有些疯狂。但如果你迫切需要一个解决方案，而你又不知道或找不到合适的方案，那么阻力最小的路径就是遵循哈贾吉的推理：愿意相信一切。不仅仅是尝试一切，而是相信它。

Chronicling the Great Plague of London, Daniel Defoe wrote in 1722:

丹尼尔·笛福在 1722 年记录了伦敦大瘟疫：

The people were more addicted to prophecies and astrological conjurations, dreams, and old wives’ tales than ever they were before or since … almanacs frighted them terribly … the posts of houses and corners of streets were plastered over with doctors’ bills and papers of ignorant fellows, quacking and inviting the people to come to them for remedies, which was generally set off with such flourishes as these: ‘Infallible preventive pills against the plague.’ ‘Neverfailing preservatives against the infection.’ ‘Sovereign cordials against the corruption of the air.’

人们比以往任何时候都更加沉迷于预言、占星术、梦境和老妇人的故事……年鉴把他们吓坏了……房屋的柱子和街道的角落里贴满了医生的账单和无知者的证件，他们嘎嘎叫着，邀请人们来找他们治病，通常配上这样的花言巧语：“预防瘟疫的万无一失的药丸。”“防止感染的万无一失的防腐剂。”“抵抗空气污染的至高无上的强心剂。”

The plague killed a quarter of Londoners in 18 months. You’ll believe just about anything when the stakes are that high.

这场瘟疫在18个月内夺走了四分之一的伦敦人的生命。事关重大，你几乎什么都会相信。

Now think about how the same set of limited information and high stakes impact our financial decisions.

现在想想同样的有限信息和高风险如何影响我们的财务决策。

Why do people listen to TV investment commentary that has little track record of success? Partly because the stakes are so high in investing. Get a few stock picks right and you can become rich without much effort. If there’s a 1% chance that someone’s prediction will come true, and it coming true will change your life, it’s not crazy to pay attention—just in case.

为什么人们会听那些几乎没有成功记录的电视投资评论？部分原因是投资风险太高。只要选对几只股票，你就能毫不费力地致富。如果某人的预测有1%的概率成真，而且成真会改变你的人生，那么关注一下也没什么不妥——以防万一。

And there are so many financial opinions that once you pick a strategy or side, you become invested in them both financially and mentally. If you want a certain stock to rise 10-fold, that’s your tribe. If you think a certain economic policy will spark hyperinflation, that’s your side.

金融观点五花八门，一旦你选择了一种策略或立场，你就会在财务和精神上都投入其中。如果你希望某只股票上涨10倍，那就是你的阵营。如果你认为某项经济政策会引发恶性通货膨胀，那就是你的阵营。

These may be low-probability bets. The problem is that viewers can’t, or don’t, calibrate low odds, like a 1% chance. Many default to a firm belief that what they want to be true is unequivocally true. But they’re only doing that because the possibility of a huge outcome exists.

这些可能是低概率的赌注。问题在于，观众无法，或者不会去校准低赔率，比如1%的概率。许多人默认坚信他们想要发生的事情是绝对正确的。但他们这样做，只是因为存在出现巨大结果的可能性。

Investing is one of the only fields that offers daily opportunities for extreme rewards. People believe in financial quackery in a way they never would for, say, weather quackery because the rewards for correctly predicting what the stock market will do next week are in a different universe than the rewards for predicting whether it will be sunny or rainy next week.

投资是少数几个每天都能提供极高回报机会的领域之一。人们对金融骗术的信任程度，远超他们对天气骗术的信任程度，因为准确预测下周股市走势的回报，与预测下周晴雨的回报截然不同。

Consider that 85% of active mutual funds underperformed their benchmark over the 10 years ending 2018.⁶⁵ That figure has been fairly stable for generations. You would think an industry with such poor performance would be a niche service and have a hard time staying in business. But there’s almost five trillion dollars invested in these funds.⁶⁶ Give someone the chance of investing alongside “the next Warren Buffett” and they’ll believe with such faith that millions of people will put their life savings behind it.

想想看，截至2018年的10年间，85%的主动型共同基金表现逊于基准。⁶⁵ 几代人以来，这个数字一直相当稳定。你可能会认为，表现如此糟糕的行业应该只是小众服务，难以维持下去。但如今，投资于这些基金的资金已接近5万亿美元。⁶⁶ 如果有人有机会与“下一个沃伦·巴菲特”一起投资，他们就会坚信，数百万人会将毕生积蓄都投入其中。

Or take Bernie Madoff. In hindsight his Ponzi scheme should have been obvious. He reported returns that never varied, they were audited by a relatively unknown accounting firm, and he refused to release much information on how the returns were achieved. Yet Madoff raised billions of dollars from some of the most sophisticated investors in the world. He told a good story, and people wanted to believe it.

或者以伯尼·麦道夫为例。事后看来，他的庞氏骗局本应显而易见。他报告的收益始终如一，由一家名不见经传的会计师事务所审计，而且他拒绝透露太多关于这些收益如何实现的信息。然而，麦道夫却从世界上最精明的投资者手中筹集了数十亿美元。他编造了一个精彩的故事，人们愿意相信。

This is a big part of why room for error, flexibility, and financial independence—important themes discussed in previous chapters—are indispensable.

这在很大程度上解释了为什么容错空间、灵活性和财务独立性（前几章讨论过的重要主题）是不可或缺的。

The bigger the gap between what you want to be true and what you need to be true to have an acceptable outcome, the more you are protecting yourself from falling victim to an appealing financial fiction.

你希望的现实与你需要的现实之间的差距越大，你就越能保护自己免于成为诱人的金融虚构的受害者。

When thinking about room for error in a forecast it is tempting to think that potential outcomes range from you being just right enough to you being very, very right. But the biggest risk is that you want something to be true so badly that the range of your forecast isn’t even in the same ballpark as reality.

在考虑预测的误差范围时，人们很容易认为潜在的结果范围从勉强正确到非常非常正确不等。但最大的风险在于，你太渴望某件事成真，以至于你的预测范围与现实甚至不在一个水平。

In its last 2007 meeting the Federal Reserve predicted what economic growth would be in 2008 and 2009.⁶⁷ Already weary of a weakening economy, it was not optimistic. It predicted a range of potential growth—1.6% growth on the low end, 2.8% on the high end. That was its margin of safety, its room for error. In reality the economy contracted by more than 2%, meaning the Fed’s low-end estimate was off by almost threefold.

美联储在2007年的上一次会议上预测了2008年和2009年的经济增长。⁶⁷ 美联储早已对经济疲软感到厌倦，因此并不乐观。它预测的潜在增长率区间为——低端为1.6%，高端为2.8%。这是它的安全边际，是它的容错空间。实际上，经济萎缩了2%以上，这意味着美联储的低端预测几乎与实际情况相差了三倍。

It’s hard for a policymaker to predict an outright recession, because a recession will make their careers complicated. So even worst-case projections rarely expect anything worse than just “slow-ish” growth. It’s an appealing fiction, and it’s easy to believe because expecting anything worse is too painful to consider.

政策制定者很难预测彻底的经济衰退，因为衰退会让他们的职业生涯变得复杂。因此，即使是最坏的预测，也很少会比“略微缓慢”的增长更糟糕。这听起来很诱人，而且很容易让人相信，因为预期更糟糕的情况太过痛苦，难以想象。

Policymakers are easy targets for criticism, but all of us do this to some extent. And we do it in both directions. If you think a recession is coming and you cash out your stocks in anticipation, your view of the economy is suddenly going to be warped by what you want to happen. Every blip, every anecdote, will look like a sign that doom has arrived—maybe not because it has, but because you want it to.

政策制定者很容易成为批评的对象，但我们所有人在某种程度上都会这样。而且我们双向都会这样。如果你认为经济衰退即将来临，并提前套现股票，你对经济的看法就会突然被你希望发生的事情扭曲。每一个波动，每一个轶事，都看起来像是末日来临的征兆——或许不是因为它已经到来，而是因为你希望它到来。
