Incentives are a powerful motivator, and we should always remember how they influence our own financial goals and outlooks. It can’t be overstated: there is no greater force in finance than room for error, and the higher the stakes, the wider it should be.

激励机制是强大的动力，我们应该时刻铭记它如何影响我们自身的财务目标和愿景。这一点无论怎样强调都不为过：在财务领域，没有什么比容错空间更大，而且风险越高，容错空间就应该越大。

2. Everyone has an incomplete view of the world. But we form a complete narrative to fill in the gaps.

2. 每个人对世界的看法都是不完整的。但我们会构建一个完整的叙事来填补这些空白。

My daughter is about a year old as I write this. She’s curious about everything and learns so fast.

我写这篇文章的时候，我女儿大概一岁左右。她对一切都充满好奇，学东西也很快。

But sometimes I think about all the stuff she can’t comprehend.

但有时我会想到所有她无法理解的事情。

She has no idea why her dad goes to work every morning.

她不知道为什么她的爸爸每天早上都要去上班。

The concept of bills, budgets, careers, promotions, and saving for retirement are completely foreign to her.

账单、预算、职业、晋升和退休储蓄的概念对她来说完全陌生。

Imagine trying to explain the Federal Reserve, credit derivatives, or NAFTA to her. Impossible.

想象一下，向她解释美联储、信贷衍生品或北美自由贸易协定。不可能。

But her world isn’t dark. She does not wander around in confusion.

但她的世界并不黑暗，她也没有迷茫地徘徊。

Even at a year old, she’s written her own internal narrative of how everything works. Blankets keep you warm, mom snuggles keep you safe, and dates taste good.

即使才一岁，她就已经在内心深处写下了关于万物如何运转的叙述。毯子让你温暖，妈妈的依偎让你安全，枣子的味道也很好。

Everything she comes across fits into one of a few dozen mental models she’s learned. When I go to work she doesn’t stop in confusion, wondering what salary and bills are. She has a crystal clear explanation of the situation: Dad isn’t playing with me, and I wanted him to play with me, so I’m sad.

她遇到的每件事都符合她所学的几十种思维模式。我去上班的时候，她不会一头雾水，不知道工资和账单是什么。她对这种情况的解释非常清晰：爸爸不陪我玩，而我想让他陪我玩，所以我很难过。

Even though she knows little, she doesn’t realize it, because she tells herself a coherent story about what’s going on based on the little she does know.

尽管她知道的不多，但她并没有意识到这一点，因为她根据自己所知的一点点事情，给自己讲述了一个连贯的故事。

All of us, no matter our age, do the same thing.

我们所有人，无论年龄大小，都会做同样的事情。

Just like my daughter, I don’t know what I don’t know. So I am just as susceptible to explaining the world through the limited set of mental models I have at my disposal.

就像我女儿一样，我不知道自己不知道什么。所以我很容易用我有限的思维模型来解释这个世界。

Like her, I look for the most understandable causes in everything I come across. And, like her, I’m wrong about a lot of them, because I know a lot less about how the world works than I think I do.

像她一样，我会在遇到的一切事情中寻找最容易理解的原因。而且，和她一样，我对很多事情的理解都是错的，因为我对世界运作方式的了解远比我想象的要少。

This is true for the most fact-based of subjects.

对于大多数基于事实的主题来说，这都是正确的。

Take history. It’s just the recounting of stuff that already happened. It should be clear and objective. But as B. H. Liddell Hart writes in the book Why Don’t We Learn From History?:

以历史为例。它只是对已经发生的事情的叙述。它本应清晰客观。但正如B·H·利德尔·哈特在《我们为何不从历史中吸取教训？》一书中所写：

[History] cannot be interpreted without the aid of imagination and intuition. The sheer quantity of evidence is so overwhelming that selection is inevitable. Where there is selection there is art. Those who read history tend to look for what proves them right and confirms their personal opinions. They defend loyalties. They read with a purpose to affirm or to attack. They resist inconvenient truth since everyone wants to be on the side of the angels. Just as we start wars to end all wars.

解读历史离不开想象力和直觉。证据数量之巨，选择在所难免。有选择，就有艺术。阅读历史的人往往会寻找那些能证明自己正确、佐证个人观点的东西。他们捍卫自己的忠诚。他们阅读的目的是为了肯定或批判。他们抵制难以忽视的真相，因为每个人都想站在天使一边。就像我们发动战争是为了结束所有战争一样。

Daniel Kahneman once told me about the stories people tell themselves to make sense of the past. He said:

丹尼尔·卡尼曼曾经跟我讲过，人们为了理解过去，会自言自语一些故事。他说：

Hindsight, the ability to explain the past, gives us the illusion that the world is understandable. It gives us the illusion that the world makes sense, even when it doesn’t make sense. That’s a big deal in producing mistakes in many fields.

后见之明，即解释过去的能力，让我们产生一种错觉，以为世界是可以理解的。它让我们产生一种错觉，以为世界是合理的，即使它根本不合理。这在很多领域都是导致错误的关键因素。

Most people, when confronted with something they don’t understand, do not realize they don’t understand it because they’re able to come up with an explanation that makes sense based on their own unique perspective and experiences in the world, however limited those experiences are. We all want the complicated world we live in to make sense. So we tell ourselves stories to fill in the gaps of what are effectively blind spots.

大多数人在面对不理解的事物时，并没有意识到自己无法理解，因为他们能够基于自身独特的视角和经验，即便这些经验有限，也能给出合理的解释。我们都希望自己生活的这个复杂世界能够通情达理。因此，我们用故事来填补那些实际上的盲点。

What these stories do to us financially can be both fascinating and terrifying.

这些故事对我们财务的影响既令人着迷又令人恐惧。

When I’m blind to parts of how the world works I might completely misunderstand why the stock market is behaving like it is, in a way that gives me too much confidence in my ability to know what it might do next. Part of the reason forecasting the stock market and the economy is so hard is because you are the only person in the world who thinks the world operates the way you do. When you make decisions for reasons that I can’t even comprehend, I might follow you blindly into a decision that’s right for you and disastrous to me. This, as we saw in chapter 16, is how bubbles form.

当我对世界运作的某些部分视而不见时，我可能会完全误解股市为何如此运作，以至于我对自己预测股市下一步走势的能力过于自信。预测股市和经济如此困难的部分原因在于，你是世界上唯一一个认为世界运作方式与你相同的人。当你出于我无法理解的原因做出决定时，我可能会盲目地跟随你，做出对你有利、对我却灾难性的决定。正如我们在第16章中看到的，这就是泡沫形成的原因。

Coming to terms with how much you don’t know means coming to terms with how much of what happens in the world is out of your control. And that can be hard to accept.

接受自己未知的事物，意味着接受世界上发生的很多事情都超出了你的掌控。这或许很难接受。

Think about market forecasts. We’re very, very bad at them. I once calculated that if you just assume that the market goes up every year by its historic average, your accuracy is better than if you follow the average annual forecasts of the top 20 market strategists from large Wall Street banks. Our ability to predict recessions isn’t much better. And since big events come out of nowhere, forecasts may do more harm than good, giving the illusion of predictability in a world where unforeseen events control most outcomes. Carl Richards writes: “Risk is what’s left over when you think you’ve thought of everything.”

想想市场预测。我们在这方面非常非常糟糕。我曾经计算过，如果你仅仅假设市场每年都会按照历史平均水平上涨，那么你的准确率会比遵循华尔街大型银行前20名市场策略师的平均年度预测要高得多。我们预测经济衰退的能力也好不到哪里去。而且，由于重大事件突如其来，预测可能弊大于利，在一个不可预见事件控制着大多数结果的世界里，预测可能会给人一种可预测的错觉。卡尔·理查兹写道：“当你自以为已经考虑到了一切时，剩下的就是风险。”

People know this. I have not met an investor who genuinely thinks market forecasts as a whole are accurate or useful. But there’s still tremendous demand for forecasts, in both the media and from financial advisors.

人们都知道这一点。我还没遇到过哪个投资者真心认为市场预测总体上是准确或有用的。但媒体和财务顾问对预测的需求仍然巨大。

Why?

为什么？

Psychologist Philip Tetlock once wrote: “We need to believe we live in a predictable, controllable world, so we turn to authoritative-sounding people who promise to satisfy that need.”

心理学家菲利普·泰特洛克曾经写道：“我们需要相信我们生活在一个可预测、可控制的世界，所以我们会向那些承诺满足这种需求的权威人士求助。”

Satisfying that need is a great way to put it. Wanting to believe we are in control is an emotional itch that needs to be scratched, rather than an analytical problem to be calculated and solved. The illusion of control is more persuasive than the reality of uncertainty. So we cling to stories about outcomes being in our control.

满足这种需求是很好的表达方式。想要相信自己掌控一切，是一种需要搔痒的情感需求，而不是一个需要计算和解决的分析性问题。掌控的幻觉比不确定性的现实更有说服力。所以我们执着于相信结果尽在掌握的故事。

Part of this has to do with confusing fields of precision with fields of uncertainty.

部分原因在于混淆了精确领域和不确定性领域。

NASA’s New Horizons spacecraft passed by Pluto two years ago. It was a three-billion mile trip that took nine and a half years. According to NASA, the trip “took about one minute less than predicted when the craft was launched in January 2006.”⁶⁸

美国宇航局的新视野号宇宙飞船两年前飞越了冥王星。这段旅程长达30亿英里，耗时九年半。据美国宇航局称，这次旅程“比2006年1月发射时预计的时间少了大约一分钟”。⁶⁸

Think about that. In an untested, decade-long journey, NASA’s forecast was 99.99998% accurate. That’s like forecasting a trip from New York to Boston and being accurate to within four millionths of a second.

想想看。在一场未经测试的长达十年的旅程中，NASA 的预测准确率高达 99.99998%。这就像预测从纽约到波士顿的旅程，准确率在百万分之四秒以内。

But astrophysics is a field of precession. It isn’t impacted by the vagaries of human behavior and emotions, like finance is. Business, economics, and investing, are fields of uncertainty, overwhelmingly driven by decisions that can’t easily be explained with clean formulas, like a trip to Pluto can. But we desperately want it to be like a trip to Pluto, because the idea of a NASA engineer being in 99.99998% control of an outcome is beautiful and comforting. It’s so comforting that we’re tempted to tell ourselves stories about how much control we have in other parts of our life, like money.

但天体物理学是一个进动领域。它不像金融那样受人类行为和情绪变化的影响。商业、经济和投资都是充满不确定性的领域，绝大多数是由那些无法用清晰公式解释的决策驱动的，就像去冥王星旅行一样。但我们迫切希望它能像去冥王星旅行一样，因为NASA工程师对结果拥有99.99998%的控制权，这个想法既美好又令人欣慰。这种欣慰感让我们忍不住给自己编造一些故事，讲述我们在生活其他方面，比如金钱方面，拥有多么强大的掌控力。

Kahneman once laid out the path these stories take:

卡尼曼曾经描绘过这些故事的发展路径：

When planning we focus on what we want to do and can do, neglecting the plans and skills of others whose decisions might affect our outcomes.

在制定计划时，我们关注的是自己想要做什么和能够做什么，而忽略了其他人的计划和技能，因为他们的决定可能会影响我们的结果。

Both in explaining the past and in predicting the future, we focus on the causal role of skill and neglect the role of luck.

无论是解释过去还是预测未来，我们都注重技能的因果作用而忽视运气的作用。

We focus on what we know and neglect what we do not know, which makes us overly confident in our beliefs.

我们专注于已知的事物而忽略未知的事物，这使得我们对自己的信念过于自信。

He described how this impacts businesses:

他描述了这对企业的影响：

I have had several occasions to ask founders and participants in innovative start-ups a question: To what extent will the outcome of your effort depend on what you do in your firm? This is evidently an easy question; the answer comes quickly and it has never been less than 80%. Even when they are not sure they will succeed, these bold people think their fate is almost entirely in their own hands. They are surely wrong: the outcome of a start-up depends as much on the achievements of its competitors and on changes in the market as on its own efforts. However, entrepreneurs naturally focus on what they know best—their plans and actions and the most immediate threats and opportunities, such as the availability of funding. They know less about their competitors and therefore find it natural to imagine a future in which the competition plays little part.

我曾多次向创新型初创企业的创始人和参与者提出一个问题：你们努力的结果在多大程度上取决于你们在公司所做的事情？这显然是一个简单的问题；答案很快就能出来，而且从来没有低于 80%。即使在不确定自己能否成功时，这些大胆的人也认为他们的命运几乎完全掌握在自己手中。他们肯定错了：初创企业的结果不仅取决于自身的努力，也取决于竞争对手的成就和市场变化。然而，企业家自然会专注于他们最了解的领域——他们的计划和行动以及最直接的威胁和机遇，例如资金的可用性。他们对竞争对手了解较少，因此很自然地会想象一个竞争几乎不起作用的未来。

We all do this to some extent.

在某种程度上，我们都这样做。

And like my daughter, it doesn’t bother us a bit.

就像我的女儿一样，这并没有给我们带来任何困扰。

We don’t wander around blind and confused. We have to think the world we operate in makes sense based on what we happen to know. It’d be too hard to get out of bed in the morning if you felt otherwise.

我们不会盲目迷茫地四处游荡。我们必须根据我们已知的知识，去思考我们所处的世界是否合理。如果你不这么认为，早上起床就会很困难。

But the alien circling over Earth?

但是外星人在地球上空盘旋吗？

The one who’s confident he knows what’s happening based on what he sees but turns out to be completely wrong because he can’t know the stories going on inside everyone else’s head?

那个人自信地根据他所看到的知道正在发生的事情，但结果却完全错了，因为他无法知道其他人脑子里正在发生的故事？

He’s all of us.

他就是我们所有人。

#↩

#↩

Congratulations, you’re still reading.

恭喜，您仍在阅读。

It’s time to tie together a few things we’ve learned.

现在是时候把我们学到的一些东西整合在一起了。

This chapter is a bit of a summary; a few short and actionable lessons that can help you make better financial decisions.

本章是一个总结；一些简短且可操作的课程可以帮助您做出更好的财务决策。

First, let me tell you a story about a dentist appointment gone horribly awry. It teaches us something vital about the dangers of giving advice about what to do with your money.

首先，我想给你讲一个关于牙医预约出问题的糟糕故事。这个故事让我们深刻认识到，在金钱问题上给出建议是多么危险。

Clarence Hughes went to the dentist in 1931. His mouth was radiating pain. His dentist put him under crude anesthesia to ease the pain. When Clarence awoke hours later he had 16 fewer teeth and his tonsils removed.

1931年，克拉伦斯·休斯去看牙医。他的口腔疼痛难忍。牙医给他注射了简易麻醉剂来缓解疼痛。几个小时后，克拉伦斯醒来时，他的牙齿少了16颗，扁桃体也被切除了。

And then everything went wrong. Clarence died a week later from his surgery’s complications.

然后一切都出错了。克拉伦斯一周后因手术并发症去世。

His wife sued the dentist, but not because the surgery went awry. Every surgery risked death in 1931.

他的妻子起诉了牙医，但并非因为手术出了问题。1931年，每次手术都可能带来生命危险。

Clarence, she said, never consented to the procedures in the first place, and wouldn’t if he were asked.

她说，克拉伦斯从一开始就不同意接受这些手术，即使被问到他也不会答应。

The case wove through courts, but went nowhere. Consent between doctor and patient wasn’t black and white in 1931. One court summed up the idea that doctors require freedom to make the best medical decisions: “Without such, we could not enjoy the advancement of science.”

此案辗转各大法院，却毫无进展。1931年，医患之间的知情同意并非黑白分明。一家法院总结了医生需要自由做出最佳医疗决策的观点：“没有这样的自由，我们就无法享受科学的进步。”

For most of history the ethos of medicine was that the doctor’s job was to fix the patient, and what the patient thought about the doctor’s treatment plans wasn’t relevant. Dr. Jay Katz wrote about the philosophy in his book The Silent World Between Doctor and Patient:

在医学史上的大部分时间里，医生的职责是治愈病人，病人对医生治疗方案的看法无关紧要。杰伊·卡茨医生在他的著作《医患之间的沉默世界》中阐述了这一理念：

Doctors felt that in order to accomplish that objective they were obligated to attend to their patients’ physical and emotional needs and to do so on their own authority, without consulting with their patients about the decisions that needed to be made. The idea that patients may also be entitled to sharing the burdens of decisions with their doctors was never part of the ethos of medicine.

医生们认为，为了实现这一目标，他们有义务照顾病人的生理和情感需求，并且必须自行决定，无需与病人商量。而病人也有权与医生分担决策负担，这种想法从来就不符合医学精神。

This wasn’t ego or malice. It was a belief in two points:

这不是出于自负或恶意。这是基于两点信念：

Every patient wants to be cured.

每个病人都希望自己能够被治愈。

There is a universal and right way to cure them.

有一种通用且正确的方法来治疗这些疾病。

Not requiring patient consent in treatment plans makes sense if you believe in those two points.

如果您相信这两点，那么在治疗计划中不要求患者同意就是有道理的。

But that’s not how medicine works.

但医学并不是这样运作的。

In the last 50 years medical schools subtly shifted teaching away from treating disease and toward treating patients. That meant laying out the options of treatment plans, and then letting the patient decide the best path forward.

过去50年，医学院的教学模式悄然从治疗疾病转向治疗患者。这意味着要列出各种治疗方案，然后让患者自己决定最佳的治疗方案。

This trend was partly driven by patient-protection laws, partly by Katz’s influential book, which argued that patients have wildly different views about what’s worth it in medicine, so their beliefs have to be taken into consideration. Katz wrote:

这一趋势部分源于患者保护法，部分源于卡茨那本影响深远的著作。该书认为，患者对于医学的价值持有截然不同的看法，因此必须考虑他们的信念。卡茨写道：

It is dangerous nonsense to assert that in the practice of their art and science physicians can rely on their benevolent intentions, their abilities to judge what is the right thing to do ... It is not that easy. Medicine is a complex profession and the interactions between physicians and patients are also complex.

声称医生在实践其医术和科学时可以依靠仁慈的意图和判断正确做法的能力，这纯属危险的胡言乱语……事情并非如此简单。医学是一个复杂的职业，医生与患者之间的互动同样复杂。

That last line is important. “Medicine is a complex profession and the interactions between physicians and patients are also complex.”

最后一句很重要。“医学是一个复杂的职业，医生和病人之间的互动也很复杂。”

You know what profession is the same? Financial advice.

你知道什么职业也一样吗？财务顾问。

I can’t tell you what to do with your money, because I don’t know you.

我不能告诉你如何处理你的钱，因为我不认识你。

I don’t know what you want. I don’t know when you want it. I don’t know why you want it.

我不知道你想要什么。我不知道你什么时候想要它。我不知道你为什么想要它。

So I’m not going to tell you what to do with your money. I don’t want to treat you like a dentist treated Clarence Hughes.

所以我不会告诉你该怎么处理你的钱。我不想像牙医对待克拉伦斯·休斯那样对待你。

But doctors and dentists aren’t useless, obviously. They have knowledge. They know the odds. They know what tends to work, even if patients come to different conclusions about what kind of treatment is right for them.

但医生和牙医显然并非一无是处。他们拥有知识，他们知道胜算，他们知道什么方法往往有效，即使患者对于哪种治疗方法最适合自己得出了不同的结论。

Financial advisors are the same. There are universal truths in money, even if people come to different conclusions about how they want to apply those truths to their own finances.

财务顾问也是如此。金钱方面存在着普遍的真理，即使人们对如何将这些真理应用于自身财务得出不同的结论。

With that caveat in place, let’s look at a few short recommendations that can help you make better decisions with your money.

有了这个警告，让我们来看看一些简短的建议，它们可以帮助您更好地管理您的资金。

Go out of your way to find humility when things are going right and forgiveness/compassion when they go wrong. Because it’s never as good or as bad as it looks. The world is big and complex. Luck and risk are both real and hard to identify. Do so when judging both yourself and others. Respect the power of luck and risk and you’ll have a better chance of focusing on things you can actually control. You’ll also have a better chance of finding the right role models.

当事情进展顺利时，要努力保持谦逊；当事情进展不顺时，要努力寻求宽恕/同情。因为事情远没有表面看起来那么好或那么坏。世界广阔而复杂。运气和风险都真实存在，却又难以区分。在评判自己和他人时，要做到这一点。尊重运气和风险的力量，你才能更好地专注于自己真正能够掌控的事情。你也更有可能找到合适的榜样。

Less ego, more wealth. Saving money is the gap between your ego and your income, and wealth is what you don’t see. So wealth is created by suppressing what you could buy today in order to have more stuff or more options in the future. No matter how much you earn, you will never build wealth unless you can put a lid on how much fun you can have with your money right now, today.

少一点自负，多一点财富。省钱是你的自负和收入之间的差距，而财富是你看不见的。所以，财富的创造是通过抑制你今天可以买的东西，以便在未来拥有更多的东西或更多的选择。无论你赚多少钱，除非你能限制你现在用钱玩得有多开心，否则你永远都无法积累财富。

Manage your money in a way that helps you sleep at night. That’s different from saying you should aim to earn the highest returns or save a specific percentage of your income. Some people won’t sleep well unless they’re earning the highest returns; others will only get a good rest if they’re conservatively invested. To each their own. But the foundation of, “does this help me sleep at night?” is the best universal guidepost for all financial decisions.

用一种能让你晚上睡得着觉的方式管理你的资金。这不同于说你应该追求最高的回报，或者把收入的一定比例存起来。有些人除非获得最高的回报，否则睡不好觉；而有些人只有保守投资才能好好休息。每个人都有自己的方法。但“这能让我晚上睡得着觉吗？”这个问题，才是所有财务决策的最佳通用指南。

If you want to do better as an investor, the single most powerful thing you can do is increase your time horizon. Time is the most powerful force in investing. It makes little things grow big and big mistakes fade away. It can’t neutralize luck and risk, but it pushes results closer towards what people deserve.

如果你想成为一名更优秀的投资者，你能做的最有力的事情就是延长你的投资期限。时间是投资中最强大的力量。它能让小事成就大事，也能让大错误逐渐消失。它无法抵消运气和风险，但它能让结果更接近人们应得的回报。

Become OK with a lot of things going wrong. You can be wrong half the time and still make a fortune, because a small minority of things account for the majority of outcomes. No matter what you’re doing with your money you should be comfortable with a lot of stuff not working. That’s just how the world is. So you should always measure how you’ve done by looking at your full portfolio, rather than individual investments. It is fine to have a large chunk of poor investments and a few outstanding ones. That’s usually the best-case scenario. Judging how you’ve done by focusing on individual investments makes winners look more brilliant than they were, and losers appear more regrettable than they should.

接受很多事情出错。你可能一半的时间都错了，但仍然能赚大钱，因为少数因素决定了大多数结果。无论你如何运用你的资金，你都应该坦然接受很多事情不顺利。世界就是这样。所以，你应该始终通过观察你的整个投资组合，而不是单个投资来衡量你的表现。拥有大量糟糕的投资和少数优秀的投资是可以的。这通常是最好的情况。仅仅关注单个投资来判断你的表现，会让赢家看起来比他们实际表现更出色，而输家看起来比他们实际表现更令人遗憾。

Use money to gain control over your time, because not having control of your time is such a powerful and universal drag on happiness. The ability to do what you want, when you want, with who you want, for as long as you want to, pays the highest dividend that exists in finance.

用金钱来掌控你的时间，因为无法掌控时间是阻碍幸福感的普遍而强大的因素。能够随时随地、随心所欲地做你想做的事，与你想做的人一起，想做多久就做多久，这才是财务上最高的回报。

Be nicer and less flashy. No one is impressed with your possessions as much as you are. You might think you want a fancy car or a nice watch. But what you probably want is respect and admiration. And you’re more likely to gain those things through kindness and humility than horsepower and chrome.

待人友善，少一些浮夸。没有人比你更欣赏你的财产。你可能想拥有一辆豪车或一块名表。但你真正想要的可能是尊重和钦佩。而善良和谦逊比马力和镀铬更容易让你获得这些东西。

Save. Just save. You don’t need a specific reason to save. It’s great to save for a car, or a downpayment, or a medical emergency. But saving for things that are impossible to predict or define is one of the best reasons to save. Everyone’s life is a continuous chain of surprises. Savings that aren’t earmarked for anything in particular is a hedge against life’s inevitable ability to surprise the hell out of you at the worst possible moment.

存钱，存就存。存钱不需要特别的理由。为了买车、付首付或应对医疗紧急情况而存钱固然很好，但为那些无法预测或定义的事情存钱才是存钱的最佳理由之一。每个人的生活都充满了惊喜。不为任何特定目的而储蓄，可以有效规避生活中不可避免的意外，避免在最糟糕的时刻给你带来意外。

Define the cost of success and be ready to pay it. Because nothing worthwhile is free. And remember that most financial costs don’t have visible price tags. Uncertainty, doubt, and regret are common costs in the finance world. They’re often worth paying. But you have to view them as fees (a price worth paying to get something nice in exchange) rather than fines (a penalty you should avoid).

明确成功的成本，并做好付出的准备。因为任何有价值的东西都不是免费的。记住，大多数财务成本都是看不见的。不确定性、怀疑和后悔是金融界常见的成本。它们通常值得付出。但你必须把它们视为费用（为了获得一些好处而值得付出的代价），而不是罚款（你应该避免的惩罚）。

Worship room for error. A gap between what could happen in the future and what you need to happen in the future in order to do well is what gives you endurance, and endurance is what makes compounding magic over time. Room for error often looks like a conservative hedge, but if it keeps you in the game it can pay for itself many times over.

尊重容错空间。未来可能发生的情况与你为了做好未来需要发生的情况之间的差距，正是赋予你忍耐力的因素，而忍耐力正是随着时间的推移产生复利魔力的因素。容错空间通常看起来像是一种保守的对冲策略，但如果它能让你坚持下去，它就能带来数倍的回报。

Avoid the extreme ends of financial decisions. Everyone’s goals and desires will change over time, and the more extreme your past decisions were the more you may regret them as you evolve.

避免财务决策走极端。每个人的目标和愿望都会随着时间而改变，你过去的决定越极端，随着你的成长，你可能会越后悔。

You should like risk because it pays off over time. But you should be paranoid of ruinous risk because it prevents you from taking future risks that will pay off over time.

你应该喜欢风险，因为随着时间的推移，它会带来回报。但你应该对毁灭性的风险保持警惕，因为它会阻止你承担未来会有回报的风险。

Define the game you’re playing, and make sure your actions are not being influenced by people playing a different game.

定义您正在玩的游戏，并确保您的行为不会受到玩其他游戏的人的影响。

Respect the mess. Smart, informed, and reasonable people can disagree in finance, because people have vastly different goals and desires. There is no single right answer; just the answer that works for you.

尊重混乱。聪明、见多识广、通情达理的人在财务方面可能会有分歧，因为人们的目标和愿望千差万别。没有唯一正确的答案；只有适合你的答案。

Now let me tell you what works for me.

现在让我告诉你什么对我有用。

#↩

#↩

Sandy Gottesman, a billionaire investor who founded the consulting group First Manhattan, is said to ask one question when interviewing candidates for his investment team: “What do you own, and why?”

咨询集团第一曼哈顿 (First Manhattan) 的创始人、亿万富翁投资者桑迪·戈特斯曼 (Sandy Gottesman) 据说在面试其投资团队候选人时会问一个问题：“你拥有什么？为什么拥有？”

Not, “What stocks do you think are cheap?” or “What economy is about to have a recession?”

而不是“你认为哪些股票便宜？”或者“哪个经济体即将陷入衰退？”

Just show me what you do with your own money.

只要告诉我你用自己的钱做了什么。

I love this question because it highlights what can often be a mile-wide gap between what makes sense—which is what people suggest you do—and what feels right to them—which is what they actually do.

我喜欢这个问题，因为它强调了有意义的事情（人们建议你做的事情）和他们认为正确的事情（他们实际做的事情）之间往往存在的巨大差距。

Half of all U.S. mutual fund portfolio managers do not invest a cent of their own money in their funds, according to Morningstar.⁶⁹ This might seem atrocious, and surely the statistic uncovers some hypocrisy.

据晨星公司称，一半的美国共同基金投资组合经理没有在他们的基金中投资一分钱。⁶⁹这看起来可能很残酷，而且统计数据肯定揭露了一些虚伪。

But this kind of stuff is more common than you’d think. Ken Murray, a professor of medicine at USC, wrote an essay in 2011 titled “How Doctors Die” that showed the degree to which doctors choose different end-of-life treatments for themselves than they recommend for their patients.⁷⁰

但这种事比你想象的更常见。南加州大学医学教授肯·默里在2011年发表了一篇题为《医生如何死亡》的文章，指出医生为自己选择的临终治疗方案与为患者推荐的方案存在很大差异。⁷⁰

“[Doctors] don’t die like the rest of us,” he wrote. “What’s unusual about them is not how much treatment they get compared to most Americans, but how little. For all the time they spend fending off the deaths of others, they tend to be fairly serene when faced with death themselves. They know exactly what is going to happen, they know the choices, and they generally have access to any sort of medical care they could want. But they go gently.” A doctor may throw the kitchen sink at her patient’s cancer, but choose palliative care for herself.

“（医生）的死亡和我们其他人不一样，”他写道。“他们的不同寻常之处不在于与大多数美国人相比，他们接受的治疗有多少，而在于他们接受的治疗多么少。尽管他们一直在与他人的死亡抗争，但在面对死亡时，他们往往相当平静。他们清楚地知道会发生什么，他们知道有哪些选择，而且通常可以获得任何他们想要的医疗服务。但他们选择的是温和的方式。” 医生可能会竭尽全力治疗癌症患者，但为自己选择姑息治疗。

The difference between what someone suggests you do and what they do for themselves isn’t always a bad thing. It just underscores that when dealing with complicated and emotional issues that affect you and your family, there is no one right answer. There is no universal truth. There’s only what works for you and your family, checking the boxes you want checked in a way that leaves you comfortable and sleeping well at night.

别人建议你做的事情和他们自己做的事情之间的差异并不总是坏事。这恰恰强调了，在处理影响你和你家人的复杂情感问题时，没有唯一的正确答案。没有放之四海而皆准的真理。只有适合你和你家人的方法，用一种让你感到舒适、晚上睡得安稳的方式，去完成你想做的事情。

There are basic principles that must be adhered to—this is true in finance and in medicine—but important financial decisions are not made in spreadsheets or in textbooks. They are made at the dinner table. They often aren’t made with the intention of maximizing returns, but minimizing the chance of disappointing a spouse or child. Those kinds of things are difficult to summarize in charts or formulas, and they vary widely from person to person. What works for one person may not work for another.

有一些基本原则必须遵守——金融和医学领域都是如此——但重要的财务决策并非在电子表格或教科书中做出，而是在餐桌上做出的。这些决策通常并非为了最大化收益，而是为了最大限度地减少让配偶或孩子失望的可能性。这类事情很难用图表或公式来概括，而且因人而异。对一个人有效的方法可能对另一个人无效。

You have to find what works for you. Here’s what works for me.

你必须找到适合自己的方法。以下是对我有用的方法。

How my family thinks about savings

我家人对储蓄的看法

Charlie Munger once said “I did not intend to get rich. I just wanted to get independent.”

查理·芒格曾经说过：“我并没有想过要致富，我只是想独立。”

We can leave aside rich, but independence has always been my personal financial goal. Chasing the highest returns or leveraging my assets to live the most luxurious life has little interest to me. Both look like games people do to impress their friends, and both have hidden risks. I mostly just want to wake up every day knowing my family and I can do whatever we want to do on our own terms. Every financial decision we make revolves around that goal.

我们可以把富裕抛在一边，但独立一直是我的个人财务目标。追求最高回报或利用我的资产过上最奢华的生活对我来说没什么吸引力。两者都像是人们为了炫耀朋友而玩的游戏，而且都隐藏着风险。我主要只想每天醒来，知道我和我的家人可以按照自己的意愿做任何我们想做的事情。我们做的每一个财务决策都围绕着这个目标。

My parents lived their adult years in two stages: dirt poor and moderately well off. My father became a doctor when he was 40 and already had three kids. Earning a doctor’s salary did not offset the frugal mentality that is forced when supporting three hungry kids while in medical school, and my parents spent the good years living well below their means with a high savings rate. This gave them a degree of independence. My father was an Emergency Room doctor, one of the highest-stress professions I can imagine and one that requires a painful toggling of circadian rhythms between night and day shifts. After two decades he decided he’d had enough, so he stopped. Just quit. Moved onto the next phase of his life.

我的父母成年后经历了两个阶段：一贫如洗和略有起色。我父亲40岁时才成为一名医生，那时他已经有三个孩子了。医生的薪水并不能抵消他们在医学院读书期间为了养活三个饥饿的孩子而被迫节俭的心态。我的父母在人生的黄金岁月里，生活水平远低于他们的收入水平，储蓄率很高。这让他们获得了一定程度的独立。我父亲是一名急诊室医生，这是我能想象到的压力最大的职业之一，需要在夜班和白班之间痛苦地切换昼夜节律。二十年后，他决定受够了，于是他停了下来。干脆辞职，开启人生的下一个阶段。

That stuck with me. Being able to wake up one morning and change what you’re doing, on your own terms, whenever you’re ready, seems like the grandmother of all financial goals. Independence, to me, doesn’t mean you’ll stop working. It means you only do the work you like with people you like at the times you want for as long as you want.

这句话让我印象深刻。能够在某天早上醒来，按照自己的意愿，在准备好的时候改变自己正在做的事情，这似乎是所有财务目标中最伟大的。对我来说，独立并不意味着停止工作。它意味着你只在你喜欢的时间，和你喜欢的人，做你喜欢的工作，想做多久就做多久。

And achieving some level of independence does not rely on earning a doctor’s income. It’s mostly a matter of keeping your expectations in check and living below your means. Independence, at any income level, is driven by your savings rate. And past a certain level of income your savings rate is driven by your ability to keep your lifestyle expectations from running away.

实现一定程度的独立并不依赖于赚取医生那样的收入。这主要取决于控制你的期望值，量入为出。无论收入水平如何，独立都取决于你的储蓄率。而超过一定的收入水平后，你的储蓄率则取决于你能否控制住你的生活方式预期，避免失控。

My wife and I met in college and moved in with each other years before we got married. After school we both had entry-level jobs with entry-level pay, and settled into a moderate lifestyle. All lifestyles exist on a spectrum, and what is decent to one person can feel like royalty or poverty to another. But at our incomes we got what we considered a decent apartment, a decent car, decent clothes, decent food. Comfortable, but nothing close to fancy.

我和妻子大学相识，结婚前几年就同居了。毕业后，我们都从事着入门级的工作，薪水也只是入门级，过着中规中矩的生活。所有生活方式都各有不同，对一个人来说体面的生活，对另一个人来说可能像贵族，也可能像贫困。但以我们的收入水平，我们拥有一套称心如意的公寓、一辆不错的车、体面的衣服和美味的食物。虽然舒适，但谈不上奢华。

Despite more than a decade of rising incomes—myself in finance, my wife in health care—we’ve more or less stayed at that lifestyle ever since. That’s pushed our savings rate continuously higher. Virtually every dollar of raise has accrued to savings—our “independence fund.” We now live considerably below our means, which tells you little about our income and more about our decision to maintain a lifestyle that we established in our 20s.

尽管十多年来收入不断增长——我自己从事金融行业，妻子从事医疗保健行业——但我们此后基本一直保持着那种生活方式。这推高了我们的储蓄率。几乎每一分钱的增加都存进了储蓄账户——我们的“独立基金”。我们现在的生活水平远低于自己的收入，这与其说是我们的“收入”，不如说是我们决定维持20多岁时确立的生活方式。

If there’s a part of our household financial plan I’m proud of it’s that we got the goalpost of lifestyle desires to stop moving at a young age. Our savings rate is fairly high, but we rarely feel like we’re repressively frugal because our aspirations for more stuff haven’t moved much. It’s not that our aspirations are nonexistent—we like nice stuff and live comfortably. We just got the goalpost to stop moving.

如果说我们家庭财务计划中有什么让我感到自豪的地方，那就是我们在年轻时就设定了生活方式的“目标”，让我们不再动摇。我们的储蓄率相当高，但我们很少觉得自己过着压抑的节俭生活，因为我们对更多物质的渴望并没有太大改变。这并不是说我们的渴望不存在——我们喜欢好东西，生活舒适。我们只是设定了目标，让我们不再动摇。

This would not work for everyone, and it only works for us because we both agree to it equally—neither of us are compromising for the other. Most of what we get pleasure from—going for walks, reading, podcasts—costs little, so we rarely feel like we’re missing out. On the rare occasion when I question our savings rate I think of the independence my parents earned from years of high savings, and I quickly come back. Independence is our top goal. A secondary benefit of maintaining a lifestyle below what you can afford is avoiding the psychological treadmill of keeping up with the Joneses. Comfortably living below what you can afford, without much desire for more, removes a tremendous amount of social pressure that many people in the modern first world subject themselves to. Nassim Taleb explained: “True success is exiting some rat race to modulate one’s activities for peace of mind.” I like that.

这并不适用于所有人，而它只适用于我们，因为我们双方都平等地同意这一点——我们都没有为对方妥协。我们从中获得乐趣的大部分事情——散步、阅读、播客——花费不多，所以我们很少觉得自己错过了什么。在我偶尔质疑我们的储蓄率时，我会想到父母多年的高额储蓄所获得的独立，我很快就会回过神来。独立是我们最重要的目标。维持低于自身承受能力的生活方式的第二个好处是避免了与邻居攀比的心理压力。舒适地生活在低于自身承受能力的水平，而没有太多的渴望，可以消除许多现代第一世界的人所承受的巨大社会压力。纳西姆·塔勒布解释说：“真正的成功是退出激烈的竞争，调整自己的活动以获得内心的平静。”我喜欢这句话。

We’re so far committed to the independence camp that we’ve done things that make little sense on paper. We own our house without a mortgage, which is the worst financial decision we’ve ever made but the best money decision we’ve ever made. Mortgage interest rates were absurdly low when we bought our house. Any rational advisor would recommend taking advantage of cheap money and investing extra savings in higher-return assets, like stocks. But our goal isn’t to be coldly rational; just psychologically reasonable.

到目前为止，我们一直坚守独立阵营，以至于我们做的事情在纸面上看起来毫无意义。我们拥有自己的房子，却没有抵押贷款，这是我们做过的最糟糕的财务决定，但却是我们做过的最好的理财决定。我们买房的时候，抵押贷款利率低得离谱。任何理性的顾问都会建议利用廉价资金，把多余的积蓄投资于股票等高回报资产。但我们的目标不是冷酷理性，而是心理上的理性。

The independent feeling I get from owning our house outright far exceeds the known financial gain I’d get from leveraging our assets with a cheap mortgage. Eliminating the monthly payment feels better than maximizing the long-term value of our assets. It makes me feel independent.

完全拥有自己的房子给我带来的独立感，远远超过了用低息抵押贷款来杠杆化资产所带来的经济收益。省去每月还款的痛苦，比最大化资产的长期价值更让人感到安心。这让我感到自己独立了。

I don’t try to defend this decision to those pointing out its flaws, or those who would never do the same. On paper it’s defenseless. But it works for us. We like it. That’s what matters. Good decisions aren’t always rational. At some point you have to choose between being happy or being “right.”

我不会试图为这个决定辩护，也不会向那些指出它缺陷的人，或者那些永远不会这么做的人辩护。理论上，它毫无根据。但它对我们有用。我们喜欢它。这才是最重要的。好的决定并不总是理性的。在某些时候，你必须在快乐和“正确”之间做出选择。

We also keep a higher percentage of our assets in cash than most financial advisors would recommend—something around 20% of our assets outside the value of our house. This is also close to indefensible on paper, and I’m not recommending it to others. It’s just what works for us.

我们持有的现金资产比例也比大多数理财顾问建议的要高——大约占房屋价值以外资产的20%。从理论上讲，这几乎站不住脚，我也不会推荐给其他人。这只是我们自己觉得有效的做法。

We do it because cash is the oxygen of independence, and—more importantly—we never want to be forced to sell the stocks we own. We want the probability of facing a huge expense and needing to liquidate stocks to cover it to be as close to zero as possible. Perhaps we just have a lower risk tolerance than others.

我们这样做是因为现金是维持独立的氧气，更重要的是，我们永远不想被迫出售持有的股票。我们希望面临巨额支出并需要清算股票来弥补损失的可能性尽可能接近于零。或许我们只是比其他人更能承受风险而已。

But everything I’ve learned about personal finance tells me that everyone—without exception—will eventually face a huge expense they did not expect—and they don’t plan for these expenses specifically because they did not expect them. The few people who know the details of our finances ask, “What are you saving for? A house? A boat? A new car?” No, none of those. I’m saving for a world where curveballs are more common than we expect. Not being forced to sell stocks to cover an expense also means we’re increasing the odds of letting the stocks we own compound for the longest period of time. Charlie Munger put it well: “The first rule of compounding is to never interrupt it unnecessarily.”

但我所学到的个人理财知识告诉我，每个人——无一例外——最终都会面临一笔意料之外的巨额开支——而他们之所以没有专门为这些开支做计划，并不是因为他们没有预料到。少数了解我们财务状况的人会问：“你存钱是为了什么？房子？船？还是新车？”不，这些都不是。我是为了一个比我们预期更可能出现意外的世界而存钱。不必被迫出售股票来弥补开支，也意味着我们增加了让持有的股票在最长时间内获得复利的几率。查理·芒格说得好：“复利的第一条规则是，永远不要无缘无故地打断它。”

How my family thinks about investing

我的家人如何看待投资

I started my career as a stock picker. At the time we only owned individual stocks, mostly large companies like Berkshire Hathaway and Procter & Gamble, mixed with smaller stocks I considered deep value investments. Go back to my 20s and at any given point I held something like 25 individual stocks.

我的职业生涯始于选股。当时我们只持有个股，主要是像伯克希尔·哈撒韦和宝洁这样的大公司，也有一些我认为是深度价值投资的小盘股。回想我20多岁的时候，我几乎每个月都会持有25只左右的股票。

I don’t know how I did as a stock picker. Did I beat the market? I’m not sure. Like most who try, I didn’t keep a good score. Either way, I’ve shifted my views and now every stock we own is a low-cost index fund.

我不知道自己选股做得怎么样。我跑赢了市场吗？我不确定。和大多数尝试的人一样，我的得分并不高。不管怎样，我已经改变了看法，现在我们持有的每一只股票都成了低成本的指数基金。

I don’t have anything against actively picking stocks, either on your own or through giving your money to an active fund manager. I think some people can outperform the market averages—it’s just very hard, and harder than most people think.

我并不反对主动选股，无论是自己动手还是把钱交给主动型基金经理。我认为有些人可以跑赢市场平均水平——只是很难，而且比大多数人想象的要难。

If I had to summarize my views on investing, it’s this: Every investor should pick a strategy that has the highest odds of successfully meeting their goals. And I think for most investors, dollar-cost averaging into a low-cost index fund will provide the highest odds of long-term success.

如果要我总结一下我的投资观点，那就是：每个投资者都应该选择最有可能实现目标的策略。我认为，对于大多数投资者来说，采用平均成本法投资于低成本指数基金，将获得最高的长期成功几率。

That doesn’t mean index investing will always work. It doesn’t mean it’s for everyone. And it doesn’t mean active stock picking is doomed to fail. In general, this industry has become too entrenched on one side or the other—particularly those vehemently against active investing.

这并不意味着指数投资永远有效，也不意味着它适合所有人，更不意味着主动选股注定失败。总的来说，这个行业已经变得过于根深蒂固，倾向于某一方——尤其是那些强烈反对主动投资的人。

Beating the market should be hard; the odds of success should be low. If they weren’t, everyone would do it, and if everyone did it there would be no opportunity. So no one should be surprised that the majority of those trying to beat the market fail to do so. (The statistics show 85% of large-cap active managers didn’t beat the S&P 500 over the decade ending 2019.)⁷¹

战胜市场本应很难；成功的几率应该很低。如果不是这样，每个人都会这么做，而如果每个人都这么做，那就没有机会了。所以，大多数试图战胜市场的人都失败了，这并不奇怪。（统计数据显示，截至2019年的十年间，85%的大盘主动型基金经理的业绩未能跑赢标准普尔500指数。）⁷¹

I know people who think it’s insane to try to beat the market but encourage their kids to reach for the stars and try to become professional athletes. To each their own. Life is about playing the odds, and we all think about odds a little differently.

我认识一些人，他们觉得试图战胜市场是疯狂的，但却鼓励自己的孩子追求卓越，努力成为职业运动员。每个人都有自己的想法。人生就是在玩概率游戏，而我们每个人对概率的看法都略有不同。

Over the years I came around to the view that we’ll have a high chance of meeting all of our family’s financial goals if we consistently invest money into a low-cost index fund for decades on end, leaving the money alone to compound. A lot of this view comes from our lifestyle of frugal spending. If you can meet all your goals without having to take the added risk that comes from trying to outperform the market, then what’s the point of even trying? I can afford to not be the greatest investor in the world, but I can’t afford to be a bad one. When I think of it that way, the choice to buy the index and hold on is a no-brainer for us. I know not everyone will agree with that logic, especially my friends whose job it is to beat the market. I respect what they do. But this is what works for us.

多年来，我逐渐形成了这样一种观点：如果我们几十年来持续不断地把钱投资到低成本的指数基金中，让这些钱自然复利，我们就有很大机会实现家庭的所有财务目标。这种观点很大程度上源于我们节俭的生活方式。如果不用承担试图超越市场带来的额外风险就能实现所有目标，那努力还有什么意义呢？我可以承受不是世界上最伟大的投资者，但我承受不起成为一个糟糕的投资者。这样想的话，买入指数基金并持有对我们来说是理所当然的。我知道并非所有人都会认同这种逻辑，尤其是我那些以跑赢市场为己任的朋友。我尊重他们的工作。但这对我们来说是有效的。

We invest money from every paycheck into these index funds—a combination of U.S. and international stocks. There’s no set goal—it’s just whatever is leftover after we spend. We max out retirement accounts in the same funds, and contribute to our kids’ 529 college savings plans.

我们把每一份薪水都投资到这些指数基金里——美国股票和国际股票的组合。没有设定目标——只是花完之后剩下的钱。我们把这些基金里的退休账户用到最大，还给孩子们的529大学储蓄计划存钱。

And that’s about it. Effectively all of our net worth is a house, a checking account, and some Vanguard index funds.

就是这样。实际上，我们的净资产就是一套房子、一个支票账户和一些先锋指数基金。

It doesn’t need to be more complicated than that for us. I like it simple. One of my deeply held investing beliefs is that there is little correlation between investment effort and investment results. The reason is because the world is driven by tails—a few variables account for the majority of returns. No matter how hard you try at investing you won’t do well if you miss the two or three things that move the needle in your strategy. The reverse is true. Simple investment strategies can work great as long as they capture the few things that are important to that strategy’s success. My investing strategy doesn’t rely on picking the right sector, or timing the next recession. It relies on a high savings rate, patience, and optimism that the global economy will create value over the next several decades. I spend virtually all of my investing effort thinking about those three things—especially the first two, which I can control.

对我们来说，事情不需要比这更复杂。我喜欢简单。我坚信的投资理念之一是，投资投入和投资结果之间几乎没有关联。原因在于，这个世界是由反面驱动的——少数变量决定了大部分回报。无论你多么努力地投资，如果忽略了策略中影响投资方向的两三个因素，你都不会成功。反之亦然。简单的投资策略只要抓住了对策略成功至关重要的几个因素，就能发挥巨大作用。我的投资策略并不依赖于选择正确的行业或把握下一次经济衰退的时机。它依赖于高储蓄率、耐心以及对全球经济将在未来几十年创造价值的乐观态度。我几乎把所有的投资精力都花在思考这三件事上——尤其是前两件事，因为它们我可以掌控。

I’ve changed my investment strategy in the past. So of course there’s a chance I’ll change it in the future.

我过去改变过我的投资策略。所以未来当然也有可能改变。

No matter how we save or invest I’m sure we’ll always have the goal of independence, and we’ll always do whatever maximizes for sleeping well at night.

无论我们如何储蓄或投资，我相信我们始终以独立为目标，并且我们始终会尽一切努力让自己晚上睡得更好。

We think it’s the ultimate goal; the mastery of the psychology of money.

我们认为这是最终目标：掌握金钱心理学。

But to each their own. No one is crazy.

但每个人都有自己的想法。没有人是疯子。

#↩

To understand the psychology of the modern consumer and to grasp where they might be heading next, you have to know how they got here.

要了解现代消费者的心理并了解他们下一步的发展方向，您必须知道他们是如何走到这一步的。

How we all got here.

我们是如何来到这里的。

If you fell asleep in 1945 and woke up in 2020 you would not recognize the world around you.

如果你在 1945 年睡着了，并在 2020 年醒来，你将无法认出周围的世界。

The amount of economic growth that took place during that period is virtually unprecedented. If you saw the level of wealth in New York and San Francisco, you’d be shocked. If you compared it to the poverty of Detroit, you’d be shocked. If you saw the price of homes, college tuition, and health care, you’d be shocked. If you saw how average Americans think about savings and spending in general, you’d be shocked. And if you tried to think of a reasonable narrative of how it all happened, my guess is you’d be totally wrong. Because it isn’t intuitive, and it wasn’t foreseeable.

那段时期的经济增长速度几乎是史无前例的。如果你看看纽约和旧金山的财富水平，你会感到震惊。如果你把它与底特律的贫困状况相比，你也会感到震惊。如果你看看房价、大学学费和医疗保健的价格，你也会感到震惊。如果你看看普通美国人对储蓄和支出的总体看法，你也会感到震惊。而如果你试图想出一个合理的解释来解释这一切是如何发生的，我猜你完全错了。因为它既不直观，也无法预见。

What happened in America since the end of World War II is the story of the American consumer. It’s a story that helps explain why people think about money the way they do today.

二战结束以来美国发生的一切，正是美国消费者的故事。这个故事有助于解释为什么人们今天会以这样的方式看待金钱。

The short story is this: Things were very uncertain, then they were very good, then pretty bad, then really good, then really bad, and now here we are. And there is, I think, a narrative that links all those events together. Not a detailed account. But a story of how things fit together.

简而言之：事情一开始非常不确定，然后变得非常好，然后非常糟糕，然后非常好，然后非常糟糕，现在我们到了这里。我认为，有一个叙事将所有事件串联在一起。这不是一个详细的叙述，而是一个关于事情如何串联起来的故事。

Since this is an attempt to link the big events together, it leaves out many details of what happened during this period. I’m likely to agree with anyone who points out what I’ve missed. The goal here is not to describe every play; it’s to look at how one game influenced the next.

由于本文试图将重大事件串联起来，因此遗漏了这段时期发生的许多细节。如果有人指出我遗漏了什么，我可能会表示同意。本文的目的并非描述每场比赛，而是探究一场比赛如何影响下一场比赛。

Here’s how the modern consumer got here.

现代消费者的消费方式如下。

1. August, 1945. World War II ends.

1. 1945 年 8 月。第二次世界大战结束。

Japan surrendering was “The Happiest Day in American History,” The New York Times wrote.

《纽约时报》写道，日本投降是“美国历史上最快乐的一天”。

But there’s the saying, “History is just one damn thing after another.”

但有句话说得好，“历史就是一件又一件的事情。”

The joy of the war ending was quickly met with the question, “What happens now?”

战争结束的喜悦很快引发了人们的疑问：“接下来会发生什么？”

Sixteen million Americans—11% of the population—served in the war. About eight million were overseas at the end. Their average age was 23. Within 18 months all but 1.5 million of them would be home and out of uniform.

一千六百万美国人（占总人口的11%）参加了战争。战争结束时，约有八百万人在海外服役。他们的平均年龄为23岁。在18个月内，除了150万人外，其余所有人都回国，不再穿着军装。

And then what?

然后呢？

What were they going to do next?

他们下一步要做什么？

Where were they going to work?

他们要去哪里工作？

Where were they going to live?

他们要住哪儿？

Those were the most important questions of the day, for two reasons. One, no one knew the answers. Two, if they couldn’t be answered quickly, the most likely scenario—in the eyes of many economists—was that the economy would slip back into the depths of the Great Depression.

这些是当时最重要的问题，原因有二。第一，没人知道答案。第二，如果不能迅速找到答案，在许多经济学家看来，最有可能的情况是，经济将再次陷入大萧条的深渊。

Three forces had built up during the war:

战争期间，有三股力量逐渐壮大：

Housing construction ground to a halt, as virtually all production capacity was shifted to building war supplies. Fewer than 12,000 homes per month were built in 1943, equivalent to less than one new home per American city. Returning soldiers faced a severe housing shortage.

住房建设陷入停滞，几乎所有产能都转移到了战争物资的生产上。1943年，每月新建住房不足1.2万套，相当于每个美国城市新建住房不足一套。退役士兵面临严重的住房短缺。

The specific jobs created during the war—building ships, tanks, and planes—were very suddenly not necessary after it, stopping with a speed and magnitude rarely seen in private business. It was unclear where soldiers could work.

战争期间创造的特定工作——造船、坦克和飞机——在战后突然变得不再必要，并以私营企业中罕见的速度和规模停止。士兵们不知道在哪里可以工作。

The marriage rate spiked during and immediately after the war. Soldiers didn’t want to return to their mother’s basement. They wanted to start a family, in their own home, with a good job, right away.

战争期间和战后，结婚率飙升。士兵们不想回到母亲的地下室。他们想立刻在自己的家里，找到一份好工作，成家立业。

This worried policymakers, especially since the Great Depression was still a recent memory, having ended just five years prior.

这让政策制定者感到担忧，尤其是大萧条五年前才结束，人们还记忆犹新。

In 1946 the Council of Economic Advisors delivered a report to President Truman warning of “a full-scale depression some time in the next one to four years.”

1946年，经济顾问委员会向杜鲁门总统提交了一份报告，警告“未来一到四年内将出现全面萧条”。

They wrote in a separate 1947 memo, summarizing a meeting with Truman:

他们在 1947 年的另一份备忘录中总结了与杜鲁门的会面：

We might be in some sort of recession period where we should have to be very sure of our ground as to whether recessionary forces might be in danger of getting out of hand … There is a substantial prospect which should not be overlooked that a further decline may increase the danger of a downward spiral into depression conditions.

我们可能正处于某种衰退时期，我们必须非常清楚衰退力量是否有失控的危险……不容忽视的巨大前景是，进一步的衰退可能会增加陷入萧条状态的危险。

This fear was exacerbated by the fact that exports couldn’t be immediately relied upon for growth, as two of the largest economies—Europe and Japan—sat in ruins dealing with humanitarian crises. And America itself was buried in more debt than ever before, limiting direct government stimulus.

由于两大经济体——欧洲和日本——正深陷人道主义危机，无法立即依赖出口来拉动经济增长，这种担忧进一步加剧。而美国自身的债务负担也比以往任何时候都沉重，限制了政府的直接刺激措施。

So we did something about it.

因此我们采取了一些措施。

2. Low interest rates and the intentional birth of the American consumer.

2.低利率和美国消费者的有意诞生。

The first thing we did to keep the economy afloat after the war was keep interest rates low. This wasn’t an easy decision, because when soldiers came home to a shortage of everything from clothes to cars it temporarily sent inflation into double digits.

战后，我们为维持经济运转所做的第一件事就是维持低利率。这并非易事，因为士兵们回家后会发现，从衣服到汽车，各种物资都短缺，这导致通货膨胀率一度达到两位数。

The Federal Reserve was not politically independent before 1951.⁷² The president and the Fed could coordinate policy. In 1942 the Fed announced it would keep short-term rates at 0.38% to help finance the war. Rates didn’t budge a single basis point for the next seven years. Three-month Treasury yields stayed below 2% until the mid-1950s.

1951年之前，美联储并非政治独立。⁷² 总统和美联储可以协调政策。1942年，美联储宣布将短期利率维持在0.38%，以支持战争融资。此后七年，利率未曾变动过一个基点。三个月期美国国债收益率一直低于2%，直到20世纪50年代中期。

The explicit reason for keeping rates down was to keep the cost of financing the equivalent of the $6 trillion we spent on the war low.

保持低利率的明确原因是为了将相当于我们为战争花费的 6 万亿美元的融资成本保持在较低水平。

But low rates also did something else for all the returning GIs. It made borrowing to buy homes, cars, gadgets, and toys really cheap.

但低利率也为所有回国的美国士兵带来了其他好处。它使得借贷购买房屋、汽车、电子产品和玩具变得非常便宜。

Which, from a paranoid policymaker’s perspective, was great. Consumption became an explicit economic strategy in the years after World War II.

从偏执的政策制定者的角度来看，这很棒。二战后，消费成为一项明确的经济战略。

An era of encouraging thrift and saving to fund the war quickly turned into an era of actively promoting spending. Princeton historian Sheldon Garon writes:

一个鼓励节俭储蓄以资助战争的时代，很快就变成了一个积极推动支出的时代。普林斯顿大学历史学家谢尔登·加伦写道：

After 1945, America again diverged from patterns of savings promotion in Europe and East Asia … Politicians, businessmen and labor leaders all encouraged Americans to spend to foster economic growth.⁷³

1945年后，美国再次偏离了欧洲和东亚的储蓄促进模式……政客、商人和劳工领袖都鼓励美国人消费以促进经济增长。⁷³

Two things fueled this push.

有两件事推动了这一努力。

One was the GI Bill, which offered unprecedented mortgage opportunities. Sixteen million veterans could buy a home often with no money down, no interest in the first year, and fixed rates so low that monthly mortgage payments could be lower than a rental.

其中之一就是《退伍军人权利法案》，它提供了前所未有的抵押贷款机会。1600万退伍军人可以买房，通常零首付，第一年免息，而且固定利率非常低，以至于每月的抵押贷款还款额甚至可能低于租房。

The second was an explosion of consumer credit, enabled by the loosening of Depression-era regulations. The first credit card was introduced in 1950. Store credit, installment credit, personal loans, payday loans—everything took off. And interest on all debt, including credit cards, was tax deductible at the time.

第二个因素是消费信贷的爆炸式增长，这得益于大萧条时期监管的放松。第一张信用卡于1950年问世。商店信贷、分期付款信贷、个人贷款、发薪日贷款——一切都蓬勃发展。当时，包括信用卡在内的所有债务的利息都可以抵税。

It tasted delicious. So we ate a lot of it. A simple story in a simple table:

味道好极了。所以我们吃了很多。一张简单的桌子里装着一个简单的故事：

Household debt in the 1950s grew 1.5 times faster than it did during the 2000s debt splurge.

20 世纪 50 年代家庭债务的增长速度是 21 世纪债务激增期间的 1.5 倍。

3. Pent-up demand for stuff fed by a credit boom and a hidden 1930s productivity boom led to an economic boom.

3. 信贷繁荣和 20 世纪 30 年代隐性的生产力繁荣所激发的被压抑的需求导致了经济繁荣。

The 1930s were the hardest economic decade in American history. But there was a silver lining that took two decades to notice: By necessity, the Great Depression had supercharged resourcefulness, productivity, and innovation.

20世纪30年代是美国历史上经济最艰难的十年。但其中也蕴含着一线希望，人们花了二十年时间才注意到：大萧条必然会增强人们的智慧、生产力和创新能力。

We didn’t pay that much attention to the productivity boom in the ’30s, because everyone was focused on how bad the economy was. We didn’t pay attention to it in the ’40s, because everyone was focused on the war.

20世纪30年代，我们没怎么关注生产力繁荣，因为大家都关注当时糟糕的经济状况。40年代，我们也没怎么关注生产力繁荣，因为大家都关注战争。

Then the 1950s came around and we suddenly realized, “Wow, we have some amazing new inventions. And we’re really good at making them.”

到了20世纪50年代，我们突然意识到：“哇，我们有一些令人惊叹的新发明。而且我们真的很擅长制造它们。”

Appliances, cars, phones, air conditioning, electricity.

家用电器、汽车、电话、空调、电力。

It was nearly impossible to buy many household goods during the war, because factories were converted to make guns and ships. That created pent-up demand from GIs for stuff after the war ended. Married, eager to get on with life, and emboldened with new cheap consumer credit, they went on a buying spree like the country had never seen.

战争期间，许多家庭用品几乎买不到，因为工厂被改造成生产枪支和船只。战争结束后，美国士兵们积压已久的物资需求被释放出来。他们结婚了，渴望继续生活，再加上新的廉价消费信贷，他们掀起了全国前所未有的疯狂购物狂潮。

Frederick Lewis Allen writes in his book The Big Change:

弗雷德里克·刘易斯·艾伦在他的《大变革》一书中写道：

During these postwar years the farmer bought a new tractor, a corn picker, an electric milking machine; in fact he and his neighbors, between them, assembled a formidable array of farm machinery for their joint use. The farmer’s wife got the shining white electric refrigerator she had always longed for and never during the Great Depression had been able to afford, and an up-to-date washing machine, and a deep-freeze unit. The suburban family installed a dishwashing machine and invested in a power lawnmower. The city family became customers of a laundromat and acquired a television set for the living room. The husband’s office was air-conditioned. And so on endlessly.

战后这些年里，农场主买了一台新拖拉机、一台玉米收割机和一台电动挤奶机；事实上，他和邻居们一起组装了一大批农用机械，供大家使用。农场主的妻子得到了她一直梦寐以求、但在大萧条时期却买不起的亮白色电冰箱，以及一台最新的洗衣机和一台冷冻柜。住在郊区的家庭安装了一台洗碗机，并投资购置了一台电动割草机。住在城里的家庭成了自助洗衣店的顾客，并在客厅里添置了一台电视机。丈夫的办公室装上了空调。诸如此类，不胜枚举。

It’s hard to overstate how big this surge was.

很难夸大这次激增的规模。

Commercial car and truck manufacturing virtually ceased from 1942 to 1945. Then 21 million cars were sold from 1945 to 1949. Another 37 million were sold by 1955.

1942 年至 1945 年间，商用轿车和卡车制造业几乎停止。1945 年至 1949 年间，共售出 2100 万辆汽车。到 1955 年，又售出 3700 万辆。

Just under two million homes were built from 1940 to 1945. Then seven million were built from 1945 to 1950. Another eight million were built by 1955.

1940 年至 1945 年间，建造了近 200 万套住房。1945 年至 1950 年间，又建造了 700 万套住房。到 1955 年，又建造了 800 万套住房。

Pent-up demand for stuff, and our newfound ability to make stuff, created the jobs that put returning GIs back to work. And they were good jobs, too. Mix that with consumer credit, and America’s capacity for spending exploded.

被压抑的商品需求，以及我们新获得的制造能力，创造了就业机会，让退役士兵重返工作岗位。而且这些工作也都很好。再加上消费信贷，美国的消费能力就爆炸式增长。

The Federal Reserve wrote to President Truman in 1951: “By 1950, total consumer expenditures, together with residential construction, amounted to about 203 billion dollars, or in the neighborhood of 40 percent above the 1944 level.”⁷⁴

美联储在 1951 年写给杜鲁门总统的信中表示：“到 1950 年，总消费支出加上住宅建设支出约为 2030 亿美元，比 1944 年的水平高出约 40%。”74

The answer to the question, “What are all these GIs going to do after the war?” was now obvious. They were going to buy stuff, with money earned from their jobs making new stuff, helped by cheap borrowed money to buy even more stuff.

“战后这些美国大兵要干什么？”这个问题的答案现在显而易见了。他们会用自己打工赚来的钱去买东西，再用低息贷款买更多东西。

4. Gains are shared more equally than ever before.

4. 收益分享比以往更加平等。

The defining characteristic of economics in the 1950s is that the country got rich by making the poor less poor.

20 世纪 50 年代经济学的典型特征是，国家通过让穷人变得不那么穷而变得富裕。

Average wages doubled from 1940 to 1948, then doubled again by 1963.

1940 年至 1948 年间，平均工资翻了一番，到 1963 年又翻了一番。

And those gains focused on those who had been left behind for decades before. The gap between rich and poor narrowed by an extraordinary amount.

这些进步主要集中在那些几十年前被抛在后面的人们身上，贫富差距大幅缩小。

Lewis Allen wrote in 1955:

刘易斯·艾伦（Lewis Allen）在 1955 年写道：

The enormous lead of the well-to-do in the economic race has been considerably reduced.

富裕阶层在经济竞赛中的巨大领先优势已大大缩小。

It is the industrial workers who as a group have done best—people such as a steelworker’s family who used to live on $2,500 and now are getting $4,500, or the highly skilled machine-tool operator’s family who used to have $3,000 and now can spend an annual $5,500 or more.

作为一个群体，产业工人的生活状况最好——比如钢铁工人的家庭，以前的生活费是 2,500 美元，现在能得到 4,500 美元；高技能机床操作员的家庭，以前的生活费是 3,000 美元，现在每年能花掉 5,500 美元甚至更多。

As for the top one percent, the really well-to-do and the rich, whom we might classify very roughly indeed as the $16,000-and-over group, their share of the total national income, after taxes, had come down by 1945 from 13 percent to 7 percent.

至于最顶层的 1%，即真正富裕和富人，我们可以粗略地将他们归类为收入 16,000 美元及以上的群体，他们在税后国民总收入中所占的份额到 1945 年已经从 13% 下降到 7%。

This was not a short-term trend. Real income for the bottom 20% of wage-earners grew by a nearly identical amount as the top 5% from 1950 to 1980.

这并非短期趋势。1950年至1980年间，底层20%工薪阶层的实际收入增幅与顶层5%几乎相同。

The equality went beyond wages.

这种平等不仅仅局限于工资。

Women held jobs outside the home in record numbers. Their labor force participation rate went from 31% after the war to 37% by 1955, and to 40% by 1965.

女性外出工作的数量创下了历史新高。她们的劳动参与率从战后的31%上升到1955年的37%，到1965年又上升到40%。

Minorities gained, too. After the 1945 inauguration Eleanor Roosevelt wrote about an African American reporter who told her:

少数族裔也受益匪浅。1945年总统就职典礼后，埃莉诺·罗斯福（Eleanor Roosevelt）写道，一位非裔美国记者告诉她：

Do you realize what twelve years have done? If at the 1933 reception a number of colored people had gone down the line and mixed with everyone else in the way they did today, every paper in the country would have reported it. We do not even think it is news and none of us will mention it.

你知道十二年过去了，发生了些什么吗？如果1933年的招待会上，有一群有色人种像今天这样，沿着队伍走下去，和其他人混在一起，全国的报纸都会报道这件事。我们甚至不认为这是新闻，也不会提及。

Women and minority rights were still a fraction of what they are today. But the progress toward equality in the late ’40s and ’50s was extraordinary.

当时，妇女和少数族裔的权利与今天相比仍然微不足道。但40年代末和50年代，在平等方面取得的进步是非凡的。

The leveling out of classes meant a leveling out of lifestyles. Normal people drove Chevys. Rich people drove Cadillacs. TV and radio equalized the entertainment and culture people enjoyed regardless of class. Mail-order catalogs equalized the clothes people wore and the goods they bought regardless of where they lived. Harper’s Magazine noted in 1957:

阶级的平等意味着生活方式的平等。普通人开雪佛兰，富人开凯迪拉克。电视和广播使人们无论阶级如何都能享受到平等的娱乐和文化。邮购目录使人们无论身在何处都能穿衣打扮，购买商品也变得平等。《哈泼斯杂志》在1957年指出：

The rich man smokes the same sort of cigarettes as the poor man, shaves with the same sort of razor, uses the same sort of telephone, vacuum cleaner, radio, and TV set, has the same sort of lighting and heating equipment in his house, and so on indefinitely. The differences between his automobile and the poor man’s are minor. Essentially they have similar engines, similar fittings. In the early years of the century there was a hierarchy of automobiles.

富人和穷人抽着同一种香烟，用同一种剃须刀刮胡子，用同一种电话、吸尘器、收音机和电视机，家里有同一种照明和取暖设备，等等等等。富人和穷人的汽车差别很小。本质上，他们有相似的发动机和相似的配件。在本世纪初，汽车存在着等级制度。

Paul Graham wrote in 2016 about what something as simple as there only being three TV stations did to equalize culture:

保罗·格雷厄姆 (Paul Graham) 在 2016 年撰文写道，只有三家电视台这样的简单事物如何使文化均衡：

It’s difficult to imagine now, but every night tens of millions of families would sit down together in front of their TV set watching the same show, at the same time, as their next door neighbors. What happens now with the Super Bowl used to happen every night. We were literally in sync.⁷⁵

现在很难想象，但每天晚上，数千万个家庭都会和隔壁邻居坐在电视机前，在同一时间观看同一档节目。现在超级碗的盛况，过去每晚都会上演。我们简直是同步的。⁷⁵

This was important. People measure their well-being against their peers. And for most of the 1945–1980 period, people had a lot of what looked like peers to compare themselves to. Many people—most people—lived lives that were either equal or at least fathomable to those around them. The idea that people’s lives equalized as much as their incomes is an important point of this story we’ll come back to.

这一点很重要。人们会与同龄人比较，以此衡量自己的幸福感。在1945年至1980年的大部分时间里，人们有很多看似同龄的人可以与自己比较。许多人——大多数人——的生活与周围的人一样，或者至少可以理解。人们的生活与收入的平等程度，是本文的重点，我们稍后会回顾。

5. Debt rose tremendously. But so did incomes, so the impact wasn’t a big deal.

5. 债务大幅增加。但收入也随之增加，所以影响并不大。

Household debt increased fivefold from 1947 to 1957 due to the combination of the new consumption culture, new debt products, and interest rates subsidized by government programs, and held low by the Federal Reserve.

1947 年至 1957 年间，由于新的消费文化、新的债务产品以及政府项目补贴的利率和美联储维持的低利率，家庭债务增加了五倍。

But income growth was so strong during this period that the impact on households wasn’t severe. And household debt was so low to begin with after the war. The Great Depression wiped out a lot of it, and household spending was so curtailed during the war that debt accumulation was restricted. So the growth in household debt-to-income from 1947–1957 was manageable.

但这段时期收入增长强劲，对家庭的影响并不严重。战后，家庭债务本来就很低。大萧条抹去了很大一部分债务，战争期间家庭支出大幅缩减，债务积累也受到了限制。因此，1947年至1957年期间家庭债务收入比的增长是可控的。

Household debt-to-income today is just over 100%. Even after rising in the 1950s, 1960s, and 1970s, it stayed below 60%.

目前家庭债务与收入之比略高于100%。即使在20世纪50年代、60年代和70年代有所上升，这一比例也一直保持在60%以下。

Driving a lot of this debt boom was a surge in home ownership.

推动此次债务繁荣的很大一部分原因是房屋所有权的激增。

The homeownership rate in 1900 was 47%. It stayed right about there for the next four decades. Then it took off, hitting 53% by 1945 and 62% by 1970. A substantial portion of the population was now using debt that previous generations would not—could not—have accessed. And they were mostly OK with it.

1900年的住房自有率为47%。在接下来的四十年里，这一比例基本保持不变。之后，这一比例开始飙升，到1945年达到53%，到1970年更是达到了62%。当时，相当一部分人口背负着前几代人无法承担的债务。而他们大多对此并不介意。

David Halberstam writes in his book The Fifties:

戴维·哈伯斯塔姆 (David Halberstam) 在他的《五十年代》一书中写道：

They were confident in themselves and their futures in a way that [those] growing up in harder times found striking. They did not fear debt as their parents had … They differed from their parents not just in how much they made and what they owned but in their belief that the future had already arrived. As the first homeowners in their families, they brought a new excitement and pride with them to the store as they bought furniture or appliances—in other times young couples might have exhibited such feelings as they bought clothes for their first baby. It was as if the very accomplishment of owning a home reflected such an immense breakthrough that nothing was too good to buy for it.

他们对自己和未来充满信心，这种信心让那些在艰难时期成长的人印象深刻。他们不像父母那样害怕债务……他们与父母的不同之处不仅在于收入和财产，更在于他们相信未来已经到来。作为家中第一个拥有房产的人，他们带着新的兴奋和自豪感去商店购买家具或电器——在其他时候，年轻夫妇可能会在为第一个孩子购买衣服时表现出这种感觉。拥有一套房子本身就是一种巨大的突破，没有什么比它更值得拥有了。

Now’s a good time to connect a few things, as they’ll become increasingly important:

现在是将一些事情联系起来的好时机，因为它们将变得越来越重要：

America is booming.

美国正在蓬勃发展。

It’s booming together like never before.

它正以前所未有的方式蓬勃发展。

It’s booming with debt that isn’t a big deal at the time because it’s still low relative to income and there’s a cultural acceptance that debt isn’t a scary thing.

这个行业的债务不断增加，但当时债务问题并不大，因为相对于收入而言，债务仍然很低，而且人们的文化也认为债务并不可怕。

6. Things start cracking.

6. 事物开始破裂。

1973 was the first year where it became clear the economy was walking down a new path.

1973年是经济走上新道路的第一年。

The recession that began that year brought unemployment to the highest it had been since the 1930s.

始于那一年的经济衰退使失业率达到 20 世纪 30 年代以来的最高水平。

Inflation surged. But unlike the post-war spikes, it stayed high.

通货膨胀率飙升。但与战后高峰不同，通货膨胀率一直居高不下。

Short-term interest rates hit 8% in 1973, up from 2.5% a decade earlier.

1973年短期利率达到8%，高于十年前的2.5%。

And you have to put all of that in the context of how much fear there was between Vietnam, riots, and the assassinations of Martin Luther King, and John and Bobby Kennedy.

你必须把所有这些都放在越南战争、骚乱以及马丁·路德·金、约翰和鲍比·肯尼迪遇刺事件之间所引发的恐惧背景下考虑。

It got bleak.

情况变得暗淡。

America dominated the world economy in the two decades after the war. Many of the largest countries had their manufacturing capacity bombed into rubble. But as the 1970s emerged, that changed. Japan was booming. China’s economy was opening up. The Middle East was flexing its oil muscles.

战后二十年，美国主宰着世界经济。许多最大的国家的制造业产能被炸成废墟。但随着20世纪70年代的到来，情况发生了变化。日本蓬勃发展。中国经济开放。中东则在展示其石油实力。

A combination of lucky economic advantages and a culture shared by the Greatest Generation—hardened by the Depression and anchored in systematic cooperation from the war—shifted when Baby Boomers began coming of age. A new generation that had a different view of what’s normal hit at the same time a lot of the economic tailwinds of the previous two decades ended.

幸运的经济优势，加上“最伟大的一代”所共有的文化——大萧条时期的磨砺，以及战后系统性合作的根基——在婴儿潮一代步入成年之际发生了转变。新一代对“常态”持有不同看法，与此同时，过去二十年的许多经济顺风也随之结束。

Everything in finance is data within the context of expectations. One of the biggest shifts of the last century happened when the economic winds began blowing in a different, uneven direction, but people’s expectations were still rooted in a post-war culture of equality. Not necessarily equality of income, although there was that. But equality in lifestyle and consumption expectations; the idea that someone earning a 50th percentile income shouldn’t live a life dramatically different than someone in the 80th or 90th percentile. And that someone in the 99th percentile lived a better life, but still a life that someone in the 50th percentile could comprehend. That’s how America worked for most of the 1945–1980 period. It doesn’t matter whether you think that’s morally right or wrong. It just matters that it happened.

金融中的一切都是预期背景下的数据。上个世纪最大的转变之一发生在经济风向开始发生变化、不均衡的时候，但人们的预期仍然根植于战后的平等文化。这不一定是收入平等，尽管确实存在收入平等。而是生活方式和消费预期的平等；这种观念认为，收入在第50个百分点的人的生活不应该与收入在第80个百分点或第90个百分点的人有太大差异。收入在第99个百分点的人生活得更好，但仍然是第50个百分点的人能够理解的生活。这就是美国在1945年至1980年的大部分时间里运作的方式。无论你认为这在道德上是对是错，都无关紧要。重要的是它发生了。

Expectations always move slower than facts. And the economic facts of the years between the early 1970s through the early 2000s were that growth continued, but became more uneven, yet people’s expectations of how their lifestyle should compare to their peers did not change.

预期总是比事实发展得慢。20世纪70年代初至21世纪初的经济现实是，经济增长持续，但变得更加不平衡，然而人们对自身生活方式与同龄人相比的预期却没有改变。

7. The boom resumes, but it’s different than before.

7. 繁荣再次来临，但与以往有所不同。

Ronald Reagan’s 1984 “Morning in America” ad declared:

罗纳德·里根 1984 年的“美国的早晨”广告宣称：

It’s morning again in America. Today more men and women will go to work than ever before in our country’s history. With interest rates at about half the record highs of 1980, nearly 2,000 families today will buy new homes, more than at any time in the past four years. This afternoon 6,500 young men and women will be married, and with inflation at less than half of what it was just four years ago, they can look forward with confidence to the future.

美国又迎来了黎明。今天，就业人数将达到我国历史上的最高水平。利率约为1980年历史最高水平的一半，今天将有近2000个家庭购买新房，数量超过过去四年的任何时候。今天下午，6500名年轻男女将结婚，通货膨胀率还不到四年前的一半，他们可以满怀信心地展望未来。

That wasn’t hyperbole. GDP growth was the highest it had been since the 1950s. By 1989 there were six million fewer unemployed Americans than there were seven years before. The S&P 500 rose almost fourfold between 1982 and 1990. Total real GDP growth in the 1990s was roughly equal to that of the 1950s—40% vs. 42%.

这并非夸张。GDP增长率达到了自20世纪50年代以来的最高水平。到1989年，美国的失业人数比七年前减少了600万。标准普尔500指数在1982年至1990年间上涨了近四倍。20世纪90年代的实际GDP增长率与20世纪50年代大致相当——分别为40%和42%。

President Clinton boasted in his 2000 State of the Union speech:

克林顿总统在 2000 年国情咨文演讲中夸口道：

We begin the new century with over 20 million new jobs; the fastest economic growth in more than 30 years; the lowest unemployment rates in 30 years; the lowest poverty rates in 20 years; the lowest African-American and Hispanic unemployment rates on record; the first back-to-back surpluses in 42 years; and next month, America will achieve the longest period of economic growth in our entire history. We have built a new economy.

我们以超过2000万个新增就业岗位开启新世纪；30多年来最快的经济增长；30年来最低的失业率；20年来最低的贫困率；非裔美国人和西班牙裔美国人的失业率创历史新低；42年来首次连续盈余；下个月，美国将实现历史上持续时间最长的经济增长。我们已建立起一个全新的经济。

His last sentence was important. It was a new economy. The biggest difference between the economy of the 1945–1973 period and that of the 1982–2000 period was that the same amount of growth found its way into totally different pockets.

他最后一句话很重要。这是一种新的经济。1945-1973年的经济和1982-2000年的经济之间最大的区别在于，同样的增长量流入了完全不同的领域。

You’ve probably heard these numbers but they’re worth rehashing. The Atlantic writes:

你可能听说过这些数字，但它们值得重新讨论。《大西洋月刊》写道：

Between 1993 and 2012, the top 1 percent saw their incomes grow 86.1 percent, while the bottom 99 percent saw just 6.6 percent growth.

1993年至2012年间，最富裕的1%人口的收入增长了86.1%，而最贫困的99%人口的收入仅增长了6.6%。

Joseph Stiglitz in 2011:

约瑟夫·斯蒂格利茨于2011年表示：

While the top 1 percent have seen their incomes rise 18 percent over the past decade, those in the middle have actually seen their incomes fall. For men with only high-school degrees, the decline has been precipitous—12 percent in the last quarter-century alone.

过去十年，最富裕的1%人群的收入增长了18%，而中产阶级的收入却在下降。对于仅有高中学历的男性来说，收入下降幅度更是惊人——仅在过去25年就下降了12%。

It was nearly the opposite of the flattening that occurred after the war.

这与战后出现的平坦化几乎截然相反。

Why this happened is one of the nastiest debates in economics, topped only by the debate over what we should do about it. Lucky for the purpose of this discussion, neither matters.

为何会发生这种情况是经济学中最激烈的争论之一，仅次于我们应该如何应对。幸运的是，就本次讨论的目的而言，这两个问题都不重要。

All that matters is that sharp inequality became a force over the last 35 years, and it happened during a period where, culturally, Americans held onto two ideas rooted in the post-WW2 economy: That you should live a lifestyle similar to most other Americans, and that taking on debt to finance that lifestyle is acceptable.

重要的是，严重的不平等现象在过去 35 年里成为一股力量，而这发生在美国人从文化上坚持二战后经济根源的两个观念的时期：你应该过上与大多数其他美国人相似的生活方式，并且承担债务来维持这种生活方式是可以接受的。

8. The big stretch.

8. 大伸展。

Rising incomes among a small group of Americans led to that group breaking away in lifestyle.

一小部分美国人的收入不断增加，导致他们的生活方式发生改变。

They bought bigger homes, nicer cars, went to expensive schools, and took fancy vacations.

他们购买更大的房子、更好的汽车、上昂贵的学校、享受奢华的假期。

And everyone else was watching—fueled by Madison Avenue in the ’80s and ’90s, and the internet after that.

其他人也在关注着——80 年代和 90 年代的麦迪逊大道以及之后的互联网推动了这一趋势。

The lifestyles of a small portion of legitimately rich Americans inflated the aspirations of the majority of Americans, whose incomes weren’t rising.

一小部分真正富裕的美国人的生活方式夸大了大多数美国人的期望，而他们的收入并没有增加。

A culture of equality and togetherness that came out of the 1950s–1970s innocently morphs into a Keeping Up With The Joneses effect.

20 世纪 50 年代至 70 年代兴起的平等和团结文化无意中演变成了一种“与琼斯一家同行”的效应。

Now you can see the problem.

现在你可以看到问题所在了。

Joe, an investment banker making $900,000 a year, buys a 4,000 square foot house with two Mercedes and sends three of his kids to Pepperdine. He can afford it.

乔是一位年薪90万美元的投资银行家，他买了一栋4000平方英尺的房子，配两辆奔驰，还送三个孩子去佩珀代因大学读书。他负担得起。

Peter, a bank branch manager making $80,000 a year, sees Joe and feels a subconscious sense of entitlement to live a similar lifestyle, because Peter’s parents believed—and instilled in him—that Americans’ lifestyles weren’t that different even if they had different jobs. His parents were right during their era, because incomes fell into a tight distribution. But that was then. Peter lives in a different world. But his expectations haven’t changed much from his parents’, even if the facts have.

彼得是一位年薪8万美元的银行分行经理。他看到乔，潜意识里就觉得自己也应该过上类似的生活。因为彼得的父母一直相信——并且也向他灌输——即使工作不同，美国人的生活方式也没什么不同。在那个年代，父母的这种想法是对的，因为收入分配很紧张。但那已经是过去式了。彼得生活在一个完全不同的世界。尽管事实已经发生了变化，但他的期望与父母的期望并没有太大变化。

So what does Peter do?

那么彼得做了什么？

He takes out a huge mortgage. He has $45,000 of credit card debt. He leases two cars. His kids will graduate with heavy student loans. He can’t afford the stuff Joe can, but he’s pushed to stretch for the same lifestyle. It is a big stretch.

他背负着巨额的抵押贷款，信用卡债务高达4.5万美元，租了两辆车。他的孩子们毕业时将背负沉重的学生贷款。他买不起乔能买得起的东西，但他不得不努力维持同样的生活方式。这真是太难了。

This would have seemed preposterous to someone in the 1930s. But we’ve spent 75 years since the end of the war fostering a cultural acceptance of household debt.

对于20世纪30年代的人来说，这或许显得荒谬。但战争结束75年以来，我们花了75年时间，才形成了一种对家庭债务的文化接受。

During a time when median wages were flat, the median new American home grew 50% larger.

在平均工资持平的时期，美国新建住房的平均面积却增长了 50%。

The average new American home now has more bathrooms than occupants. Nearly half have four or more bedrooms, up from 18% in 1983.

如今，美国新建住宅的平均浴室数量比居住人数还多。近一半的住宅拥有四间或四间以上的卧室，而1983年这一比例仅为18%。

The average car loan adjusted for inflation more than doubled between 1975 and 2003, from $12,300 to $27,900.

1975年至2003年间，经通胀调整后的平均汽车贷款额增加了一倍多，从12,300美元增至27,900美元。

And you know what happened to college costs and student loans.

你知道大学费用和学生贷款发生了什么变化吗？

Household debt-to-income stayed about flat from 1963 to 1973. Then it climbed, and climbed, and climbed, from around 60% in 1973 to more than 130% by 2007.

1963年至1973年，家庭债务收入比基本持平。随后，这一比例不断攀升，从1973年的60%左右上升到2007年的130%以上。

Even as interest rates plunged from the early 1980s through 2020, the percentage of income going to debt service payments rose. And it skewed toward lower-income groups. The share of income going toward debt and lease payments is just over 8% for the highest income groups—those with the biggest income gains—but over 21% for those below the 50th percentile.

即使从20世纪80年代初到2020年利率暴跌，用于偿还债务的收入比例仍在上升。而且这种趋势向低收入群体倾斜。对于收入最高（收入增长最快的群体）的人群来说，用于偿还债务和租赁收入的比例略高于8%，而对于收入低于50%的群体来说，这一比例则超过21%。

The difference between this climbing debt and the debt increase that took place during the 1950s and ’60s is that the recent jump started from a high base.

此次债务攀升与 20 世纪 50 年代和 60 年代债务增加的区别在于，最近的跃升是从高基数开始的。

Economist Hyman Minsky described the beginning of debt crises: The moment when people take on more debt than they can service. It’s an ugly, painful moment. It’s like Wile E. Coyote looking down, realizing he’s screwed, and falling precipitously.

经济学家海曼·明斯基这样描述债务危机的开端：人们承担的债务超过其偿还能力的时刻。这是一个丑陋而痛苦的时刻。就像歪心狼俯视着前方，意识到自己完蛋了，然后猛地坠落。

Which, of course, is what happened in 2008.

当然，这就是 2008 年发生的事情。

9. Once a paradigm is in place it is very hard to turn it around.

9. 一旦范式形成，就很难改变它。

A lot of debt was shed after 2008. And then interest rates plunged. Household debt payments as a percentage of income are now at the lowest levels in 35 years.

2008年后，大量债务被削减。随后利率暴跌。家庭债务支出占收入的比例目前处于35年来的最低水平。

But the response to 2008, necessary as it may have been, perpetuated some of the trends that got us here.

但对 2008 年的反应，尽管是必要的，却延续了导致我们走到这一步的一些趋势。

Quantitative easing both prevented economic collapse and boosted asset prices, a boon for those who owned them—mostly rich people.

量化宽松政策既防止了经济崩溃，又推高了资产价格，这对资产拥有者（主要是富人）来说是一种福音。

The Fed backstopped corporate debt in 2008. That helped those who owned that debt—mostly rich people.

美联储在 2008 年为企业债务提供了支持。这帮助了那些拥有债务的人——主要是富人。

Tax cuts over the last 20 years have predominantly gone to those with higher incomes. People with higher incomes send their kids to the best colleges. Those kids can go on to earn higher incomes and invest in corporate debt that will be backstopped by the Fed, own stocks that will be supported by various government policies, and so on.

过去20年的减税主要惠及了高收入人群。高收入人群把孩子送进了最好的大学。这些孩子可以继续赚取更高的收入，投资于由美联储支持的公司债券，持有由各种政府政策支持的股票，等等。

None of these things are problems in and of themselves, which is why they stay in place.

这些事情本身都不是问题，这就是它们仍然存在的原因。

But they’re symptomatic of the bigger thing that’s happened since the early 1980s: The economy works better for some people than others. Success isn’t as meritocratic as it used to be and, when success is granted, it’s rewarded with higher gains than in previous eras.

但它们反映了自20世纪80年代初以来发生的一件更大的事情：经济对某些人比对其他人更有利。成功不再像过去那样取决于精英，而且，一旦获得成功，获得的回报也比以往更高。

You don’t have to think that’s morally right or wrong.

你不必认为这在道德上是对是错。

And, again, in this story it doesn’t matter why it happened.

再说一次，在这个故事中，事情发生的原因并不重要。

It just matters that it did happen, and it caused the economy to shift away from people’s expectations that were set after the war: That there’s a broad middle class without systematic inequality, where your neighbors next door and a few miles down the road live a life that’s pretty similar to yours.

重要的是它确实发生了，它导致经济偏离了人们在战后设定的期望：存在一个没有系统性不平等的广大中产阶级，你隔壁和几英里外的邻居过着和你非常相似的生活。

Part of the reason these expectations have stuck around for 35 years after they shifted away from reality is because they felt so good for so many people when they were valid. Something that good—or at least the impression that it was that good—isn’t easy to let go of.

这些预期在脱离现实后依然存在了35年，部分原因在于，当它们成立时，很多人感觉它们非常好。如此美好的事物——或者至少是那种感觉如此美好的印象——是很难被抛弃的。

So people haven’t let go of it. They want it back.

所以人们还没有放弃它。他们想要把它找回来。

10. The Tea Party, Occupy Wall Street, Brexit, and Donald Trump each represents a group shouting, “Stop the ride, I want off.”

10. 茶党、占领华尔街、英国脱欧和唐纳德·特朗普都代表着一群高呼“别再骑了，我要下车”的人。

The details of their shouting are different, but they’re all shouting—at least in part—because stuff isn’t working for them within the context of the post-war expectation that stuff should work roughly the same for roughly everyone.

他们喊叫的细节各不相同，但他们都在喊叫——至少部分原因是——因为在战后期望的背景下，事情对他们不起作用，而战后期望是事情对几乎所有人都应该大致相同。

You can scoff at linking the rise of Trump to income inequality alone. And you should. These things are always layers of complexity deep. But it’s a key part of what drives people to think, “I don’t live in the world I expected. That pisses me off. So screw this. And screw you! I’m going to fight for something totally different, because this—whatever it is—isn’t working.”

你可以嘲笑特朗普的崛起仅仅与收入不平等挂钩。你也应该这么做。这类事情总是层层复杂，但这正是促使人们产生这样想法的关键因素：“我没有生活在我期望的世界里。这让我很生气。所以去他的。去你的！我要为完全不同的东西而战，因为无论它是什么——都行不通。”

Take that mentality and raise it to the power of Facebook, Instagram, and cable news—where people are more keenly aware of how other people live than ever before. It’s gasoline on a flame. Benedict Evans says, “The more the Internet exposes people to new points of view, the angrier people get that different views exist.” That’s a big shift from the post-war economy where the range of economic opinions were smaller, both because the actual range of outcomes was lower and because it wasn’t as easy to see and learn what other people thought and how they lived.

将这种心态提升到Facebook、Instagram和有线电视新闻的力量——在这些平台上，人们比以往任何时候都更加敏锐地了解其他人的生活。这无异于火上浇油。本尼迪克特·埃文斯说：“互联网让人们接触到的新观点越多，人们就越会对不同的观点的存在感到愤怒。” 这与战后经济相比是一个巨大的转变，当时的经济观点范围较小，这既因为实际结果的差异较小，也因为了解和了解其他人的想法和生活方式不那么容易。

I’m not pessimistic. Economics is the story of cycles. Things come, things go.

我并不悲观。经济学就是一个循环的故事。有来有去。

The unemployment rate is now the lowest it’s been in decades. Wages are now actually growing faster for low-income workers than the rich.⁷⁶ College costs by and large stopped growing once grants are factored in.⁷⁷ If everyone studied advances in health care, communication, transportation, and civil rights since the Glorious 1950s, my guess is most wouldn’t want to go back.

失业率目前处于几十年来的最低水平。低收入工人的工资增长速度实际上比富人更快。⁷⁶ 大学费用一旦计入助学金，就基本停止增长了。⁷⁷ 如果每个人都研究一下辉煌的1950年代以来医疗保健、通讯、交通和民权方面的进步，我猜大多数人都不想回到过去。

But a central theme of this story is that expectations move slower than reality on the ground. That was true when people clung to 1950s expectations as the economy changed over the next 35 years. And even if a middle-class boom began today, expectations that the odds are stacked against everyone but those at the top may stick around.

但这个故事的核心主题是，预期的变化比实际情况慢。当人们在接下来的35年里，经济发生巨变，却依然抱有20世纪50年代的预期时，情况确实如此。即使中产阶级繁荣始于今天，除了顶层人士之外，其他人都面临困境的预期可能依然存在。

So the era of “This isn’t working” may stick around.

因此，“这行不通”的时代可能会持续下去。

And the era of “We need something radically new, right now, whatever it is” may stick around.

“我们现在就需要一些全新的东西，无论它是什么”的时代可能会持续下去。

Which, in a way, is part of what starts events that led to things like World War II, where this story began.

从某种程度上来说，这也是导致第二次世界大战等事件发生的部分原因，而这个故事就是从第二次世界大战开始的。

History is just one damned thing after another.

历史就是一件又一件该死的事情。

65 B. Pisani，“主动型基金经理连续第九年落后于标准普尔 500 指数，成为指数化投资的胜利者”，CNBC（2019 年 3 月 15 日）。

68 www.nasa.gov

69 A. Ram，“投资组合经理不愿投资自有基金”，金融时报（2016 年 9 月 18 日）。

70 K. Murray，“医生如何死去”，佐卡洛公共广场（2011 年 11 月 30 日）。

71 B. Pisani，“主动型基金经理连续第九年落后于标准普尔 500 指数，成为指数化胜利者”，CNBC（2019 年 3 月 15 日）。

#↩

Like all books, The Psychology of Money wouldn’t have been possible without the help of countless people who helped me along the way. There are too many to list them all. But a few who have been particularly supportive:

和所有书籍一样，如果没有无数人的帮助，《金钱心理学》就不可能问世。他们太多了，无法一一列举。以下是一些给予我特别支持的人：

Brian Richards, who bet on me before anyone else.

布莱恩·理查兹 (Brian Richards)，他比其他任何人都更早地相信我。

Craig Shapiro, who bet on me when he didn’t have to.

克雷格·夏皮罗 (Craig Shapiro)，他在没有必要的情况下也把赌注押在我身上。

Gretchen Housel, whose support is unwavering.

格雷琴·豪瑟尔 (Gretchen Housel)，她的支持始终坚定不移。

Jenna Abdou, who helps while asking for nothing in return.

詹娜·阿卜杜 (Jenna Abdou) 提供帮助，但不求回报。

Craig Pearce, who encourages, guides, and grounds me.

克雷格·皮尔斯 (Craig Pearce)，他鼓励我、指导我、让我脚踏实地。

Jamie Catherwood, Josh Brown, Brent Beshore, Barry Ritholtz, Ben Carlson, Chris Hill, Michael Batnick, James Osorne, whose feedback is invaluable.

Jamie Catherwood、Josh Brown、Brent Beshore、Barry Ritholtz、Ben Carlson、Chris Hill、Michael Batnick 和 James Osorne，他们的反馈非常宝贵。

Thank you.

谢谢。

尽管我们已尽一切努力确保本书中信息的准确性，但对于任何人仅依赖本书中包含的信息而造成的任何损失，我们概不负责。

No responsibility for loss occasioned to any person or corporate body acting or refraining to act as a result of reading material in this book can be accepted by the Publisher, by the Author, or by the employers of the Author.

对于任何个人或法人因阅读本书材料而采取或不采取行动而造成的损失，出版商、作者或作者的雇主均不承担任何责任。
